quoteText: Was anyone hurt?
subQuotationList: ['Was anyone hurt?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
No one, I am thankful to say, except two housemaids
who lost their heads and jumped through a glass roof into the paved
court. They were in no danger. The fire never reached the bedrooms, I am
afraid. Still, they are bound to need doing up, everything black with
smoke and drenched in water and luckily they had that old-fashioned sort
of extinguisher that ruins _everything_. One really cannot complain. The
chief rooms were _completely_ gutted and everything was insured. Sylvia
Newport knows the people. I must get on to them this morning before that
ghoul Mrs Shutter snaps them up.
subQuotationList:
['No one, I am thankful to say,', 'except two housemaids
who lost their heads and jumped through a glass roof into the paved
court. They were in no danger. The fire never reached the bedrooms, I am
afraid. Still, they are bound to need doing up, everything black with
smoke and drenched in water and luckily they had that old-fashioned sort
of extinguisher that ruins _everything_. One really cannot complain. The
chief rooms were _completely_ gutted and everything was insured. Sylvia
Newport knows the people. I must get on to them this morning before that
ghoul Mrs Shutter snaps them up.']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
Heavens, how nasty this stuff is. I wish you'd take to it, John. You're
looking so tired lately. I don't know how I should get through my day
without it.
subQuotationList: ["Heavens, how nasty this stuff is. I wish you'd take to it, John. You're\nlooking so tired lately. I don't know how I should get through my day\nwithout it."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: But, mumsy, I haven't as much to do as you have.
subQuotationList: ["But, mumsy, I haven't as much to do as you have."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: That's true, my son.
subQuotationList: ["That's true, my son."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: What was your evening?
subQuotationList: ['What was your evening?']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
Audrey rang up at eight and asked me to dinner. Ten of us at the
Embassy, rather dreary. Afterwards we all went on to a party given by a
woman called de Trommet.
subQuotationList: ['Audrey rang up at eight and asked me to dinner. Ten of us at the\nEmbassy, rather dreary. Afterwards we all went on to a party given by a\nwoman called de Trommet.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I know who you mean. American. She hasn't paid for the toile-de-jouy
chair covers we made her last April. I had a dull time too; didn't hold
a card all the evening and came away four pounds ten to the bad.
subQuotationList: ["I know who you mean. American. She hasn't paid for the toile-de-jouy\nchair covers we made her last April. I had a dull time too; didn't hold\na card all the evening and came away four pounds ten to the bad."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Poor mumsy.
subQuotationList: ['Poor mumsy.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I'm lunching at Viola Chasm's. What are you doing? I didn't order
anything here, I'm afraid.
subQuotationList: ["I'm lunching at Viola Chasm's. What are you doing? I didn't order\nanything here, I'm afraid."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Nothing so far. I can always go round to Bratt's.
subQuotationList: ["Nothing so far. I can always go round to Bratt's."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
But that's so expensive. I'm sure if we ask Chambers she'll be able to
get you something in. I thought you were certain to be out.
subQuotationList: ["But that's so expensive. I'm sure if we ask Chambers she'll be able to\nget you something in. I thought you were certain to be out."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Well, I still may be. It isn't twelve yet.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I still may be. It isn't twelve yet."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
John, darling, there's been a muddle and Sonia has
arrived without Reggie. Could you be an angel and help me out? Only be
quick, because we're going in now
subQuotationList: ["John, darling, there's been a muddle and Sonia has\narrived without Reggie. Could you be an angel and help me out? Only be\nquick, because we're going in now"]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Where are you going for the week-end?
subQuotationList: ['Where are you going for the week-end?']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Hetton.
subQuotationList: ['Hetton.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Who's that? I forget.
subQuotationList: ["Who's that? I forget."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Tony Last.
subQuotationList: ['Tony Last.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Yes, of course. She's lovely, he's rather a stick. I didn't know you
knew them.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, of course. She's lovely, he's rather a stick. I didn't know you\nknew them."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
Well, I don't really. Tony asked me in Bratt's the other night. He may
have forgotten.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I don't really. Tony asked me in Bratt's the other night. He may\nhave forgotten."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Send a telegram and remind them. It is far better than ringing up. It
gives them less chance to make excuses. Send it to-morrow just before
you start. They owe me for a table.
subQuotationList: ['Send a telegram and remind them. It is far better than ringing up. It\ngives them less chance to make excuses. Send it to-morrow just before\nyou start. They owe me for a table.']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: What's their dossier?
subQuotationList: ["What's their dossier?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I used to see her quite a lot before she married. She was Brenda Rex,
Lord St Cloud's daughter, very fair, underwater look. People used to be
mad about her when she was a girl. Everyone thought she would marry Jock
Grant-Menzies at one time. Wasted on Tony Last, he's a prig. I should
say it was time she began to be bored. They've been married five or six
years. Quite well off but everything goes in keeping up the house. I've
never seen it but I've an idea it's huge and quite hideous. They've got
one child at least, perhaps more.
subQuotationList:
["I used to see her quite a lot before she married. She was Brenda Rex,
Lord St Cloud's daughter, very fair, underwater look. People used to be
mad about her when she was a girl. Everyone thought she would marry Jock
Grant-Menzies at one time. Wasted on Tony Last, he's a prig. I should
say it was time she began to be bored. They've been married five or six
years. Quite well off but everything goes in keeping up the house. I've
never seen it but I've an idea it's huge and quite hideous. They've got
one child at least, perhaps more."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Mumsy, you are wonderful. I believe you know about everyone.
subQuotationList: ['Mumsy, you are wonderful. I believe you know about everyone.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
It's a great help. All a matter of paying attention while people are
talking.
subQuotationList: ["It's a great help. All a matter of paying attention while people are\ntalking."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
That's the way, you are doing very nicely, Joyce. I'll soon
get you on to something more interesting.
subQuotationList: ["That's the way,", "you are doing very nicely, Joyce. I'll soon\nget you on to something more interesting."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Thank you, Mrs Beaver.
subQuotationList: ['Thank you, Mrs Beaver.']
speaker: Joyce

quoteText:
Mr
Beaver? Will you please hold the line, sir, Mrs Tipping would like to
speak to you.
subQuotationList: ['Mr\nBeaver? Will you please hold the line, sir, Mrs Tipping would like to\nspeak to you.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
Oh, Mr Beaver, I _am_ so sorry to trouble you. I was wondering, could
you _possibly_ tell me the name of the young man you introduced to me
last night at Madame de Trommet's? The one with the reddish moustache. I
think he was in Parliament.
subQuotationList:
["Oh, Mr Beaver, I _am_ so sorry to trouble you. I was wondering, could
you _possibly_ tell me the name of the young man you introduced to me
last night at Madame de Trommet's? The one with the reddish moustache. I
think he was in Parliament."]
speaker: Mrs Tipping
mentionTextsList: [['Mr Beaver', 'you', 'you', 'Madame de Trommet', 'The one with the reddish moustache', 'he']]
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['De Trommet'], ['Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['Jock Grant-Menzies']]]

quoteText: I expect you mean Jock Grant-Menzies.
subQuotationList: ['I expect you mean Jock Grant-Menzies.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Yes, that's the name. You don't by any chance know where I can find
him, do you?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's the name. You don't by any chance know where I can find\nhim, do you?"]
speaker: Mrs Tipping

quoteText:
He's in the book but I don't suppose he'll be at home now. You might be
able to get him at Bratt's at about one. He's almost always there.
subQuotationList: ["He's in the book but I don't suppose he'll be at home now. You might be\nable to get him at Bratt's at about one. He's almost always there."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Jock Grant-Menzies, Bratt's Club. Thank you so _very_ much. It _is_
kind of you. I hope you will come and see me some day. _Good_-bye.
subQuotationList: ["Jock Grant-Menzies, Bratt's Club. Thank you so _very_ much. It _is_\nkind of you. I hope you will come and see me some day. _Good_-bye."]
speaker: Mrs Tipping

quoteText:
Well, old boy, What are you
drinking?
subQuotationList: ['Well, old boy,', 'What are you\ndrinking?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Nothing so far.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing so far.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
But I think it's time I
had one. Brandy and ginger ale.
subQuotationList: ["But I think it's time I\nhad one. Brandy and ginger ale."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Who was the old girl you wished on me at that party last night?
subQuotationList: ['Who was the old girl you wished on me at that party last night?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies
referringExpression: Jock called to the barman and then said

quoteText: She's called Mrs Tipping.
subQuotationList: ["She's called Mrs Tipping."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I thought she might be. That explains it. They gave me a message
downstairs that someone with a name like that wanted me to lunch with
her.
subQuotationList: ['I thought she might be. That explains it. They gave me a message\ndownstairs that someone with a name like that wanted me to lunch with\nher.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Are you going?
subQuotationList: ['Are you going?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
No, I'm no good at lunch parties. Besides, I decided when I got up that
I'd have oysters here.
subQuotationList: ["No, I'm no good at lunch parties. Besides, I decided when I got up that\nI'd have oysters here."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Mr Beaver, sir, there's ten shillings against you in my books for last
month.
subQuotationList: ["Mr Beaver, sir, there's ten shillings against you in my books for last\nmonth."]
speaker: The Barman

quoteText: Ah, thank you, Macdougal, remind me some time, will you?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, thank you, Macdougal, remind me some time, will you?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Very good, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Very good, sir.']
speaker: The Barman

quoteText: I'm going to Hetton to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ["I'm going to Hetton to-morrow."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Are you now? Give Tony and Brenda my love.
subQuotationList: ['Are you now? Give Tony and Brenda my love.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: What's the form?
subQuotationList: ["What's the form?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Very quiet and enjoyable.
subQuotationList: ['Very quiet and enjoyable.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: No paper games?
subQuotationList: ['No paper games?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Oh, no, nothing like that. A certain amount of bridge and backgammon
and low poker with the neighbours.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, no, nothing like that. A certain amount of bridge and backgammon\nand low poker with the neighbours.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Comfortable?
subQuotationList: ['Comfortable?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Not bad. Plenty to drink. Rather a shortage of bathrooms. You can stay
in bed all the morning.
subQuotationList: ['Not bad. Plenty to drink. Rather a shortage of bathrooms. You can stay\nin bed all the morning.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: I've never met Brenda.
subQuotationList: ["I've never met Brenda."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
You'll like her, she's a grand girl. I often think Tony Last's one of
the happiest men I know. He's got just enough money, loves the place,
one son he's crazy about, devoted wife, not a worry in the world.
subQuotationList: ["You'll like her, she's a grand girl. I often think Tony Last's one of\nthe happiest men I know. He's got just enough money, loves the place,\none son he's crazy about, devoted wife, not a worry in the world."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Most enviable. You don't know anyone else who's going, do you? I was
wondering if I could get a lift down there.
subQuotationList: ["Most enviable. You don't know anyone else who's going, do you? I was\nwondering if I could get a lift down there."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I don't, I'm afraid. It's quite easy by train.
subQuotationList: ["I don't, I'm afraid. It's quite easy by train."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Yes, but it's more pleasant by road.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, but it's more pleasant by road."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: And cheaper.
subQuotationList: ['And cheaper.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Yes, and cheaper I suppose... well, I'm going down to lunch. You won't
have another?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, and cheaper I suppose... well, I'm going down to lunch. You won't\nhave another?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes, I think I will.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I think I will.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Oh, all right. Macdougal. Two more, please.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, all right. Macdougal. Two more, please.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Shall I book them to you, sir?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I book them to you, sir?']
speaker: The Barman

quoteText: Yes, if you will.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, if you will.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I made Beaver pay for a drink.
subQuotationList: ['I made Beaver pay for a drink.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: He can't have liked that.
subQuotationList: ["He can't have liked that."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: He nearly died of it. Know anything about pigs?
subQuotationList: ['He nearly died of it. Know anything about pigs?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: No. Why.
subQuotationList: ['No. Why.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Only that they keep writing to me about them from my constituency.
subQuotationList: ['Only that they keep writing to me about them from my constituency.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Mrs Tipping rang up a few minutes ago and asked whether you could come
to luncheon with her to-day.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs Tipping rang up a few minutes ago and asked whether you could come\nto luncheon with her to-day.']
speaker: The Porter

quoteText:
Will you ring her up and say that I shall be delighted to, but that I
may be a few minutes late?
subQuotationList: ['Will you ring her up and say that I shall be delighted to, but that I\nmay be a few minutes late?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Has her ladyship been called yet?
subQuotationList: ['Has her ladyship been called yet?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Then I'll have breakfast in her room.
subQuotationList: ["Then I'll have breakfast in her room."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Kiss.
subQuotationList: ['Kiss.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Anything interesting?
subQuotationList: ['Anything interesting?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
No. Mama wants nanny to send John's measurements. She's knitting him
something for Christmas. And the mayor wants me to open something next
month. I needn't, need I?
subQuotationList: ["No. Mama wants nanny to send John's measurements. She's knitting him\nsomething for Christmas. And the mayor wants me to open something next\nmonth. I needn't, need I?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I think you'd better, we haven't done anything for him for a long
time.
subQuotationList: ["I think you'd better, we haven't done anything for him for a long\ntime."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, you must write the speech. I'm getting too old for the girlish
one I used to give them all. And Angela says, will we stay for the New
Year?
subQuotationList: ["Well, you must write the speech. I'm getting too old for the girlish\none I used to give them all. And Angela says, will we stay for the New\nYear?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: That's easy. Not on her life, we won't.
subQuotationList: ["That's easy. Not on her life, we won't."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I guessed not... though it sounds an amusing party.
subQuotationList: ['I guessed not... though it sounds an amusing party.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You go if you like. I can't possibly get away.
subQuotationList: ["You go if you like. I can't possibly get away."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's all right. I knew it would be "no" before I opened the letter.
subQuotationList: ['That\'s all right. I knew it would be "no" before I opened the letter.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Well, what sort of pleasure can there be in going all the way to
Yorkshire in the middle of winter?
subQuotationList: ['Well, what sort of pleasure can there be in going all the way to\nYorkshire in the middle of winter?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Darling, don't be cross. I know we aren't going. I'm not making a thing
about it. I just thought it might be fun to eat someone else's food for
a bit.
subQuotationList: ["Darling, don't be cross. I know we aren't going. I'm not making a thing\nabout it. I just thought it might be fun to eat someone else's food for\na bit."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
As a matter of fact I probably _can_ manage to get away that
week-end.
subQuotationList: ['As a matter of fact I probably _can_ manage to get away that\nweek-end.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Darling, are you sure you wouldn't hate it?
subQuotationList: ["Darling, are you sure you wouldn't hate it?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I daresay not.
subQuotationList: ['I daresay not.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Reggie's
been making another speech... There's such an extraordinary picture of
Babe and Jock... a woman in America has had twins by two different
husbands. Would you have thought that possible?... Two more chaps in
gas ovens... a little girl has been strangled in a cemetery with a
bootlace... that play we went to about a farm is coming off. I don't believe you're listening.
Why doesn't Sylvia want Rupert to get the letter?
subQuotationList:
["Reggie's
been making another speech... There's such an extraordinary picture of
Babe and Jock... a woman in America has had twins by two different
husbands. Would you have thought that possible?... Two more chaps in
gas ovens... a little girl has been strangled in a cemetery with a
bootlace... that play we went to about a farm is coming off.", "I don't believe you're listening.
Why doesn't Sylvia want Rupert to get the letter?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Eh? Oh well, you see, she doesn't really trust Rupert.
subQuotationList: ["Eh? Oh well, you see, she doesn't really trust Rupert."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I _knew_ it. There's no such character as Rupert in the story. I shall
never read to you again.
subQuotationList: ["I _knew_ it. There's no such character as Rupert in the story. I shall\nnever read to you again."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, to tell you the truth I was just thinking.
subQuotationList: ['Well, to tell you the truth I was just thinking.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I was thinking how delightful it is, that it's Saturday morning and we
haven't got anyone coming for the week-end.
subQuotationList: ["I was thinking how delightful it is, that it's Saturday morning and we\nhaven't got anyone coming for the week-end."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, you thought that?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, you thought that?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Don't you?
subQuotationList: ["Don't you?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, it sometimes seems to me rather pointless keeping up a house this
size if we don't now and then ask some other people to stay in it.
subQuotationList: ["Well, it sometimes seems to me rather pointless keeping up a house this\nsize if we don't now and then ask some other people to stay in it."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
_Pointless?_ I can't think what you mean. I don't keep up this house to
be a hostel for a lot of bores to come and gossip in. We've always lived
here and I hope John will be able to keep it on after me. One has a duty
towards one's employees, and towards the place too. It's a definite part
of English life which would be a serious loss if...
subQuotationList:
["_Pointless?_ I can't think what you mean. I don't keep up this house to
be a hostel for a lot of bores to come and gossip in. We've always lived
here and I hope John will be able to keep it on after me. One has a duty
towards one's employees, and towards the place too. It's a definite part
of English life which would be a serious loss if..."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh God, What have I done?
subQuotationList: ['Oh God,', 'What have I done?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I say, am I being pompous again?
subQuotationList: ['I say, am I being pompous again?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Oh no,
darling, not _pompous_. You wouldn't know how.
subQuotationList: ["Oh no,\ndarling, not _pompous_. You wouldn't know how."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Sorry.
subQuotationList: ['Sorry.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
And, please, I didn't mean it. I'm jolly glad too, that
no one's coming.
subQuotationList: ["And, please, I didn't mean it. I'm jolly glad too, that\nno one's coming."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Now take it quite easy. Canter up slow and when she takes off lean
forward in the saddle and you'll be over like a bird. Keep her head
straight at it.
subQuotationList: ["Now take it quite easy. Canter up slow and when she takes off lean\nforward in the saddle and you'll be over like a bird. Keep her head\nstraight at it."]
speaker: Ben

quoteText:
What
d'you suppose your bloody legs are for? Here, take this and just give
her a tap when you get up to it!
subQuotationList: ["What\nd'you suppose your bloody legs are for? Here, take this and just give\nher a tap when you get up to it!"]
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Legs!
subQuotationList: ['Legs!']
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Oh, what's happened, Mr Hacket, is he hurt?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, what's happened, Mr Hacket, is he hurt?"]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: He's all right,
subQuotationList: ["He's all right,"]
speaker: Ben

quoteText: I'm all right, I think she put in a short step.
subQuotationList: ["I'm all right,", 'I think she put in a short step.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Short step my grandmother. You just opened your bloody legs and took an
arser. Keep hold on to the reins next time. You can lose a hunt that
way.
subQuotationList: ['Short step my grandmother. You just opened your bloody legs and took an\narser. Keep hold on to the reins next time. You can lose a hunt that\nway.']
speaker: Ben

quoteText:
There, how did that feel? You just skimmed over like a swallow. Try it
again?
subQuotationList: ['There, how did that feel? You just skimmed over like a swallow. Try it\nagain?']
speaker: Ben

quoteText:
Oh dear, look at all the mud on your
coat.
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear, look at all the mud on your\ncoat.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: We'll have you riding the winner at Aintree soon.
subQuotationList: ["We'll have you riding the winner at Aintree soon."]
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Good morning, Mr Hacket.
subQuotationList: ['Good morning, Mr Hacket.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Good morning, miss.
subQuotationList: ['Good morning, miss.']
speaker: Ben

quoteText:
Good-bye, Ben, may I come and see you doing the farm horses this
evening?
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye, Ben, may I come and see you doing the farm horses this\nevening?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
That's not for me to say. You must ask nanny. Tell you what though, the
grey carthorse has got worms. Would you like to see me give him a pill?
subQuotationList: ["That's not for me to say. You must ask nanny. Tell you what though, the\ngrey carthorse has got worms. Would you like to see me give him a pill?"]
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Oh yes; please, nanny, may I?
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes; please, nanny, may I?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
You must ask mother. Come along now, you've had quite enough of horses
for one day.
subQuotationList: ["You must ask mother. Come along now, you've had quite enough of horses\nfor one day."]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Can't have enough of horses, ever.
subQuotationList: ["Can't have enough of horses,", 'ever.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Can I have my milk in mummy's room?
subQuotationList: ["Can I have my milk in mummy's room?"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: That depends.
subQuotationList: ['That depends.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: We'll see
subQuotationList: ["We'll see"]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText:
That's
asking
subQuotationList: ["That's\nasking"]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Those that ask no questions hear no lies
subQuotationList: ['Those that ask no questions hear no lies']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: What does it depend on?
subQuotationList: ['What does it depend on?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Lots of things.
subQuotationList: ['Lots of things.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Tell me one of them.
subQuotationList: ['Tell me one of them.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: On your not asking a lot of silly questions.
subQuotationList: ['On your not asking a lot of silly questions.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Silly old tart.
subQuotationList: ['Silly old tart.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: _John!_ How dare you? What do you mean?
subQuotationList: ['_John!_ How dare you? What do you mean?']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Silly old tart, silly old tart
subQuotationList: ['Silly old tart, silly old tart']
speaker: John Andrew
referringExpression: John broke away from her hand and danced in front of her saying

quoteText:
Go straight up to the nursery, I am going to speak to your
mother about you.
subQuotationList: ['Go straight up to the nursery,', 'I am going to speak to your\nmother about you.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Please, nanny. I don't know what it means, but I didn't mean it.
subQuotationList: ["Please, nanny. I don't know what it means, but I didn't mean it."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Go straight to the nursery.
subQuotationList: ['Go straight to the nursery.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText:
It's been the same ever since Ben Hacket started teaching him to ride,
my lady, there's been no doing anything with him.
subQuotationList: ["It's been the same ever since Ben Hacket started teaching him to ride,\nmy lady, there's been no doing anything with him."]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: But, nanny, what exactly did he say?
subQuotationList: ['But, nanny, what exactly did he say?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, I couldn't repeat it, my lady.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I couldn't repeat it, my lady."]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText:
Nonsense, you must tell me. Otherwise I shall be thinking it something
far worse than it was.
subQuotationList: ['Nonsense, you must tell me. Otherwise I shall be thinking it something\nfar worse than it was.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
It couldn't have been worse... he called me a silly old tart, my
lady.
subQuotationList: ["It couldn't have been worse... he called me a silly old tart, my\nlady."]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: He said _that_?
subQuotationList: ['He said _that_?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Repeatedly. He danced in front of me all the way up the drive, _singing
it_.
subQuotationList: ['Repeatedly. He danced in front of me all the way up the drive, _singing\nit_.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: I see... well, you were quite right to tell me.
subQuotationList: ['I see... well, you were quite right to tell me.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Thank you, my lady, and since we are talking about it I think I ought
to say that it seems to me that Ben Hacket is making the child go ahead
far too quickly with his riding. It's very dangerous. He had what might
have been a serious fall this morning.
subQuotationList:
["Thank you, my lady, and since we are talking about it I think I ought
to say that it seems to me that Ben Hacket is making the child go ahead
far too quickly with his riding. It's very dangerous. He had what might
have been a serious fall this morning."]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: All right, nanny, I'll speak to Mr Last about it.
subQuotationList: ["All right, nanny, I'll speak to Mr Last about it."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Darling, _you_ must speak to him. You're so much better at being
serious than I am.
subQuotationList: ['Darling,', "_you_ must speak to him. You're so much better at being\nserious than I am."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I should have thought it was very nice to be called a tart, and anyway it's a word Ben often uses about people.
subQuotationList: ['I should have thought it was very nice to be called a tart,', "and anyway it's a word Ben often uses about people."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Well, he's got no business to.
subQuotationList: ["Well, he's got no business to."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I like Ben more than anyone in the world. And I should think he's
cleverer too.
subQuotationList: ["I like Ben more than anyone in the world. And I should think he's\ncleverer too."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Now, you know you don't like him more than your mother.
subQuotationList: ["Now, you know you don't like him more than your mother."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes I do. _Far_ more.
subQuotationList: ['Yes I do. _Far_ more.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Now listen, John. It was very wrong
of you to call nanny a silly old tart. First, because it was unkind to
her. Think of all the things she does for you every day.
subQuotationList: ['Now listen, John. It was very wrong\nof you to call nanny a silly old tart. First, because it was unkind to\nher. Think of all the things she does for you every day.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: She's paid to.
subQuotationList: ["She's paid to."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Be quiet. And secondly, because you were using a word which people of
your age and class do not use. Poor people use certain expressions which
gentlemen do not. You are a gentleman. When you grow up all this house
and lots of other things besides will belong to you. You must learn to
speak like someone who is going to have these things and to be
considerate to people less fortunate than you, particularly women. Do
you understand?
subQuotationList:
['Be quiet. And secondly, because you were using a word which people of
your age and class do not use. Poor people use certain expressions which
gentlemen do not. You are a gentleman. When you grow up all this house
and lots of other things besides will belong to you. You must learn to
speak like someone who is going to have these things and to be
considerate to people less fortunate than you, particularly women. Do
you understand?']
speaker: Tony Last
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Andrew'], ['John Last'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Last']]]

quoteText: Is Ben less fortunate than me?
subQuotationList: ['Is Ben less fortunate than me?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
That has nothing to do with it. Now you are to go upstairs and say you
are sorry to nanny and promise never to use that word about anyone
again.
subQuotationList: ['That has nothing to do with it. Now you are to go upstairs and say you\nare sorry to nanny and promise never to use that word about anyone\nagain.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: All right.
subQuotationList: ['All right.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
And because you have been so naughty to-day you are not to ride
to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['And because you have been so naughty to-day you are not to ride\nto-morrow.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: To-morrow's Sunday.
subQuotationList: ["To-morrow's Sunday."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Well, next day then.
subQuotationList: ['Well, next day then.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: But you said
subQuotationList: ['But you said']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: It isn't fair to change now.
subQuotationList: ["It isn't fair to change now."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
John, don't argue. If you are not careful I shall send Thunderclap back
to Uncle Reggie and say that I find you are not a good enough boy to
keep it. You wouldn't like that, would you?
subQuotationList: ["John, don't argue. If you are not careful I shall send Thunderclap back\nto Uncle Reggie and say that I find you are not a good enough boy to\nkeep it. You wouldn't like that, would you?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
What would Uncle Reggie do with her? She couldn't carry him. Besides,
he's usually abroad.
subQuotationList: ["What would Uncle Reggie do with her? She couldn't carry him. Besides,\nhe's usually abroad."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
He'd give her to some other little boy. Anyway, that's got nothing to
do with it. Now run off and say you're sorry to nanny.
subQuotationList: ["He'd give her to some other little boy. Anyway, that's got nothing to\ndo with it. Now run off and say you're sorry to nanny."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It's all right riding on Monday, isn't it? You
did _say_
subQuotationList: ["It's all right riding on Monday, isn't it? You\ndid _say_"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Yes, I suppose so.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I suppose so.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Hooray. Thunderclap went very well to-day. We jumped a big post and
rail. She refused first time but went like a bird after that.
subQuotationList: ['Hooray. Thunderclap went very well to-day. We jumped a big post and\nrail. She refused first time but went like a bird after that.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Didn't you come off?
subQuotationList: ["Didn't you come off?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, once. It wasn't Thunderclap's fault. I just opened my bloody legs
and cut an arser.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, once. It wasn't Thunderclap's fault. I just opened my bloody legs\nand cut an arser."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: How did the lecture go?
subQuotationList: ['How did the lecture go?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Bad. Rotten bad.
subQuotationList: ['Bad. Rotten bad.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: The trouble is that nanny's jealous of Ben.
subQuotationList: ["The trouble is that nanny's jealous of Ben."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm not sure we shan't both be soon.
subQuotationList: ["I'm not sure we shan't both be soon."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'm sure it does me a great deal of good.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sure it does me a great deal of good."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, darling, and when we get tired of it we might try an alphabetical
diet, having things beginning with a different letter every day. J would
be hungry, nothing but jam and jellied eels... What are your plans for

subQuotationList:

quoteText:
Nothing much. Carter's coming up at five to go over a few things. I may
go to Pigstanton after luncheon. I think we've got a tenant for Lowater
Farm but it's been empty some time and I ought to see how much needs
doing to it.
subQuotationList:
["Nothing much. Carter's coming up at five to go over a few things. I may
go to Pigstanton after luncheon. I think we've got a tenant for Lowater
Farm but it's been empty some time and I ought to see how much needs
doing to it."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I wouldn't say "no" to going in to the "movies".
subQuotationList: ['I wouldn\'t say "no" to going in to the "movies".']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: All right. I can easily leave Lowater till Monday.
subQuotationList: ['All right. I can easily leave Lowater till Monday.']
speaker: Tony Last

subQuotationList: ["And we might go to Woolworth's afterwards, eh?"]

quoteText: Hell.
subQuotationList: ['Hell.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Badders?
subQuotationList: ['Badders?']
speaker: Brenda

subQuotationList: ["It's a young man."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That sounds all right.
subQuotationList: ['That sounds all right.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh no it's not. Wait till you see him.
subQuotationList: ["Oh no it's not. Wait till you see him."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: What's he coming here for? Did you ask him to stay?
subQuotationList: ["What's he coming here for? Did you ask him to stay?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I suppose I did in a vague kind of way. I went to Bratt's one evening
and he was the only chap there so we had some drinks and he said
something about wanting to see the house...
subQuotationList: ["I suppose I did in a vague kind of way. I went to Bratt's one evening\nand he was the only chap there so we had some drinks and he said\nsomething about wanting to see the house..."]

subQuotationList: ['I suppose you were tight.']

subQuotationList: ["Not really, but I never thought he'd hold it against me."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, it jolly well serves you right. That's what comes of going up to
London on business and leaving me alone here... Who is he anyway?
subQuotationList: ["Well, it jolly well serves you right. That's what comes of going up to\nLondon on business and leaving me alone here... Who is he anyway?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Just a young man. His mother keeps that shop.
subQuotationList: ['Just a young man. His mother keeps that shop.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I used to know her. She's hell. Come to think of it we owe her some
money.
subQuotationList: ["I used to know her. She's hell. Come to think of it we owe her some\nmoney."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Look here, we must put a call through and say we're ill.
subQuotationList: ["Look here, we must put a call through and say we're ill."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Too late, he's in the train now, recklessly mixing starch and protein
in the Great Western three and sixpenny lunch... Anyway, he can go into
Galahad. No one who sleeps there ever comes again--the bed's agony I
believe.
subQuotationList:
["Too late, he's in the train now, recklessly mixing starch and protein
in the Great Western three and sixpenny lunch... Anyway, he can go into

What on earth are we going to do with him? It's too late to get anyone
else.
subQuotationList: ["What on earth are we going to do with him? It's too late to get anyone\nelse."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You go over to Pigstanton. I'll look after him. It's easier alone. We
can take him to the movies to-night, and to-morrow he can see over the
house. If we're lucky he may go up by the evening train. Does he have to
work on Monday morning?
subQuotationList:
["You go over to Pigstanton. I'll look after him. It's easier alone. We
can take him to the movies to-night, and to-morrow he can see over the
house. If we're lucky he may go up by the evening train. Does he have to
work on Monday morning?"]

quoteText: I shouldn't know.
subQuotationList: ["I shouldn't know."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It is nice that you
were able to come. I must break it to you at once that we haven't got a
party. I'm afraid you'll be terribly bored... Tony had to go out but
he'll be in soon... was the train crowded? It often is on Saturdays...
would you like to come outside? It'll be dark soon and we might get some
of the sun while we can...
subQuotationList:
["It is nice that you
were able to come. I must break it to you at once that we haven't got a

subQuotationList: ['Polly Cockpurse is having one soon.']

quoteText: Yes, I know.

speaker: Brenda

subQuotationList: ['Are you coming up for it?']

subQuotationList: ["I don't expect so. We never go anywhere nowadays."]

subQuotationList: ["Oh, didn't you know? That's broken up."]

quoteText: When?
subQuotationList: ['When?']

subQuotationList: ['It began in Austria this summer...']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: And Billy Angmering?
subQuotationList: ['And Billy Angmering?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: He's having a terrific walk out with a girl called Sheila Shrub.
subQuotationList: ["He's having a terrific walk out with a girl called Sheila Shrub."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: And the Helm-Hubbards?
subQuotationList: ['And the Helm-Hubbards?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
That marriage isn't going too well either... Daisy has started a new
restaurant. It's going very well... and there's a new night club called
the Warren...
subQuotationList: ["That marriage isn't going too well either... Daisy has started a new\nrestaurant. It's going very well... and there's a new night club called\nthe Warren..."]

subQuotationList: ['Dear me,', 'What fun everyone seems to be having.']

How do you do? I didn't know you were coming.
Daddy said he had a week-end to himself for once. Do you hunt?
subQuotationList: ['How do you do?', "I didn't know you were coming.\nDaddy said he had a week-end to himself for once. Do you hunt?"]

quoteText: Not for a long time.

Ben says it stands to reason everyone ought to hunt who can afford to,
for the good of the country.

quoteText: Oh.

The grey horse at the farm has
got worms.

Oh dear, what would nanny say if she heard you talking

Well, if I was you I'd do something and earn some money. Then you'd be

I

There just isn't anything nice about him. He's got a silly voice and a

silly feet and silly toes, silly head and silly

directly. Ring for a drink when you feel like it.
subQuotationList: ["No, really, I shouldn't if I were you. You wouldn't enjoy it. I only go\nbecause I more or less have to. You stay here. Brenda will be down\ndirectly. Ring for a drink when you feel like it."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, all right.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, all right.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: See you later then.
subQuotationList: ['See you later then.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: How very sad.
subQuotationList: ['How very sad.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, _I_ thought it was sad too, but it isn't. Ben said it made him
laugh fit to bust his pants.
subQuotationList: ["Well, _I_ thought it was sad too, but it isn't. Ben said it made him\nlaugh fit to bust his pants."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
...And so as we stand here bareheaded at this solemn hour of the
week, let
us remember our Gracious Queen Empress in whose service we are here, and
pray that she may long be spared to send us at her bidding to do our
duty in the uttermost parts of the earth; and let us think of our dear
ones far away and the homes we have left in her name, and remember that
though miles of barren continent and leagues of ocean divide us, we are
never so near to them as on these Sunday mornings, united with them
across dune and mountain in our loyalty to our sovereign and
thanksgiving for her welfare; one with them as proud subjects of her
sceptre and crown.
subQuotationList:
['...And so as we stand here bareheaded at this solemn hour of the
week,', 'let
us remember our Gracious Queen Empress in whose service we are here, and
pray that she may long be spared to send us at her bidding to do our
duty in the uttermost parts of the earth; and let us think of our dear
ones far away and the homes we have left in her name, and remember that
though miles of barren continent and leagues of ocean divide us, we are
never so near to them as on these Sunday mornings, united with them
across dune and mountain in our loyalty to our sovereign and
thanksgiving for her welfare; one with them as proud subjects of her
sceptre and crown.']
speaker: The Vicar

quoteText: The Reverend Tendril "e do speak uncommon "igh of the Queen,
subQuotationList: ['The Reverend Tendril "e do speak uncommon "igh of the Queen,']
speaker: A Gardener'S Wife
referringExpression: a gardeners wife had once remarked to Tony

quoteText: Lady Brenda is not ill, I hope?
subQuotationList: ['Lady Brenda is not ill, I hope?']
speaker: The Vicar

quoteText: No, nothing serious.
subQuotationList: ['No, nothing serious.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: A most interesting sermon, Vicar.
subQuotationList: ['A most interesting sermon, Vicar.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
My dear boy, I'm delighted to hear you say so. It is one of my
favourites. But have you never heard it before?
subQuotationList: ["My dear boy, I'm delighted to hear you say so. It is one of my\nfavourites. But have you never heard it before?"]
speaker: The Vicar

quoteText: No, I assure you.
subQuotationList: ['No, I assure you.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I haven't used it here lately. When I am asked to supply elsewhere it
is the one I invariably choose. Let me see now, I always make a note of
the times I use it.
subQuotationList: ["I haven't used it here lately. When I am asked to supply elsewhere it\nis the one I invariably choose. Let me see now, I always make a note of\nthe times I use it."]
speaker: The Vicar

quoteText:
Ah yes, here we are. I preached it first in Jellalabad when the
Coldstream Guards were there; then I used it in the Red Sea coming home
from my fourth leave; then at Sidmouth... Mentone... Winchester... to
the Girl Guides at their summer rally in 1921... the Church Stage Guild
at Leicester... twice at Bournemouth during the winter of 1926 when
poor Ada was so ill... No, I don't seem to have used it here since
1911, when you would have been too young to enjoy it...
subQuotationList:
["Ah yes, here we are. I preached it first in Jellalabad when the
Coldstream Guards were there; then I used it in the Red Sea coming home
from my fourth leave; then at Sidmouth... Mentone... Winchester... to
the Girl Guides at their summer rally in 1921... the Church Stage Guild
at Leicester... twice at Bournemouth during the winter of 1926 when
poor Ada was so ill... No, I don't seem to have used it here since
1911, when you would have been too young to enjoy it..."]
speaker: The Vicar

quoteText:
...he'd have been all right, Ben says,
if he had been able to cat the rum up, but mules can't cat, neither
can horses...
subQuotationList: ["...he'd have been all right, Ben says,\nif he had been able to cat the rum up, but mules can't cat, neither\ncan horses..."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
How many times
have I told you not to go repeating whatever Ben Hacket tells you? Miss
Tendril didn't want to hear about Peppermint. And don't ever use that
rude word "cat" again.
subQuotationList:
['How many times
have I told you not to go repeating whatever Ben Hacket tells you? Miss
Tendril didn't want to hear about Peppermint. And don't ever use that
rude word "cat" again.']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: It only means to be sick.
subQuotationList: ['It only means to be sick.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Well, Miss Tendril isn't interested in being sick...
subQuotationList: ["Well, Miss Tendril isn't interested in being sick..."]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: I say, can't I carry something?
subQuotationList: ["I say, can't I carry something?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: No thanks, I've got everything safe. How did you sleep?
subQuotationList: ["No thanks, I've got everything safe. How did you sleep?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Beautifully.
subQuotationList: ['Beautifully.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I bet you didn't.
subQuotationList: ["I bet you didn't."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, I'm not a very good sleeper.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I'm not a very good sleeper."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Next time you come you shall have a different room. But I daresay you
won't ever come again. People so seldom do. It is very sad because it's
such fun for us having them and we never make any new friends living
down here.
subQuotationList:
["Next time you come you shall have a different room. But I daresay you
won't ever come again. People so seldom do. It is very sad because it's
such fun for us having them and we never make any new friends living
down here."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Tony's gone to church.
subQuotationList: ["Tony's gone to church."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Yes, he likes that. He'll be back soon. Let's go out for a minute or
two, it looks lovely.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, he likes that. He'll be back soon. Let's go out for a minute or\ntwo, it looks lovely."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
... Now cut to me again, and I'll see if it's any clearer... Oh yes... there is going to be a
sudden death which will cause you great pleasure and profit. In fact you
are going to kill someone. I can't tell if it's a man or a woman...
yes, a woman... then you are going to go on a long journey across the
sea, marry six dark men and have eleven children, grow a beard and die.
subQuotationList:
['... Now cut to me again,', "and I'll see if it's any clearer... Oh yes... there is going to be a
sudden death which will cause you great pleasure and profit. In fact you
are going to kill someone. I can't tell if it's a man or a woman...
yes, a woman... then you are going to go on a long journey across the
sea, marry six dark men and have eleven children, grow a beard and die."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Beast. And all this time I've been thinking it was serious. Hullo,
Tony. Jolly church?
subQuotationList: ["Beast. And all this time I've been thinking it was serious. Hullo,\nTony. Jolly church?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Most enjoyable; how about some sherry?
subQuotationList: ['Most enjoyable; how about some sherry?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Darling,
you're being heroic with Beaver.
subQuotationList: ["Darling,\nyou're being heroic with Beaver."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, I quite enjoy coping--in fact I'm bitching him rather.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I quite enjoy coping--in fact I'm bitching him rather."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
So I saw. Well, I'll look after him this afternoon and he's going this
evening.
subQuotationList: ["So I saw. Well, I'll look after him this afternoon and he's going this\nevening."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Is he? I'll be quite sorry. You know that's a difference between us,
that when someone's awful you just run away and hide, while I actually
enjoy it--making up to them and showing off to myself how well I can do
it. Besides, Beaver isn't so bad. He's quite like us in some ways.
subQuotationList:
["Is he? I'll be quite sorry. You know that's a difference between us,
that when someone's awful you just run away and hide, while I actually
enjoy it--making up to them and showing off to myself how well I can do
it. Besides, Beaver isn't so bad. He's quite like us in some ways."]
speaker: Brenda
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Beaver'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText: He's not like me,
subQuotationList: ["He's not like me,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, if it would really amuse you, we might
go over the house. I know it isn't fashionable to like this sort of
architecture now--my Aunt Frances says it is an authentic Pecksniff--but
I think it's good of its kind.
subQuotationList:
["Well, if it would really amuse you, we might
go over the house. I know it isn't fashionable to like this sort of
architecture now--my Aunt Frances says it is an authentic Pecksniff--but
I think it's good of its kind."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
The So-and-so's have got one rather like
that at Such-and-such a place
subQuotationList: ["The So-and-so's have got one rather like\nthat at Such-and-such a place"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Yes, I've seen it
but I think mine is the earlier.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I've seen it\nbut I think mine is the earlier."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, what did you
think of it?
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'what did you\nthink of it?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Magnificent.
subQuotationList: ['Magnificent.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: You don't have to say that to me, you know.
subQuotationList: ["You don't have to say that to me, you know."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, a lot of the things are very fine.
subQuotationList: ['Well, a lot of the things are very fine.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes, the _things_ are all right, I suppose.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, the _things_ are all right, I suppose.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: But don't you like the house?
subQuotationList: ["But don't you like the house?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Me? I _detest_ it... at least I don't mean that really, but I do wish
sometimes that it wasn't _all_, every bit of it, so appallingly ugly.
Only I'd die rather than say that to Tony. We could never live anywhere
else, of course. He's crazy about the place... It's funny. None of us
minded very much when my brother Reggie sold _our_ house--and that was
built by Vanbrugh, you know... I suppose we're lucky to be able to
afford to keep it up at all. Do you know how much it costs just to live
here? We should be quite rich if it wasn't for that. As it is we support
fifteen servants indoors, besides gardeners and carpenters and a
night-watchman and all the people at the farm and odd little men
constantly popping in to wind the clocks and cook the accounts and clean
the moat, while Tony and I have to fuss about whether it's cheaper to
take a car up to London for the night or buy an excursion ticket... I
shouldn't feel so badly about it if it were a really lovely house--like
my home for instance... but of course Tony's been brought up here and
sees it all differently...
subQuotationList:
["Me? I _detest_ it... at least I don't mean that really, but I do wish
sometimes that it wasn't _all_, every bit of it, so appallingly ugly.
Only I'd die rather than say that to Tony. We could never live anywhere
else, of course. He's crazy about the place... It's funny. None of us
minded very much when my brother Reggie sold _our_ house--and that was
built by Vanbrugh, you know... I suppose we're lucky to be able to
afford to keep it up at all. Do you know how much it costs just to live
here? We should be quite rich if it wasn't for that. As it is we support
fifteen servants indoors, besides gardeners and carpenters and a
night-watchman and all the people at the farm and odd little men
constantly popping in to wind the clocks and cook the accounts and clean
the moat, while Tony and I have to fuss about whether it's cheaper to
take a car up to London for the night or buy an excursion ticket... I
shouldn't feel so badly about it if it were a really lovely house--like
my home for instance... but of course Tony's been brought up here and
sees it all differently..."]
speaker: Brenda
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony'], ['Reggie'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Brenda', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText:
I don't want to seem inhospitable, but if
you're going to catch that train, you ought really to be getting ready.
subQuotationList: ["I don't want to seem inhospitable, but if\nyou're going to catch that train, you ought really to be getting ready."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's all right. I've persuaded him to stay on till to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ["That's all right. I've persuaded him to stay on till to-morrow."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: If you're sure you don't...
subQuotationList: ["If you're sure you don't..."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Splendid. I _am_ glad. It's beastly going up at this time, particularly
by that train.
subQuotationList: ["Splendid. I _am_ glad. It's beastly going up at this time, particularly\nby that train."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I thought Mr Beaver was going.
subQuotationList: ['I thought Mr Beaver was going.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Not till to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['Not till to-morrow.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Oh.
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
I've
thought of something
subQuotationList: ["I've\nthought of something"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Do let me know when you come to London.
subQuotationList: ['Do let me know when you come to London.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I may be up this week.
subQuotationList: ['I may be up this week.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Well, that's the last of _him_. You were superb, darling. I'm sure he's
gone back thinking that you're mad about him.
subQuotationList: ["Well, that's the last of _him_. You were superb, darling. I'm sure he's\ngone back thinking that you're mad about him."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, he wasn't too awful.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, he wasn't too awful."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
No. I must say he took a very intelligent interest when we went round
the house.
subQuotationList: ['No. I must say he took a very intelligent interest when we went round\nthe house.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Who was
there?
subQuotationList: ['Who was\nthere?']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: No one.
subQuotationList: ['No one.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: No one? My poor boy.
subQuotationList: ['No one? My poor boy.']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
They weren't expecting me. It was awful at first but got better. They
were just as you said. She's very charming. He scarcely spoke.
subQuotationList: ["They weren't expecting me. It was awful at first but got better. They\nwere just as you said. She's very charming. He scarcely spoke."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I wish I saw her sometimes.
subQuotationList: ['I wish I saw her sometimes.']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: She talked of taking a flat in London.
subQuotationList: ['She talked of taking a flat in London.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: _Did_ she?
subQuotationList: ['_Did_ she?']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: What does she want?
subQuotationList: ['What does she want?']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
Something quite simple. Two rooms and a bath. But it's all quite vague.
She hasn't said anything to Tony yet.
subQuotationList: ["Something quite simple. Two rooms and a bath. But it's all quite vague.\nShe hasn't said anything to Tony yet."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I am sure I shall be able to find her something.
subQuotationList: ['I am sure I shall be able to find her something.']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
Darling, what _does_ the country do to you? You look like a thousand
pounds. Where _did_ you get that suit?
subQuotationList: ['Darling, what _does_ the country do to you? You look like a thousand\npounds. Where _did_ you get that suit?']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: I don't know. Some shop.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know. Some shop."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: What's the news at Hetton?
subQuotationList: ["What's the news at Hetton?"]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
All the same. Tony madly feudal. John Andrew cursing like a stable
boy.
subQuotationList: ['All the same. Tony madly feudal. John Andrew cursing like a stable\nboy.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: And you?
subQuotationList: ['And you?']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Me? Oh, I'm all right.
subQuotationList: ["Me? Oh, I'm all right."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Who's been to stay?
subQuotationList: ["Who's been to stay?"]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: No one. We had a friend of Tony's called Mr Beaver last week-end.
subQuotationList: ["No one. We had a friend of Tony's called Mr Beaver last week-end."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
John Beaver?... How very odd. I shouldn't have thought he was at all
Tony's ticket.
subQuotationList: ["John Beaver?... How very odd. I shouldn't have thought he was at all\nTony's ticket."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: He wasn't... What's he like?
subQuotationList: ["He wasn't... What's he like?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I hardly know him. I see him at Margot's sometimes. He's a great one
for going everywhere.
subQuotationList: ["I hardly know him. I see him at Margot's sometimes. He's a great one\nfor going everywhere."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: I thought he was rather pathetic.
subQuotationList: ['I thought he was rather pathetic.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, he's _pathetic_ all right. D'you fancy him?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, he's _pathetic_ all right. D'you fancy him?"]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Heavens, no.
subQuotationList: ['Heavens, no.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I don't believe he has a spark of human
feeling,
subQuotationList: ["I don't believe he has a spark of human\nfeeling,"]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: He's never done that to me, What do you suppose is Mr Beaver's sex-life?
subQuotationList: ["He's never done that to me,", "What do you suppose is Mr Beaver's sex-life?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I shouldn't know. Pretty dim, I imagine... You _do_ fancy him?
subQuotationList: ["I shouldn't know. Pretty dim, I imagine... You _do_ fancy him?"]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Oh well, I don't see such a lot of young men...
subQuotationList: ['Oh well,', "I don't see such a lot of young men..."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Do come up
for it. It's certain to be amusing.
subQuotationList: ["Do come up\nfor it. It's certain to be amusing."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
I might... if I can find someone to take me. Tony doesn't like her...
I can't go to parties alone at my age.
subQuotationList: ["I might... if I can find someone to take me. Tony doesn't like her...\nI can't go to parties alone at my age."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You're in luck, there's your Mr
Beaver's mother. God, what a
party,
subQuotationList: ["You're in luck,", "there's your Mr\nBeaver's mother.", 'God, what a\nparty,']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
You're both coming to my party, darlings? Only don't tell anyone about it. It's
just a very small, secret party. The house will only hold a few
people--just old friends.
subQuotationList: ["You're both coming to my party, darlings?", "Only don't tell anyone about it. It's\njust a very small, secret party. The house will only hold a few\npeople--just old friends."]
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText:
It would be wonderful to see what Polly's _real_ old friends were
like, She hasn't known anyone more than five years.
subQuotationList: ["It would be wonderful to see what Polly's _real_ old friends were\nlike,", "She hasn't known anyone more than five years."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: I wish Tony could see her point.
subQuotationList: ['I wish Tony could see her point.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I _must_ come and
speak to you, though I'm in a great hurry. It's _so_ long since we met
and John has been telling me about a _delightful_ week-end he had with
you.
subQuotationList:
["I _must_ come and
speak to you, though I'm in a great hurry. It's _so_ long since we met
and John has been telling me about a _delightful_ week-end he had with
you."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: It was very quiet.
subQuotationList: ['It was very quiet.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
That's just what he _loves_. Poor boy, he gets rushed off his feet in
London. Tell me, Lady Brenda, is it true you are looking for a
flat?--because I think I've got just the place for you. It's being done
up now and will be ready well before Christmas.
subQuotationList:
["That's just what he _loves_. Poor boy, he gets rushed off his feet in
London. Tell me, Lady Brenda, is it true you are looking for a
flat?--because I think I've got just the place for you. It's being done
up now and will be ready well before Christmas."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
Oh dear, I must fly. You couldn't possibly come in for a
cocktail, this evening? Then you could hear all about it.
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear, I must fly. You couldn't possibly come in for a\ncocktail, this evening? Then you could hear all about it."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: I _could_...
subQuotationList: ['I _could_...']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Then _do_. I'll expect you about six. I daresay you don't know where I
live?
subQuotationList: ["Then _do_. I'll expect you about six. I daresay you don't know where I\nlive?"]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: What's all this about a flat?
subQuotationList: ["What's all this about a flat?"]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Oh, just something I thought of...
subQuotationList: ['Oh, just something I thought of...']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'll ask my husband and let you know.
subQuotationList: ["I'll ask my husband and let you know."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You _will_ let me know soon, won't you, because _everyone_ will be
wanting one.
subQuotationList: ["You _will_ let me know soon, won't you, because _everyone_ will be\nwanting one."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: I'll let you know very soon.
subQuotationList: ["I'll let you know very soon."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm sure you want to go away.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sure you want to go away."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No, really.
subQuotationList: ['No, really.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I've got lots to read.
subQuotationList: ["I've got lots to read."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I _want_ to stay.
subQuotationList: ['I _want_ to stay.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
It's very sweet of you. I suppose you wouldn't
like to take me to Polly's party, would you?
subQuotationList: ["It's very sweet of you.", "I suppose you wouldn't\nlike to take me to Polly's party, would you?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I wish
I could, but I've promised to dine out for it.
subQuotationList: ['I wish\nI could,', "but I've promised to dine out for it."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I was afraid you would have.
subQuotationList: ['I was afraid you would have.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: But we'll meet there.
subQuotationList: ["But we'll meet there."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes, if I go.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, if I go.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I wish I could have taken you.
subQuotationList: ['I wish I could have taken you.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: It's quite all right... I just wondered.
subQuotationList: ["It's quite all right... I just wondered."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Well, I think perhaps I'll
leave you now.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I think perhaps I'll\nleave you now."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes, run along. Thank you for coming.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, run along. Thank you for coming.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Barnardo case?
subQuotationList: ['Barnardo case?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Down and out, sunk, right under.
subQuotationList: ['Down and out,', 'sunk, right under.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Good day?
subQuotationList: ['Good day?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Saw Marjorie and her filthy dog. Bought some things.
Lunched at Daisy's new joint. Bone-setter. That's all.
subQuotationList: ["Saw Marjorie and her filthy dog. Bought some things.\nLunched at Daisy's new joint. Bone-setter. That's all."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You know I wish you'd give up these day-trips to London. They're far
too much for you.
subQuotationList: ["You know I wish you'd give up these day-trips to London. They're far\ntoo much for you."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Me? Oh, I'm all right. Wish I was dead, that's all... and please,
please, darling Tony, don't say anything about bed, because I can't
move.
subQuotationList: ["Me? Oh, I'm all right. Wish I was dead, that's all... and please,\nplease, darling Tony, don't say anything about bed, because I can't\nmove."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You seem in wonderful spirits to-day,
subQuotationList: ['You seem in wonderful spirits to-day,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I feel big. I think it's Mr Cruttwell. He puts all one's nerves right
and one's circulation and everything.
subQuotationList: ["I feel big. I think it's Mr Cruttwell. He puts all one's nerves right\nand one's circulation and everything."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Where's mummy gone?
subQuotationList: ["Where's mummy gone?"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: London.
subQuotationList: ['London.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Why?
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Someone called Lady Cockpurse is giving a party.
subQuotationList: ['Someone called Lady Cockpurse is giving a party.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Is she nice?
subQuotationList: ['Is she nice?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Mummy thinks so. I don't.
subQuotationList: ["Mummy thinks so. I don't."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Why?
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Because she looks like a monkey.
subQuotationList: ['Because she looks like a monkey.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I should love to see her. Does she live in a cage? Has she got a tail?
Ben saw a woman who looked like a fish, with scales all over instead of
skin. It was in a circus in Cairo. Smelt like a fish too, Ben says.
subQuotationList: ['I should love to see her. Does she live in a cage? Has she got a tail?\nBen saw a woman who looked like a fish, with scales all over instead of\nskin. It was in a circus in Cairo. Smelt like a fish too, Ben says.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Daddy, what does Lady Cockpurse eat?
subQuotationList: ['Daddy, what does Lady Cockpurse eat?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Oh, nuts and things.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, nuts and things.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Nuts and what things?
subQuotationList: ['Nuts and what things?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Different kinds of nuts.
subQuotationList: ['Different kinds of nuts.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You mustn't say things like that about real people, Whatever would Lady Cockpurse do if she heard about it?
subQuotationList: ["You mustn't say things like that about real people,", 'Whatever would Lady Cockpurse do if she heard about it?']
speaker: Nanny

quoteText:
She'd gibber and chatter and lash round with her tail, and then I
expect she'd catch some nice, big, juicy fleas and forget all about it.
subQuotationList: ["She'd gibber and chatter and lash round with her tail, and then I\nexpect she'd catch some nice, big, juicy fleas and forget all about it."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Lovely, darling. New?
subQuotationList: ['Lovely, darling. New?']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Fairly.
subQuotationList: ['Fairly.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Look
here, are you absolutely sure you can't make Allan come to-night?
subQuotationList: ["Look\nhere, are you absolutely sure you can't make Allan come to-night?"]
speaker: The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining

quoteText:
Absolutely. He's got a meeting in Camberwell. He may not even come to
Polly's.
subQuotationList: ["Absolutely. He's got a meeting in Camberwell. He may not even come to\nPolly's."]
speaker: Marjorie
addressees: ['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']

quoteText: Is there _any_ man you can bring?
subQuotationList: ['Is there _any_ man you can bring?']
speaker: The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining

quoteText: Can't think of anybody.
subQuotationList: ["Can't think of anybody."]
speaker: Marjorie
addressees: ['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']

quoteText:
Well, we shall have to be one short, that's all. I can't think what's
happened to-night. I rang up John Beaver but even _he_ won't come.
subQuotationList: ["Well, we shall have to be one short, that's all. I can't think what's\nhappened to-night. I rang up John Beaver but even _he_ won't come."]
speaker: The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marjorie', 'The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

quoteText:
You know, you're causing a
great deal of trouble. You've taken London's only spare man.
subQuotationList: ['You know,', "you're causing a\ngreat deal of trouble. You've taken London's only spare man."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Oh dear, I didn't realize...
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear, I didn't realize..."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I must see your Mr Beaver properly, Let's make him
take off his coat and drink something.
subQuotationList: ['I must see your Mr Beaver properly,', "Let's make him\ntake off his coat and drink something."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
Mrs Jimmy Deane's very upset that she couldn't get you for to-night. I
didn't give away what you were doing.
subQuotationList: ["Mrs Jimmy Deane's very upset that she couldn't get you for to-night. I\ndidn't give away what you were doing."]
speaker: Marjorie
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

quoteText: Give her my love, Anyway we'll all meet at Polly's.
subQuotationList: ['Give her my love,', "Anyway we'll all meet at Polly's."]
speaker: John Beaver
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']], [['Marjorie', 'John Beaver', 'The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining'], ['Polly Cockpurse']]]

quoteText: I must go, we're dining at nine.
subQuotationList: ["I must go, we're dining at nine."]
speaker: Marjorie
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Marjorie', 'The Woman At Whose House She Was Dining']]]

quoteText: Stay a bit, She's sure to be late.
subQuotationList: ['Stay a bit,', "She's sure to be late."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No, I must go. Enjoy yourselves, bless you both.
subQuotationList: ['No, I must go. Enjoy yourselves, bless you both.']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
I suppose we ought to be going
too.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose we ought to be going\ntoo.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes, where?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, where?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I thought Espinosa's.
subQuotationList: ["I thought Espinosa's."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Yes, lovely. Only listen. I want you to understand right away that it's
_my_ dinner.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, lovely. Only listen. I want you to understand right away that it's\n_my_ dinner."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Of course not... nothing of the sort.
subQuotationList: ['Of course not... nothing of the sort.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Yes it is. I'm a year older than you and an old married woman and quite
rich, so, please, I'm going to pay.
subQuotationList: ["Yes it is. I'm a year older than you and an old married woman and quite\nrich, so, please, I'm going to pay."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: _Please_, Brenda,
subQuotationList: ['_Please_, Brenda,']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
You choose. Very little for me,
but it must only have starch, no protein.
subQuotationList: ['You choose. Very little for me,\nbut it must only have starch, no protein.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You can't think how exciting
it is for me to take a young man out. I've never done it before.
subQuotationList: ["You can't think how exciting\nit is for me to take a young man out. I've never done it before."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm sorry I was an ass in the taxi just now.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry I was an ass in the taxi just now."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Eh?
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Did you mind when I tried to kiss you just
now?
subQuotationList: ['Did you mind when I tried to kiss you just\nnow?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Me? No, not particularly.
subQuotationList: ['Me? No, not particularly.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Then why wouldn't you let me?
subQuotationList: ["Then why wouldn't you let me?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Oh dear, you've got a lot to learn.
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear, you've got a lot to learn."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: How d'you mean?
subQuotationList: ["How d'you mean?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: You mustn't ever ask questions like that. Will you try and remember?
subQuotationList: ["You mustn't ever ask questions like that. Will you try and remember?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You talk to me as if I was an undergraduate having
his first walk out.
subQuotationList: ['You talk to me as if I was an undergraduate having\nhis first walk out.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Oh, is this a walk out?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, is this a walk out?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Not as far as I am concerned.
subQuotationList: ['Not as far as I am concerned.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I am not sure it hasn't been a
mistake, taking you out to dinner. Let's ask for the bill and go to
Polly's.
subQuotationList: ["I am not sure it hasn't been a\nmistake, taking you out to dinner. Let's ask for the bill and go to\nPolly's."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You've got to _learn_ to be nicer, I don't believe
you'd find it impossible. How
much do I tip him?
subQuotationList: ["You've got to _learn_ to be nicer,", "I don't believe\nyou'd find it impossible.", 'How\nmuch do I tip him?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Are you sure that's enough?
I should have given twice as much.
subQuotationList: ["Are you sure that's enough?\nI should have given twice as much."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: It's exactly right,
subQuotationList: ["It's exactly right,"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Shut up, Come here.
subQuotationList: ['Shut up,', 'Come here.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You're not to leave me, please.
I'm not going to know anybody,
subQuotationList: ["You're not to leave me, please.\nI'm not going to know anybody,"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
All right, I'll give you a rest. Only don't
let me get left.
subQuotationList: ["All right, I'll give you a rest. Only don't\nlet me get left."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Time for supper.
subQuotationList: ['Time for supper.']
speaker: Brenda
referringExpression: Brenda saw he was out of temper and said

quoteText: I don't propose to move for a long time, d'you mind?
subQuotationList: ["I don't propose to move for a long time, d'you mind?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Are you dying of it?
subQuotationList: ['Are you dying of it?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No, indeed, never happier.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed, never happier.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Well, I am. Let's go and dance.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I am. Let's go and dance."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Oh dear, now we're done. We can't go back
to the table... it almost looks as though we should have to go home.
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear,', "now we're done. We can't go back\nto the table... it almost looks as though we should have to go home."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: It's not two.
subQuotationList: ["It's not two."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
That's late for me. Look here, don't you come. Stay and enjoy
yourself.
subQuotationList: ["That's late for me. Look here, don't you come. Stay and enjoy\nyourself."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Of course I'll come,
subQuotationList: ["Of course I'll come,"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: There already?
subQuotationList: ['There already?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I am afraid I can't ask you in for a drink. You see it isn't my house
and I shouldn't know where to find anything.
subQuotationList: ["I am afraid I can't ask you in for a drink. You see it isn't my house\nand I shouldn't know where to find anything."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No, of course not.
subQuotationList: ['No, of course not.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Well, good night, my dear. Thank you a thousand times for looking after
me. I'm afraid I rather bitched your evening.
subQuotationList: ["Well, good night, my dear. Thank you a thousand times for looking after\nme. I'm afraid I rather bitched your evening."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No, of course not,
subQuotationList: ['No, of course not,']
speaker: John Beaver
