quoteText: Will you ring me in the morning... promise?
subQuotationList: ['Will you ring me in the morning... promise?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Darling, I was just going to ring off. I thought you must have gone
back to Polly's. Is the telephone not by your bed?
subQuotationList: ["Darling, I was just going to ring off. I thought you must have gone\nback to Polly's. Is the telephone not by your bed?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No, it's on the ground floor.
subQuotationList: ["No, it's on the ground floor."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Oh dear, then it wasn't a very good idea to ring up, was it?
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear, then it wasn't a very good idea to ring up, was it?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, I don't know. What is it?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I don't know. What is it?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Just to say "good night".
subQuotationList: ['Just to say "good night".']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, I see, well--good night.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I see, well--good night.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: And you'll ring me in the morning?
subQuotationList: ["And you'll ring me in the morning?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Early, before you've made any plans.
subQuotationList: ["Early, before you've made any plans."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Then good night, bless you.
subQuotationList: ['Then good night, bless you.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: ...going away in the middle of the party.
subQuotationList: ['...going away in the middle of the party.']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: I can't tell you how innocent it was. He didn't even come in.
subQuotationList: ["I can't tell you how innocent it was. He didn't even come in."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No one is going to know that.
subQuotationList: ['No one is going to know that.']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: And he was furious when I rang him up.
subQuotationList: ['And he was furious when I rang him up.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: What does he think of you?
subQuotationList: ['What does he think of you?']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
Simply can't make me out at all... terribly puzzled, and rather bored
in bits.
subQuotationList: ["Simply can't make me out at all... terribly puzzled, and rather bored\nin bits."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Are you going to go on with it?
subQuotationList: ['Are you going to go on with it?']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: I shouldn't know.
subQuotationList: ["I shouldn't know."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Perhaps that's him.
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps that's him."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: But, really, Brenda, he's such a _dreary_ young man.
subQuotationList: ["But, really, Brenda, he's such a _dreary_ young man."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
I know it all. He's second rate and a snob and, I should think, as cold
as a fish, but I happen to have a fancy for him, that's all... besides
I'm not sure he's _altogether_ awful... he's got that odious mother
whom he adores... and he's always been very poor. I don't think he's
had a fair deal. I heard all about it last night. He got engaged once
but they couldn't get married because of money and since then he's never
had a proper affair with anyone decent... he's got to be taught a whole
lot of things. That's part of his attraction.
subQuotationList:
["I know it all. He's second rate and a snob and, I should think, as cold
as a fish, but I happen to have a fancy for him, that's all... besides
I'm not sure he's _altogether_ awful... he's got that odious mother
whom he adores... and he's always been very poor. I don't think he's
had a fair deal. I heard all about it last night. He got engaged once
but they couldn't get married because of money and since then he's never
had a proper affair with anyone decent... he's got to be taught a whole
lot of things. That's part of his attraction."]
speaker: Brenda
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Mrs. Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

quoteText: Oh dear, I see you're very serious.
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear, I see you're very serious."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Perhaps _that's_ him.
subQuotationList: ["Perhaps _that's_ him."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Good morning, darling, what's the dirt to-day?
subQuotationList: ["Good morning, darling, what's the dirt to-day?"]
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText: Oh, Polly, what a good party last night.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, Polly, what a good party last night.']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
Not so bad for the old girl, was it? I say, what about your sister and
Mr Beaver?
subQuotationList: ['Not so bad for the old girl, was it? I say, what about your sister and\nMr Beaver?']
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText: What about them?
subQuotationList: ['What about them?']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: How long has _that_ been on?
subQuotationList: ['How long has _that_ been on?']
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText: There's nothing doing there, Polly.
subQuotationList: ["There's nothing doing there, Polly."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
Don't you tell me. They were well away last night. How's the boy
managed it? That's what I want to know. He must have something we didn't
know about...
subQuotationList: ["Don't you tell me. They were well away last night. How's the boy\nmanaged it? That's what I want to know. He must have something we didn't\nknow about..."]
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText:
So Polly's on to your story. She'll be telling everyone in London at
this moment.
subQuotationList: ["So Polly's on to your story. She'll be telling everyone in London at\nthis moment."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
How I wish there was anything to tell! The cub hasn't even rung me
up... Well, I'll leave him in peace. If he doesn't do anything about me,
I'll go down to Hetton this afternoon. Perhaps that's him.
subQuotationList: ["How I wish there was anything to tell! The cub hasn't even rung me\nup... Well, I'll leave him in peace. If he doesn't do anything about me,\nI'll go down to Hetton this afternoon. Perhaps that's him."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I hear Brenda disgraced
herself,
subQuotationList: ['I hear Brenda disgraced\nherself,']
speaker: Allan

quoteText:
Goodness, People do think that young men are easily come
by.
subQuotationList: ['Goodness,', 'People do think that young men are easily come\nby.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I scarcely saw you at Polly's last night, What
became of you?
subQuotationList: ["I scarcely saw you at Polly's last night,", 'What\nbecame of you?']
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: We went early. Brenda Last was tired.
subQuotationList: ['We went early. Brenda Last was tired.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
She was looking lovely. I am so glad you've made friends with her. When
are you going to see her again?
subQuotationList: ["She was looking lovely. I am so glad you've made friends with her. When\nare you going to see her again?"]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: I said I'd ring up.
subQuotationList: ["I said I'd ring up."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Well, why don't you?
subQuotationList: ["Well, why don't you?"]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText:
Oh, mumsy, what's the use? I can't afford to start taking about women
like Brenda Last. If I ring up she'll say, what are you doing, and I
shall have to ask her to something, and it will be the same thing every
day. I simply haven't the money.
subQuotationList:
["Oh, mumsy, what's the use? I can't afford to start taking about women
like Brenda Last. If I ring up she'll say, what are you doing, and I
shall have to ask her to something, and it will be the same thing every
day. I simply haven't the money."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I know, my son. It's very difficult for you... and you're wonderful
about money. I ought to be grateful that I haven't a son always coming
to me with debts. Still, it doesn't do to deny yourself _everything_,
you know. You're getting to be an old bachelor already at twenty-five. I
could see Brenda liked you, that evening she came here.
subQuotationList:
["I know, my son. It's very difficult for you... and you're wonderful
about money. I ought to be grateful that I haven't a son always coming
to me with debts. Still, it doesn't do to deny yourself _everything_,
you know. You're getting to be an old bachelor already at twenty-five. I
could see Brenda liked you, that evening she came here."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda']]]

quoteText: Oh, she likes me all right.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, she likes me all right.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I hope she makes up her mind about that flat. They're going like hot
cakes. I shall have to look about for another suitable house to split
up. You'd be surprised who've been taking them--quite a number of people
with houses in London already... Well, I must be getting back to work.
I'm away for two nights by the way. See that Chambers looks after you
properly. There are some Australians Sylvia Newport discovered who want
to take a house in the country, so I'm driving them round to one or two
that might do for them. Where are you lunching?
subQuotationList:
["I hope she makes up her mind about that flat. They're going like hot
cakes. I shall have to look about for another suitable house to split
up. You'd be surprised who've been taking them--quite a number of people
with houses in London already... Well, I must be getting back to work.
I'm away for two nights by the way. See that Chambers looks after you
properly. There are some Australians Sylvia Newport discovered who want
to take a house in the country, so I'm driving them round to one or two
that might do for them. Where are you lunching?"]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: Margot's.
subQuotationList: ["Margot's."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
So that's that, I daresay I'm
glad really.
subQuotationList: ["So that's that,", "I daresay I'm\nglad really."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I don't
seem to have anywhere to lunch,
subQuotationList: ["I don't\nseem to have anywhere to lunch,"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Why don't you come to Margot's? I know she'd love it.
subQuotationList: ["Why don't you come to Margot's? I know she'd love it."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Well, ring up and ask her.
subQuotationList: ['Well, ring up and ask her.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I kept trying to get through to you this
morning, but the line was always engaged.
subQuotationList: ['I kept trying to get through to you this\nmorning,', 'but the line was always engaged.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Oh, come on, I'll sock you a movie.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, come on,', "I'll sock you a movie."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Is mummy coming back to-day?
subQuotationList: ['Is mummy coming back to-day?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: I hope so.
subQuotationList: ['I hope so.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
That monkey-woman's party has lasted a long time. Can I come in to the
station and meet her?
subQuotationList: ["That monkey-woman's party has lasted a long time. Can I come in to the\nstation and meet her?"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Yes, we'll both go.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, we'll both go."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
She hasn't seen Thunderclap for four days. She hasn't seen me jump the
new post and rail, has she, daddy?
subQuotationList: ["She hasn't seen Thunderclap for four days. She hasn't seen me jump the\nnew post and rail, has she, daddy?"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Her
ladyship coming back to-day?
subQuotationList: ['Her\nladyship coming back to-day?']
speaker: The Stationmaster

quoteText:
I've been expecting her every day. You know what it is when ladies get
to London.
subQuotationList: ["I've been expecting her every day. You know what it is when ladies get\nto London."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Sam Brace's wife went to London and he couldn't get her back. Had to go
up and fetch her himself. And then she give him a hiding.
subQuotationList: ["Sam Brace's wife went to London and he couldn't get her back. Had to go\nup and fetch her himself. And then she give him a hiding."]
speaker: The Stationmaster
mentionEntitiesList: [[["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ['Sam Brace'], ["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ["Sam Brace'S Wife"], ['Sam Brace']]]

quoteText:
You've _both_ come. What angels you are. I don't
at all deserve it.
subQuotationList: ["You've _both_ come. What angels you are. I don't\nat all deserve it."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, mummy, have you brought the monkey-lady?
subQuotationList: ['Oh, mummy, have you brought the monkey-lady?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: What _does_ the child mean?
subQuotationList: ['What _does_ the child mean?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: He's got it into his head that your chum Polly has a tail.
subQuotationList: ["He's got it into his head that your chum Polly has a tail."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Come to think of it, I shouldn't be surprised if she had.
subQuotationList: ["Come to think of it, I shouldn't be surprised if she had."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: What's all the news?
subQuotationList: ["What's all the news?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Ben's put the rail up ever so high and Thunderclap and I jumped it six
times yesterday and six times again to-day and two more of the fish in
the little pond are dead, floating upside down all swollen and nanny
burnt her finger on the kettle yesterday and daddy and I saw a fox just
as near as anything and he sat quite still and then went away into the
wood and I began drawing a picture of a battle only I couldn't finish it
because the paints weren't right and the grey carthorse the one that had
worms is quite well again.
subQuotationList:
["Ben's put the rail up ever so high and Thunderclap and I jumped it six
times yesterday and six times again to-day and two more of the fish in
the little pond are dead, floating upside down all swollen and nanny
burnt her finger on the kettle yesterday and daddy and I saw a fox just
as near as anything and he sat quite still and then went away into the
wood and I began drawing a picture of a battle only I couldn't finish it
because the paints weren't right and the grey carthorse the one that had
worms is quite well again."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Nothing much has happened, We've missed you. What did you
find to do in London all this time?
subQuotationList: ['Nothing much has happened,', "We've missed you. What did you\nfind to do in London all this time?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Me? Oh, I've been behaving rather badly to tell you the truth.
subQuotationList: ["Me? Oh, I've been behaving rather badly to tell you the truth."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Buying things?
subQuotationList: ['Buying things?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Worse. I've been carrying on madly with young men and I've spent heaps
of money and I've enjoyed it very much indeed. But there's one awful
thing.
subQuotationList: ["Worse. I've been carrying on madly with young men and I've spent heaps\nof money and I've enjoyed it very much indeed. But there's one awful\nthing."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: What's that?
subQuotationList: ["What's that?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, I think it had better keep. It's something you won't like at all.
subQuotationList: ["No, I think it had better keep. It's something you won't like at all."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You've bought a Pekingese.
subQuotationList: ["You've bought a Pekingese."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Worse, far worse. Only I haven't done it yet. But I _want_ to
dreadfully.
subQuotationList: ["Worse, far worse. Only I haven't done it yet. But I _want_ to\ndreadfully."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Go on.
subQuotationList: ['Go on.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Tony, I've found a flat.
subQuotationList: ["Tony, I've found a flat."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, you'd better lose it again, quick.
subQuotationList: ["Well, you'd better lose it again, quick."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
All right. I'll attack you about it again later. Meanwhile, try not to
brood about it.
subQuotationList: ["All right. I'll attack you about it again later. Meanwhile, try not to\nbrood about it."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I shan't give it another thought.
subQuotationList: ["I shan't give it another thought."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: What's a flat, daddy?
subQuotationList: ["What's a flat, daddy?"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
I suppose all this means that you're going to start again about your
flat?
subQuotationList: ["I suppose all this means that you're going to start again about your\nflat?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Mmmm.
subQuotationList: ['Mmmm.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You haven't signed any papers yet, have you?
subQuotationList: ["You haven't signed any papers yet, have you?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh no.
subQuotationList: ['Oh no.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Then no great harm's done.
subQuotationList: ["Then no great harm's done."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Listen, you
haven't been brooding?
subQuotationList: ["Listen, you\nhaven't been brooding?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Because, you see, when you say 'flat' you're thinking of something
quite different to me. _You_ mean by a flat, a lift and a man in
uniform, and a big front door with knobs, and an entrance hall and doors
opening in all directions, with kitchens and sculleries and dining-rooms
and drawing-rooms and servants' bedrooms... don't you, Tony?
subQuotationList:
["Because, you see, when you say 'flat' you're thinking of something
quite different to me. _You_ mean by a flat, a lift and a man in
uniform, and a big front door with knobs, and an entrance hall and doors
opening in all directions, with kitchens and sculleries and dining-rooms
and drawing-rooms and servants' bedrooms... don't you, Tony?"]
speaker: Brenda
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: More or less.
subQuotationList: ['More or less.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
_Exactly._ Now _I_ mean just a bedroom and a bath and a telephone. You
see the difference? Now a woman I know--
subQuotationList: ['_Exactly._ Now _I_ mean just a bedroom and a bath and a telephone. You\nsee the difference? Now a woman I know--']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Who?
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Just a woman--has fixed up a whole house like that off Belgrave Square
and they are three pounds a week, no rates and taxes, constant hot water
and central heating, woman comes in to make the bed when required, what
d'you think of that?
subQuotationList:
["Just a woman--has fixed up a whole house like that off Belgrave Square
and they are three pounds a week, no rates and taxes, constant hot water
and central heating, woman comes in to make the bed when required, what
d'you think of that?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I see.
subQuotationList: ['I see.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Now this is how I look at it. What's three pounds a week? Less than
nine bob a night. Where could one stay for less than nine bob a night
with all those advantages? You're always going to the club, and that
costs more, and I can't stay often with Marjorie because it's hell for
her having me, and anyway she's got that dog, and you're always saying
when I come back in the evenings after shopping,
subQuotationList:
["Now this is how I look at it. What's three pounds a week? Less than
nine bob a night. Where could one stay for less than nine bob a night
with all those advantages? You're always going to the club, and that
costs more, and I can't stay often with Marjorie because it's hell for
her having me, and anyway she's got that dog, and you're always saying
when I come back in the evenings after shopping,"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: you say,
subQuotationList: ['you say,']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Time and again you
say it. I'm sure we spend much more than three pounds a week through not
having a flat. Tell you what, I'll give up Mr Cruttwell. How's that?
subQuotationList: ["Time and again you\nsay it. I'm sure we spend much more than three pounds a week through not\nhaving a flat. Tell you what, I'll give up Mr Cruttwell. How's that?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: D'you really want this thing?
subQuotationList: ["D'you really want this thing?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Mmm.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Well, I'll have to see. We _might_ manage it, but it'll mean putting
off the improvements down here.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I'll have to see. We _might_ manage it, but it'll mean putting\noff the improvements down here."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I don't really deserve it, I've been
carrying on _anyhow_ this week.
subQuotationList: ["I don't really deserve it,", "I've been\ncarrying on _anyhow_ this week."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I'm sorry to be pompous, but I
just don't want your Mr Beaver hanging about the house all day and
calling me Marjorie.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry to be pompous,", "but I\njust don't want your Mr Beaver hanging about the house all day and\ncalling me Marjorie."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Oh well, the flat won't be long now.
subQuotationList: ["Oh well, the flat won't be long now."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
And I shall go on saying that I think you're making a ridiculous
mistake.
subQuotationList: ["And I shall go on saying that I think you're making a ridiculous\nmistake."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: It's just that you don't like Mr Beaver.
subQuotationList: ["It's just that you don't like Mr Beaver."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: It isn't only that. I think it's hard cheese on Tony.
subQuotationList: ["It isn't only that. I think it's hard cheese on Tony."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: Oh, Tony's all right.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, Tony's all right."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: And if there's a row--
subQuotationList: ["And if there's a row--"]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: There won't be a row.
subQuotationList: ["There won't be a row."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You never know. If there is, I don't want Allan to think I've been
helping to arrange things.
subQuotationList: ["You never know. If there is, I don't want Allan to think I've been\nhelping to arrange things."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText: I wasn't so disagreeable to you about Robin Beaseley.
subQuotationList: ["I wasn't so disagreeable to you about Robin Beaseley."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: There was never much in that,
subQuotationList: ['There was never much in that,']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
Of course the subject has
not been mentioned between John and myself, but if what I hear is true,
I think it will do the boy a world of good. Of course he's always been
very much in demand and had a great number of friends, but _that isn't
the same thing_. I've felt for a long time a Lack of Something in him,
and I think that a charming and experienced woman like Brenda Last is
just the person to help him. He's got a _very_ affectionate nature, but
he's so sensitive that he hardly ever lets it appear... to tell you the
truth I felt something of the kind was in the air last week, so I made
an excuse to go away for a few days. If I had been there things might
never have come to anything. He's very shy and reserved even to me. I'll
have the chess-men done up and sent round to you this afternoon. Thank
you so much.
subQuotationList:
["Of course the subject has
not been mentioned between John and myself, but if what I hear is true,
I think it will do the boy a world of good. Of course he's always been
very much in demand and had a great number of friends, but _that isn't
the same thing_. I've felt for a long time a Lack of Something in him,
and I think that a charming and experienced woman like Brenda Last is
just the person to help him. He's got a _very_ affectionate nature, but
he's so sensitive that he hardly ever lets it appear... to tell you the
truth I felt something of the kind was in the air last week, so I made
an excuse to go away for a few days. If I had been there things might
never have come to anything. He's very shy and reserved even to me. I'll
have the chess-men done up and sent round to you this afternoon. Thank
you so much."]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

quoteText:
I'm talking from the
flat.
subQuotationList: ["I'm talking from the\nflat."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, ah.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, ah.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: _Darling_, do try to sound interested. It's very exciting for me.
subQuotationList: ["_Darling_, do try to sound interested. It's very exciting for me."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: What's it like?
subQuotationList: ["What's it like?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, there are a good many smells at present and the bath makes odd
sounds and when you turn on the hot tap there's just a rush of air and
that's all, and the cold tap keeps dripping and the water is rather
brown and the cupboard doors are jammed and the curtains won't pull
right across so that the street lamp shines in all night... but it's
_lovely_.
subQuotationList:
["Well, there are a good many smells at present and the bath makes odd
sounds and when you turn on the hot tap there's just a rush of air and
that's all, and the cold tap keeps dripping and the water is rather
brown and the cupboard doors are jammed and the curtains won't pull
right across so that the street lamp shines in all night... but it's
_lovely_."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You don't say so.
subQuotationList: ["You don't say so."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Tony, you must be nice about it. It's all so exciting--front door and a
latch-key and all... And someone sent me a lot of flowers to-day--so
many that there's hardly room for them and I've had to put them in the
basin on account of having no pots. It wasn't you, was it?
subQuotationList:
["Tony, you must be nice about it. It's all so exciting--front door and a
latch-key and all... And someone sent me a lot of flowers to-day--so
many that there's hardly room for them and I've had to put them in the
basin on account of having no pots. It wasn't you, was it?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Yes... as a matter of fact.
subQuotationList: ['Yes... as a matter of fact.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Darling, I did so hope it was... how like you.
subQuotationList: ['Darling, I did so hope it was... how like you.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Three minutes, please.
subQuotationList: ['Three minutes, please.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Must stop now.
subQuotationList: ['Must stop now.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: When are you coming back?
subQuotationList: ['When are you coming back?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Almost at once. Good night, my sweet.
subQuotationList: ['Almost at once. Good night, my sweet.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: What a lot of talk,
subQuotationList: ['What a lot of talk,']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Wasn't it sweet of Tony to send those flowers?
subQuotationList: ["Wasn't it sweet of Tony to send those flowers?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm not awfully fond of Tony.
subQuotationList: ["I'm not awfully fond of Tony."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Don't let that worry you, my beauty, he doesn't like you _at all_.
subQuotationList: ["Don't let that worry you, my beauty, he doesn't like you _at all_."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: _Doesn't_ he? Why not?
subQuotationList: ["_Doesn't_ he? Why not?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
No one does except me. You must get that clear... it's very odd that
_I_ should.
subQuotationList: ["No one does except me. You must get that clear... it's very odd that\n_I_ should."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
How difficult it is for us, to realize that this is indeed
Christmas. Instead of the glowing log fire and windows tight shuttered
against the drifting snow, we have only the harsh glare of an alien sun;
instead of the happy circle of loved faces, of home and family, we have
the uncomprehending stares of the subjugated, though no doubt grateful,
heathen. Instead of the placid ox and ass of Bethlehem, we have for companions
the ravening tiger and the exotic camel, the furtive jackal and the
ponderous elephant...
subQuotationList:
['How difficult it is for us,', 'to realize that this is indeed
Christmas. Instead of the glowing log fire and windows tight shuttered
against the drifting snow, we have only the harsh glare of an alien sun;
instead of the happy circle of loved faces, of home and family, we have
the uncomprehending stares of the subjugated, though no doubt grateful,
heathen. Instead of the placid ox and ass of Bethlehem,', 'we have for companions
the ravening tiger and the exotic camel, the furtive jackal and the
ponderous elephant...']
speaker: The Vicar

quoteText:
Dear child, all these feelings of delicacy are valueless;
only the rich realize the gulf that separates them from the poor,
subQuotationList: ['Dear child, all these feelings of delicacy are valueless;\nonly the rich realize the gulf that separates them from the poor,']
speaker: Aunt Frances
referringExpression: Aunt Frances with acid mind quickly discerned the trouble and attempted to reassure her saying

quoteText:
I can't complain, he's never pretended to like me
much. And anyway it was a damned silly present.
subQuotationList: ["I can't complain, he's never pretended to like me\nmuch. And anyway it was a damned silly present."]
speaker: Brenda
referringExpression: Brenda felt a little sick when she read this letter but she showed it to Marjorie saying

quoteText: Don't come, darling. I'll make it all right with them.
subQuotationList: ["Don't come, darling. I'll make it all right with them."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No, I'll come. I haven't seen so much of you in the last three weeks.
subQuotationList: ["No, I'll come. I haven't seen so much of you in the last three weeks."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'll tell you something very odd, Who do you think is here?
subQuotationList: ["I'll tell you something very odd,", 'Who do you think is here?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Who?
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Our old friend Beaver.
subQuotationList: ['Our old friend Beaver.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Why's that odd particularly?
subQuotationList: ["Why's that odd particularly?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Oh, I don't know. I'd forgotten all about him, hadn't you? D'you think
he sent a telegram as he did to us?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I don't know. I'd forgotten all about him, hadn't you? D'you think\nhe sent a telegram as he did to us?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I daresay.
subQuotationList: ['I daresay.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
All kinds of changes since we saw you last.
Brenda's taken a flat in London.
subQuotationList: ["All kinds of changes since we saw you last.\nBrenda's taken a flat in London."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, I know.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I know.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: How?
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, my mother let it to her, you know.
subQuotationList: ['Well, my mother let it to her, you know.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
You never told
me who was behind your flat. I might not have been so amiable if I'd
known.
subQuotationList: ["You never told\nme who was behind your flat. I might not have been so amiable if I'd\nknown."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, darling, that's why.
subQuotationList: ["No, darling, that's why."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I daresay it was a mistake to ask him. It's so hard to know.
subQuotationList: ["I daresay it was a mistake to ask him. It's so hard to know."]
speaker: Angela

quoteText:
I've
made a New Year resolution.
subQuotationList: ["I've\nmade a New Year resolution."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Anything to do with spending more time at home?
subQuotationList: ['Anything to do with spending more time at home?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Oh no, _quite_ the reverse. Listen, Tony, it's serious. I think I'll
take a course of something.
subQuotationList: ["Oh no, _quite_ the reverse. Listen, Tony, it's serious. I think I'll\ntake a course of something."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Not bone-setters again? I thought that was over.
subQuotationList: ['Not bone-setters again? I thought that was over.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
No, something like economics. You see, I've been thinking. I don't
really _do_ anything at all at present. The house runs itself. It seems
to me time I _took_ to something. Now you're always talking about going
into Parliament. Well, if I had done a course of economics I could be
some use canvassing and writing speeches and things--you know, the way
Marjorie did when Allan was standing on the Clydeside. There are all
sorts of lectures in London, to do with the University, where girls go.
Don't you think it's rather a good idea?
subQuotationList:
["No, something like economics. You see, I've been thinking. I don't
really _do_ anything at all at present. The house runs itself. It seems
to me time I _took_ to something. Now you're always talking about going
into Parliament. Well, if I had done a course of economics I could be
some use canvassing and writing speeches and things--you know, the way
Marjorie did when Allan was standing on the Clydeside. There are all
sorts of lectures in London, to do with the University, where girls go.
Don't you think it's rather a good idea?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: It's one better than the bone-setters,
subQuotationList: ["It's one better than the bone-setters,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Anyone here?
subQuotationList: ['Anyone here?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Very quiet to-night, sir. Mr Last is in the dining-room.
subQuotationList: ['Very quiet to-night, sir. Mr Last is in the dining-room.']
speaker: The Barman

quoteText: Hullo, Chucked? Come and join me.
subQuotationList: ['Hullo,', 'Chucked? Come and join me.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Been chucked?
subQuotationList: ['Been chucked?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, it's the last time I ask that bitch out.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, it's the last time I ask that bitch out."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Better have a drink. I've been drinking a whole lot. Much the best
thing.
subQuotationList: ["Better have a drink. I've been drinking a whole lot. Much the best\nthing."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Just come up for the night, Staying here.
subQuotationList: ['Just come up for the night,', 'Staying here.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You've got a flat now, haven't you?
subQuotationList: ["You've got a flat now, haven't you?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Well, Brenda has. There isn't really room for two... we tried it once
and it wasn't a success.
subQuotationList: ["Well, Brenda has. There isn't really room for two... we tried it once\nand it wasn't a success."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: What's she doing to-night?
subQuotationList: ["What's she doing to-night?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Out somewhere. I didn't let her know I was coming... silly not to, but
you see I got fed up with being alone at Hetton and thought I'd like to
see Brenda, so I came up suddenly on the spur of the moment, just like
that. Damned silly thing to do. Might have known she'd be going out
somewhere... she's very high-principled about chucking... so there it
is. She's going to ring me up here later, if she can get away.
subQuotationList:
["Out somewhere. I didn't let her know I was coming... silly not to, but
you see I got fed up with being alone at Hetton and thought I'd like to
see Brenda, so I came up suddenly on the spur of the moment, just like
that. Damned silly thing to do. Might have known she'd be going out
somewhere... she's very high-principled about chucking... so there it
is. She's going to ring me up here later, if she can get away."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Extraordinary idea of hers, taking up
economics, I never thought it would last, but she seems
really keen on it... I suppose it's a good plan. You know there wasn't
really much for her to do all the time at Hetton. Of course she'd rather
die than admit it, but I believe she got a bit bored there sometimes.
I've been thinking it over and that's the conclusion I came to. Brenda
must have been bored... Daresay she'll get bored with economics some
time... Anyway, she seems cheerful enough now. We've had parties every
week-end lately... I wish you'd come down sometimes, Jock. I don't seem
to get on with Brenda's new friends.
subQuotationList:
['Extraordinary idea of hers, taking up
economics,', "I never thought it would last, but she seems
really keen on it... I suppose it's a good plan. You know there wasn't
really much for her to do all the time at Hetton. Of course she'd rather
die than admit it, but I believe she got a bit bored there sometimes.
I've been thinking it over and that's the conclusion I came to. Brenda
must have been bored... Daresay she'll get bored with economics some
time... Anyway, she seems cheerful enough now. We've had parties every
week-end lately... I wish you'd come down sometimes, Jock. I don't seem
to get on with Brenda's new friends."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: People from the school of economics?
subQuotationList: ['People from the school of economics?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
No, but ones I don't know. I believe I bore them. Thinking it over,
that's the conclusion I've come to. I bore them. They talk about me as
subQuotationList: ["No, but ones I don't know. I believe I bore them. Thinking it over,\nthat's the conclusion I've come to. I bore them. They talk about me as"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: John heard them.
subQuotationList: ['John heard them.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, that's friendly enough.
subQuotationList: ["Well, that's friendly enough."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Yes, that's friendly.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's friendly."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I
say, come next week-end, will you?
subQuotationList: ['I\nsay, come next week-end, will you?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I think I'd love to.
subQuotationList: ["I think I'd love to."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Wish you would. I don't see many old friends... Sure to be lots of
people in the house, but you won't mind that, will you?... sociable
chap, Jock... doesn't mind people about. _I_ mind it like hell.
subQuotationList: ["Wish you would. I don't see many old friends... Sure to be lots of\npeople in the house, but you won't mind that, will you?... sociable\nchap, Jock... doesn't mind people about. _I_ mind it like hell."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Not enough bathrooms, you know... but
of course you know. You've been there before, often. Not like the new
friends who think me a bore. You don't think I'm a bore, do you?
subQuotationList: ["Not enough bathrooms, you know... but\nof course you know. You've been there before, often. Not like the new\nfriends who think me a bore. You don't think I'm a bore, do you?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, old boy.
subQuotationList: ['No, old boy.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Not even when I'm tight, like this?... There would have been
bathrooms. I had the plans out. Four new ones. A chap down there made
the plans... but then Brenda wanted the flat so I had to postpone them
as an economy... I say, that's funny. We had to economize because of
Brenda's economics.
subQuotationList:
["Not even when I'm tight, like this?... There would have been
bathrooms. I had the plans out. Four new ones. A chap down there made
the plans... but then Brenda wanted the flat so I had to postpone them
as an economy... I say, that's funny. We had to economize because of
Brenda's economics."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, that's funny. Let's have some port.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's funny. Let's have some port."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: You seem pretty low to-night.
subQuotationList: ['You seem pretty low to-night.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I am rather. Worried about the Pig Scheme. Constituents keep writing.
subQuotationList: ['I am rather. Worried about the Pig Scheme. Constituents keep writing.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
_I_ felt low, _bloody_ low, but I'm all right again now. The best thing
is to get tight. That's what I did and I don't feel low any more...
discouraging to come to London and find you're not wanted. Funny thing,
_you_ feel low because your girl's chucked, and _I_ feel low because
mine won't chuck.
subQuotationList:
["_I_ felt low, _bloody_ low, but I'm all right again now. The best thing
is to get tight. That's what I did and I don't feel low any more...
discouraging to come to London and find you're not wanted. Funny thing,
_you_ feel low because your girl's chucked, and _I_ feel low because
mine won't chuck."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, that's funny.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's funny."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
But you know I've felt low for weeks now... bloody low... how about
some brandy?
subQuotationList: ["But you know I've felt low for weeks now... bloody low... how about\nsome brandy?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, why not? After all, there are other things in life besides women
and pigs.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, why not? After all, there are other things in life besides women\nand pigs.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
A message from Lady
Brenda, sir.
subQuotationList: ['A message from Lady\nBrenda, sir.']
speaker: A Page
referringExpression: a page came to their table to say

quoteText: Good, I'll go and speak to her.
subQuotationList: ["Good, I'll go and speak to her."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's not her ladyship speaking. Someone was sending a message.
subQuotationList: ["It's not her ladyship speaking. Someone was sending a message."]
speaker: A Page

quoteText: I'll come and speak to her.
subQuotationList: ["I'll come and speak to her."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Darling,
subQuotationList: ['Darling,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Is that Mr Last? I've got a message here, from Lady Brenda.
subQuotationList: ["Is that Mr Last? I've got a message here, from Lady Brenda."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Right, put me through to her.
subQuotationList: ['Right, put me through to her.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
She can't speak herself, but she asked me to give you this message,
that she's very sorry but she cannot join you to-night. She's very tired
and has gone home to bed.
subQuotationList: ["She can't speak herself, but she asked me to give you this message,\nthat she's very sorry but she cannot join you to-night. She's very tired\nand has gone home to bed."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Tell her I want to speak to her.
subQuotationList: ['Tell her I want to speak to her.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I can't, I'm afraid, she's gone to bed. She's very tired.
subQuotationList: ["I can't, I'm afraid, she's gone to bed. She's very tired."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: She's very tired and she's gone to bed?
subQuotationList: ["She's very tired and she's gone to bed?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's right.
subQuotationList: ["That's right."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Well, I want to speak to her.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I want to speak to her.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Good night,
subQuotationList: ['Good night,']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: The old boy's plastered,
subQuotationList: ["The old boy's plastered,"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Oh dear. I feel rather awful about him. But what _can_ he expect,
coming up suddenly like this? He's got to be taught not to make surprise
visits.
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear. I feel rather awful about him. But what _can_ he expect,\ncoming up suddenly like this? He's got to be taught not to make surprise\nvisits."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Is he often like that?
subQuotationList: ['Is he often like that?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: No, it's quite new.
subQuotationList: ["No, it's quite new."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
D'you suppose that's him again? I'd better
answer it.
subQuotationList: ["D'you suppose that's him again? I'd better\nanswer it."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I want to speak to Lady Brenda Last.
subQuotationList: ['I want to speak to Lady Brenda Last.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Tony, darling, this _is_ me, Brenda.
subQuotationList: ['Tony, darling, this _is_ me, Brenda.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Some damn fool said I couldn't speak to you.
subQuotationList: ["Some damn fool said I couldn't speak to you."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I left a message from where I was dining. Are you having a lovely
evening?
subQuotationList: ['I left a message from where I was dining. Are you having a lovely\nevening?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Hellish. I'm with Jock. He's worried about the Pig Scheme. Shall we
come round and see you?
subQuotationList: ["Hellish. I'm with Jock. He's worried about the Pig Scheme. Shall we\ncome round and see you?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, not now, darling, I'm terribly tired and just going to bed.
subQuotationList: ["No, not now, darling, I'm terribly tired and just going to bed."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: We'll come and see you.
subQuotationList: ["We'll come and see you."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Tony, are you a tiny bit tight?
subQuotationList: ['Tony, are you a tiny bit tight?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Stinking. Jock and I'll come and see you.
subQuotationList: ["Stinking. Jock and I'll come and see you."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
_Tony_, you're _not_ to. D'you hear? I can't have you making a brawl.
The flats are getting a bad name anyhow.
subQuotationList: ["_Tony_, you're _not_ to. D'you hear? I can't have you making a brawl.\nThe flats are getting a bad name anyhow."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Their name'll be mud when Jock and I come.
subQuotationList: ["Their name'll be mud when Jock and I come."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Tony, listen, will you please not come, not to-night. Be a good boy and
stay at the club. Will you _please_ not?
subQuotationList: ['Tony, listen, will you please not come, not to-night. Be a good boy and\nstay at the club. Will you _please_ not?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Shan't be long.
subQuotationList: ["Shan't be long."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Oh God, This isn't the least like Tony. Ring up Bratt's
and get on to Jock. He'll have more sense.
subQuotationList: ['Oh God,', "This isn't the least like Tony. Ring up Bratt's\nand get on to Jock. He'll have more sense."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: That was Brenda.
subQuotationList: ['That was Brenda.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: So I gathered.
subQuotationList: ['So I gathered.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: She's at the flat. I said that we'd go round.
subQuotationList: ["She's at the flat. I said that we'd go round."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Splendid. Haven't seen her for weeks. Very fond of Brenda.
subQuotationList: ["Splendid. Haven't seen her for weeks. Very fond of Brenda."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: So am I. Grand girl.
subQuotationList: ['So am I. Grand girl.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Grand girl.
subQuotationList: ['Grand girl.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: A lady on the telephone for you, Mr Grant-Menzies.
subQuotationList: ['A lady on the telephone for you, Mr Grant-Menzies.']
speaker: A Page

quoteText: Who?
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: She didn't give a name.
subQuotationList: ["She didn't give a name."]
speaker: A Page

quoteText: All right. I'll come.
subQuotationList: ["All right. I'll come."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Jock, what _have_ you been doing to my husband?
subQuotationList: ['Jock, what _have_ you been doing to my husband?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: He's a bit tight, that's all.
subQuotationList: ["He's a bit tight, that's all."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
He's roaring. Look here, he threatens to come round. I simply can't
face him to-night in that mood, I'm tired out. You understand, don't
you?
subQuotationList: ["He's roaring. Look here, he threatens to come round. I simply can't\nface him to-night in that mood, I'm tired out. You understand, don't\nyou?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Yes, I understand.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I understand.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: So will you, _please_, keep him away? Are you tight too?
subQuotationList: ['So will you, _please_, keep him away? Are you tight too?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: A little bit.
subQuotationList: ['A little bit.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Oh dear, can I trust you?
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear, can I trust you?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'll try.
subQuotationList: ["I'll try."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Well, it doesn't sound too good. Good-bye
subQuotationList: ["Well, it doesn't sound too good. Good-bye"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
John, you've got to go.
Those hooligans may turn up at any moment. Have you got your taxi fare?
You'll find some change in my bag.
subQuotationList: ["John, you've got to go.\nThose hooligans may turn up at any moment. Have you got your taxi fare?\nYou'll find some change in my bag."]
speaker: Brenda
mentionEntitiesList: [[['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Tony Last', 'Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

quoteText: Was that your girl?
subQuotationList: ['Was that your girl?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Made it up?
subQuotationList: ['Made it up?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Not exactly.
subQuotationList: ['Not exactly.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Far better to make it up. Shall we have some more brandy or go round to
Brenda straight away?
subQuotationList: ['Far better to make it up. Shall we have some more brandy or go round to\nBrenda straight away?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Let's have some more brandy.
subQuotationList: ["Let's have some more brandy."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Jock, you aren't still feeling low, are you? Doesn't do to feel low.
_I'm_ not feeling low. I _was_, but I'm not any more.
subQuotationList: ["Jock, you aren't still feeling low, are you? Doesn't do to feel low.\n_I'm_ not feeling low. I _was_, but I'm not any more."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, I'm not feeling low.
subQuotationList: ["No, I'm not feeling low."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Then we'll have some brandy and then go to Brenda's.
subQuotationList: ["Then we'll have some brandy and then go to Brenda's."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: All right.
subQuotationList: ['All right.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Tell you what, I shouldn't
drive if I were you.
subQuotationList: ["Tell you what, I shouldn't\ndrive if I were you."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Not drive?
subQuotationList: ['Not drive?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: No, I shouldn't drive. They'd say you were drunk.
subQuotationList: ["No, I shouldn't drive. They'd say you were drunk."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Who would?
subQuotationList: ['Who would?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Anyone you ran over. They'd say you were drunk.
subQuotationList: ["Anyone you ran over. They'd say you were drunk."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, so I am.
subQuotationList: ['Well, so I am.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Then I shouldn't drive.
subQuotationList: ["Then I shouldn't drive."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Too far to walk.
subQuotationList: ['Too far to walk.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: We'll take a taxi.
subQuotationList: ["We'll take a taxi."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, hell, I can drive.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, hell, I can drive.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Or let's not go to Brenda's at all.
subQuotationList: ["Or let's not go to Brenda's at all."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: We'd better go to Brenda's, She's expecting us.
subQuotationList: ["We'd better go to Brenda's,", "She's expecting us."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Well, I can't walk all that way. Besides, I don't think she really
wanted us to come.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I can't walk all that way. Besides, I don't think she really\nwanted us to come."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: She'll be pleased when she sees us.
subQuotationList: ["She'll be pleased when she sees us."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Yes, but it's a long way. Let's go some other place.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, but it's a long way. Let's go some other place."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'd like to see Brenda, I'm very fond of Brenda.
subQuotationList: ["I'd like to see Brenda,", "I'm very fond of Brenda."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: She's a grand girl.
subQuotationList: ["She's a grand girl."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: She's a grand girl.
subQuotationList: ["She's a grand girl."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Well, let's take a taxi to Brenda's.
subQuotationList: ["Well, let's take a taxi to Brenda's."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Don't let's go there. Let's go some other
place. Let's go to some low joint.
subQuotationList: ["Don't let's go there. Let's go some other\nplace. Let's go to some low joint."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last', 'Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['Tony Last', 'Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['Tony Last', 'Jock Grant-Menzies']]]

quoteText: All the same to me. Tell him to go to some lousy joint.
subQuotationList: ['All the same to me. Tell him to go to some lousy joint.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Go to some lousy joint,
subQuotationList: ['Go to some lousy joint,']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: We can always ring Brenda from the lousy joint.
subQuotationList: ['We can always ring Brenda from the lousy joint.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Yes, I think we ought to do that. She's a grand girl.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I think we ought to do that. She's a grand girl."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Grand girl.
subQuotationList: ['Grand girl.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: D'you know, I believe he's taking us to the Old Hundredth.
subQuotationList: ["D'you know, I believe he's taking us to the Old Hundredth."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Can't still be open? Thought they closed it down years ago.
subQuotationList: ["Can't still be open? Thought they closed it down years ago."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: D'you mind signing on?
subQuotationList: ["D'you mind signing on?"]
speaker: A Kindly Young Lady

quoteText:
That's five bob each,
please.
subQuotationList: ["That's five bob each,\nplease."]
speaker: A Kindly Young Lady

quoteText:
Last time I was here, Tony, was the bachelor party before your
wedding.
subQuotationList: ['Last time I was here, Tony, was the bachelor party before your\nwedding.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Tight that night.
subQuotationList: ['Tight that night.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Stinking.
subQuotationList: ['Stinking.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
I'll tell you who else was tight that night--Reggie. Broke a fruit gum
machine.
subQuotationList: ["I'll tell you who else was tight that night--Reggie. Broke a fruit gum\nmachine."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Reggie was stinking.
subQuotationList: ['Reggie was stinking.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: I say, you don't still feel low about that girl?
subQuotationList: ["I say, you don't still feel low about that girl?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I don't feel low.
subQuotationList: ["I don't feel low."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Come on, we'll go downstairs.
subQuotationList: ["Come on, we'll go downstairs."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I like this joint, What'll we
drink?
subQuotationList: ['I like this joint,', "What'll we\ndrink?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Brandy.
subQuotationList: ['Brandy.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Are you in town for long?
subQuotationList: ['Are you in town for long?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
Have you got
such a thing as a cigarette?
subQuotationList: ['Have you got\nsuch a thing as a cigarette?']
speaker: Babs

quoteText: Are you fond of dancing?
subQuotationList: ['Are you fond of dancing?']
speaker: Babs

quoteText: No, are you?
subQuotationList: ['No, are you?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: So-so.
subQuotationList: ['So-so.']
speaker: Babs

quoteText: Well, let's sit down.
subQuotationList: ["Well, let's sit down."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Will you buy a ticket in a raffle for a box of
chocolates?
subQuotationList: ['Will you buy a ticket in a raffle for a box of\nchocolates?']
speaker: The Waiter

quoteText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Buy one for me,
subQuotationList: ['Buy one for me,']
speaker: Babs

quoteText: You're married, aren't you?
subQuotationList: ["You're married, aren't you?"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: No,
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Oh, I can always tell, Your friend is too.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I can always tell,', 'Your friend is too.']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Yes, _he_ is.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, _he_ is.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
You'd be surprised how many gentlemen come here just to talk about
their wives.
subQuotationList: ["You'd be surprised how many gentlemen come here just to talk about\ntheir wives."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: He hasn't.
subQuotationList: ["He hasn't."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
You see, the
trouble is my wife is studious. She's taking a course in economics.
subQuotationList: ["You see, the\ntrouble is my wife is studious. She's taking a course in economics."]
speaker: Tony Last
referringExpression: Tony was leaning across the table and saying to Babs

quoteText: I think it's nice for a girl to be interested in things.
subQuotationList: ["I think it's nice for a girl to be interested in things."]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: What will you be taking for supper?
subQuotationList: ['What will you be taking for supper?']
speaker: The Waiter

quoteText: Why, we've only just had dinner.
subQuotationList: ["Why, we've only just had dinner."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: How about a nice haddock?
subQuotationList: ['How about a nice haddock?']
speaker: The Waiter

quoteText: I tell you what I must do is to telephone. Where is it?
subQuotationList: ['I tell you what I must do is to telephone. Where is it?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: D'you mean really the telephone or the gentlemen's?
subQuotationList: ["D'you mean really the telephone or the gentlemen's?"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: No, the telephone.
subQuotationList: ['No, the telephone.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Upstairs in the office.
subQuotationList: ['Upstairs in the office.']
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
Yes,
who is it?
subQuotationList: ['Yes,\nwho is it?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I have a message here from Mr Anthony Last and Mr Jocelyn
Grant-Menzies.
subQuotationList: ['I have a message here from Mr Anthony Last and Mr Jocelyn\nGrant-Menzies.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, it's you, Tony. Well, what do you want?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, it's you, Tony. Well, what do you want?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You recognized my voice?
subQuotationList: ['You recognized my voice?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I did.
subQuotationList: ['I did.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Well, I only wanted to give a message but as I am speaking to you I can
give it myself, can't I?
subQuotationList: ["Well, I only wanted to give a message but as I am speaking to you I can\ngive it myself, can't I?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Well, Jock and I are terribly sorry but we can't come round this
evening after all.
subQuotationList: ["Well, Jock and I are terribly sorry but we can't come round this\nevening after all."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You don't think it very rude, I hope, but we have a lot to attend to.
subQuotationList: ["You don't think it very rude, I hope, but we have a lot to attend to."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's all right, Tony.
subQuotationList: ["That's all right, Tony."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Did I wake you up by any chance?
subQuotationList: ['Did I wake you up by any chance?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's all right, Tony.
subQuotationList: ["That's all right, Tony."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, good night.
subQuotationList: ['Well, good night.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I've been talking to Brenda. She sounded
rather annoyed. D'you think we _ought_ to go round there?
subQuotationList: ["I've been talking to Brenda. She sounded\nrather annoyed. D'you think we _ought_ to go round there?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: We promised we would,
subQuotationList: ['We promised we would,']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: You should never disappoint a lady,
subQuotationList: ['You should never disappoint a lady,']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Oh, it's too late now.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, it's too late now."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You two are officers, aren't you?
subQuotationList: ["You two are officers, aren't you?"]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: No, why?
subQuotationList: ['No, why?']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: I thought you were.
subQuotationList: ['I thought you were.']
speaker: Babs

quoteText:
I like business gentlemen best, myself. They've more to
say.
subQuotationList: ["I like business gentlemen best, myself. They've more to\nsay."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: What d'you do?
subQuotationList: ["What d'you do?"]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: I design postmen's hats,
subQuotationList: ["I design postmen's hats,"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Oh, go on.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, go on.']
speaker: Babs

quoteText: And my friend here trains sea-lions.
subQuotationList: ['And my friend here trains sea-lions.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Tell us another.
subQuotationList: ['Tell us another.']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: I've got a gentleman friend who works on a newspaper.
subQuotationList: ["I've got a gentleman friend who works on a newspaper."]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: I say, ought we to do something about Brenda?
subQuotationList: ['I say, ought we to do something about Brenda?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: I told her we weren't coming, didn't I?
subQuotationList: ["I told her we weren't coming, didn't I?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes... but she might still be _hoping_.
subQuotationList: ['Yes... but she might still be _hoping_.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
I tell you what, you go and ring her up and find out if she really
wants us.
subQuotationList: ['I tell you what, you go and ring her up and find out if she really\nwants us.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: All right.
subQuotationList: ['All right.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
_I_ thought she sounded
rather annoyed, But I said in the end we wouldn't come.
subQuotationList: ['_I_ thought she sounded\nrather annoyed,', "But I said in the end we wouldn't come."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
She may be tired, Has to get up early to do economics. Now
I come to think of it someone _did_ say she was tired, earlier on in the
evening.
subQuotationList: ['She may be tired,', 'Has to get up early to do economics. Now\nI come to think of it someone _did_ say she was tired, earlier on in the\nevening.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I say, what's this frightful piece of fish?
subQuotationList: ["I say, what's this frightful piece of fish?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: The waiter said you ordered it.
subQuotationList: ['The waiter said you ordered it.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Perhaps I did.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps I did.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
I'll give it to the club cat, She's a dear called
Blackberry.
subQuotationList: ["I'll give it to the club cat,", "She's a dear called\nBlackberry."]
speaker: Babs

quoteText:
D'you think we ought to ring
up Brenda again?
subQuotationList: ["D'you think we ought to ring\nup Brenda again?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Perhaps we ought. She sounded annoyed with us.
subQuotationList: ['Perhaps we ought. She sounded annoyed with us.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Let's go now and ring her up on the way out.
subQuotationList: ["Let's go now and ring her up on the way out."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Aren't you coming home with us?
subQuotationList: ["Aren't you coming home with us?"]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: Not to-night, I'm afraid.
subQuotationList: ["Not to-night, I'm afraid."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Be a sport,
subQuotationList: ['Be a sport,']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: No, we can't really.
subQuotationList: ["No, we can't really."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
All right. Well, how about a little present? We're professional dancing
partners, you know,
subQuotationList: ["All right. Well, how about a little present? We're professional dancing\npartners, you know,"]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: Oh yes, sorry, how much?
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, sorry, how much?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, we leave that to the gentlemen.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, we leave that to the gentlemen.']
speaker: Babs

quoteText: You might make it a bit more, We've sat with you two hours.
subQuotationList: ['You might make it a bit more,', "We've sat with you two hours."]
speaker: Babs

quoteText:
Come and see us again one evening when you've
got more time,
subQuotationList: ["Come and see us again one evening when you've\ngot more time,"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
I'm feeling rather ill, Don't think I
shall bother to ring up Brenda.
subQuotationList: ["I'm feeling rather ill,", "Don't think I\nshall bother to ring up Brenda."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Send a message.
subQuotationList: ['Send a message.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
That's a good idea... Look here, Will you ring up this Sloane number and speak to her ladyship and say
Mr Grant-Menzies and Mr Last are very sorry but they cannot call this
evening? Got that?
subQuotationList: ["That's a good idea... Look here,", 'Will you ring up this Sloane number and speak to her ladyship and say\nMr Grant-Menzies and Mr Last are very sorry but they cannot call this\nevening? Got that?']
speaker: Tony Last
referringExpression: he said to the seedy commissionaire
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The Seedy Commissionaire'], ['Brenda'], ['Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last', 'Jock Grant-Menzies']]]

quoteText: Brenda can't expect us to do more than that,
subQuotationList: ["Brenda can't expect us to do more than that,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I tell you what I'll do. I go almost past her door, so I'll ring the
bell a bit just in case she's awake and still waiting up for us.
subQuotationList: ["I tell you what I'll do. I go almost past her door, so I'll ring the\nbell a bit just in case she's awake and still waiting up for us."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Yes, you do that. What a good friend you are, Jock.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, you do that. What a good friend you are, Jock.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, I'm fond of Brenda... a grand girl.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I'm fond of Brenda... a grand girl."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Grand girl... I wish I didn't feel ill.
subQuotationList: ["Grand girl... I wish I didn't feel ill."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, Tony, how do you feel?
subQuotationList: ['Well, Tony, how do you feel?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Awful. I _was_ tight.
subQuotationList: ['Awful. I _was_ tight.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You were.
subQuotationList: ['You were.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm feeling pretty guilty too.
subQuotationList: ["I'm feeling pretty guilty too."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'm not surprised.
subQuotationList: ["I'm not surprised."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I don't remember everything very clearly but I have the impression that
Jock and I were rather bores.
subQuotationList: ["I don't remember everything very clearly but I have the impression that\nJock and I were rather bores."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You were.
subQuotationList: ['You were.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Are you in a rage?
subQuotationList: ['Are you in a rage?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, I was last night. What made you do it, Tony, grown up men like
you two?
subQuotationList: ['Well, I was last night. What made you do it, Tony, grown up men like\nyou two?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: We felt low.
subQuotationList: ['We felt low.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I bet you feel lower this morning... A box of white roses has just
arrived from Jock.
subQuotationList: ['I bet you feel lower this morning... A box of white roses has just\narrived from Jock.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I wish I'd thought of that.
subQuotationList: ["I wish I'd thought of that."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You're such infants, both of you.
subQuotationList: ["You're such infants, both of you."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You aren't really in a rage?
subQuotationList: ["You aren't really in a rage?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Of course I'm not, darling. Now just you go straight back to the
country. You'll feel all right again to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ["Of course I'm not, darling. Now just you go straight back to the\ncountry. You'll feel all right again to-morrow."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Am I not going to see you?
subQuotationList: ['Am I not going to see you?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Not to-day, I'm afraid. I've got lectures all the morning and I'm
lunching out. But I'll be coming down on Friday evening or anyway
Saturday morning.
subQuotationList: ["Not to-day, I'm afraid. I've got lectures all the morning and I'm\nlunching out. But I'll be coming down on Friday evening or anyway\nSaturday morning."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I see. You couldn't possibly chuck lunch or one of the lectures?
subQuotationList: ["I see. You couldn't possibly chuck lunch or one of the lectures?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Not possibly, darling.
subQuotationList: ['Not possibly, darling.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I see. You are an angel to be so sweet about last night.
subQuotationList: ['I see. You are an angel to be so sweet about last night.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Nothing could have been more fortunate, If I know Tony,
he'll be tortured with guilt for weeks to come. It was maddening last
night but it was worth it. He's put himself so much in the wrong now
that he won't dare to _feel_ resentful, let alone say anything, whatever
I do. And he hasn't really enjoyed himself at all, the poor sweet, so
_that's_ a good thing too. He had to learn not to make surprise visits.
subQuotationList:
['Nothing could have been more fortunate,', "If I know Tony,
he'll be tortured with guilt for weeks to come. It was maddening last
night but it was worth it. He's put himself so much in the wrong now
that he won't dare to _feel_ resentful, let alone say anything, whatever
I do. And he hasn't really enjoyed himself at all, the poor sweet, so
_that's_ a good thing too. He had to learn not to make surprise visits."]
speaker: Brenda
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: You are one for making people learn things,
subQuotationList: ['You are one for making people learn things,']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Hullo, daddy, had a good
time in London? You didn't mind me coming to the station, did you? I
_made_ nanny let me.
subQuotationList: ["Hullo, daddy, had a good\ntime in London? You didn't mind me coming to the station, did you? I\n_made_ nanny let me."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Very pleased to see you, John.
subQuotationList: ['Very pleased to see you, John.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: How was mummy?
subQuotationList: ['How was mummy?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: She sounded very well. I didn't see her.
subQuotationList: ["She sounded very well. I didn't see her."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: But you _said_ you were going to see her.
subQuotationList: ['But you _said_ you were going to see her.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Yes, I thought I was, but I turned out to be wrong. I talked to her
several times on the telephone.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I thought I was, but I turned out to be wrong. I talked to her\nseveral times on the telephone.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
But you can telephone her from here, can't you, daddy? Why did you go
all the way to London to telephone her?... _Why_, daddy?
subQuotationList: ["But you can telephone her from here, can't you, daddy? Why did you go\nall the way to London to telephone her?... _Why_, daddy?"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: It would take too long to explain.
subQuotationList: ['It would take too long to explain.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well tell me some of it... _Why_, daddy?
subQuotationList: ['Well tell me some of it... _Why_, daddy?']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Look here, I'm tired. If you don't stop asking questions I shan't let
you ever come and meet the train again.
subQuotationList: ["Look here, I'm tired. If you don't stop asking questions I shan't let\nyou ever come and meet the train again."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I thought you'd _like_ me to come
and meet you.
subQuotationList: ["I thought you'd _like_ me to come\nand meet you."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
If you cry I shall put you in front with Dawson. It's absurd to cry at
your age.
subQuotationList: ["If you cry I shall put you in front with Dawson. It's absurd to cry at\nyour age."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'd _sooner_ go in front with Dawson,
subQuotationList: ["I'd _sooner_ go in front with Dawson,"]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Nanny, I don't
want John to come to the station in future unless her ladyship or I
specially say he can.
subQuotationList: ["Nanny, I don't\nwant John to come to the station in future unless her ladyship or I\nspecially say he can."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
No, sir, I wouldn't have let him go to-day, only he went on so. Come
along now, John, and take off your coat. Goodness, child, where's your
handkerchief?
subQuotationList: ["No, sir, I wouldn't have let him go to-day, only he went on so. Come\nalong now, John, and take off your coat. Goodness, child, where's your\nhandkerchief?"]
speaker: Nanny
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Andrew'], ['John Last'], ['John Andrew']]]

quoteText:
Two men of
thirty, behaving as if they were up for the night
from Sandhurst--getting drunk and ringing people up and dancing with
tarts at the Old Hundredth... And it makes it all the worse that Brenda
was so nice about it.
subQuotationList:
['Two men of
thirty,', 'behaving as if they were up for the night
from Sandhurst--getting drunk and ringing people up and dancing with
tarts at the Old Hundredth... And it makes it all the worse that Brenda
was so nice about it.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Ambrose, when I'm alone I think in future I'll have
dinner in the library.
subQuotationList: ["Ambrose, when I'm alone I think in future I'll have\ndinner in the library."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Ambrose, when I'm alone I don't
really need a long dinner. In future I'll just have two courses.
subQuotationList: ["Ambrose, when I'm alone I don't\nreally need a long dinner. In future I'll just have two courses."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: When I wake up it will be the week-end.
subQuotationList: ['When I wake up it will be the week-end.']
speaker: Tony Last
referringExpression: He looked over some accounts his agent had left for him and then went to bed saying to himself

quoteText:
She usually
does better than this.
subQuotationList: ['She usually\ndoes better than this.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: Not till to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ['Not till to-morrow.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh.
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
I've got to go over to Little Bayton this afternoon. Would you like to
come too and perhaps we could see the kennels?
subQuotationList: ["I've got to go over to Little Bayton this afternoon. Would you like to\ncome too and perhaps we could see the kennels?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
No, thank
you, I want to finish a picture I'm painting.
subQuotationList: ['No, thank\nyou,', "I want to finish a picture I'm painting."]
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: You can do that any time.
subQuotationList: ['You can do that any time.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I want to do it this afternoon.
subQuotationList: ['I want to do it this afternoon.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
Whatever made you speak to your dad
like that for? You've been going on about seeing the kennels since
Christmas.
subQuotationList: ["Whatever made you speak to your dad\nlike that for? You've been going on about seeing the kennels since\nChristmas."]
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Not with _him_,
subQuotationList: ['Not with _him_,']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText:
You ungrateful little bastard, that's a lousy way to speak of your
dad.
subQuotationList: ["You ungrateful little bastard, that's a lousy way to speak of your\ndad."]
speaker: Ben

quoteText:
And you ought not to say bastard or lousy in front of me, nanny says
not.
subQuotationList: ['And you ought not to say bastard or lousy in front of me, nanny says\nnot.']
speaker: John Andrew

quoteText: My poor Brenda, it's an appalling room,
subQuotationList: ["My poor Brenda, it's an appalling room,"]
speaker: Mrs. Beaver

quoteText: It's not one we use a great deal,
subQuotationList: ["It's not one we use a great deal,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I should think not,
subQuotationList: ['I should think not,']
speaker: Veronica
referringExpression: said the one they called Veronica

quoteText:
I can't see much wrong with it, except it's a bit
mouldy.
subQuotationList: ["I can't see much wrong with it,", "except it's a bit\nmouldy."]
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText:
You see, What I thought was
that I must have _one_ habitable room downstairs. At present there's
only the smoking-room and the library. The drawing-room is vast and
quite out of the question. I thought what I needed was a small
sitting-room more or less to myself. Don't you think it has
possibilities?
subQuotationList:
['You see,', "What I thought was
that I must have _one_ habitable room downstairs. At present there's
only the smoking-room and the library. The drawing-room is vast and
quite out of the question. I thought what I needed was a small
sitting-room more or less to myself. Don't you think it has
possibilities?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
But, my angel, the _shape's_ all wrong, and that
chimney-piece--what is it made of, pink granite, and all the plaster
work and the dado. _Everything's_ horrible. It's so _dark_.
subQuotationList: ["But, my angel, the _shape's_ all wrong,", "and that\nchimney-piece--what is it made of, pink granite, and all the plaster\nwork and the dado. _Everything's_ horrible. It's so _dark_."]
speaker: Daisy

quoteText:
I know exactly what Brenda wants, I
don't think it will be impossible. I must think about it. As Veronica
says, the structure does rather limit one... you know, I think the only
thing to do would be to disregard it altogether and find some treatment
