quoteText: They don't like him much as Master.
subQuotationList: ["They don't like him much as Master."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I'm afraid this is a very difficult situation, After all
we scarcely know each other.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid this is a very difficult situation,", 'After all\nwe scarcely know each other.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You don't have to think about me.
subQuotationList: ["You don't have to think about me."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: But it must be awful for you.
subQuotationList: ['But it must be awful for you.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: And you must stop thinking that.
subQuotationList: ['And you must stop thinking that.']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
I'll try... the absurd thing is that I'm not thinking it, just saying
it... I keep thinking of other things all the time.
subQuotationList: ["I'll try... the absurd thing is that I'm not thinking it, just saying\nit... I keep thinking of other things all the time."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I know. You don't have to say anything.
subQuotationList: ["I know. You don't have to say anything."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
It's going to be so much worse for Brenda. You see
she'd got nothing else, much, except John. I've got her, and I love the
house... but with Brenda John always came first... naturally... And
then you know she's seen so little of John lately. She's been in London
such a lot. I'm afraid that's going to hurt her.
subQuotationList:
["It's going to be so much worse for Brenda. You see
she'd got nothing else, much, except John. I've got her, and I love the
house... but with Brenda John always came first... naturally... And
then you know she's seen so little of John lately. She's been in London
such a lot. I'm afraid that's going to hurt her."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You can't ever tell what's going to hurt people.
subQuotationList: ["You can't ever tell what's going to hurt people."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: But, you see, I know Brenda so well.
subQuotationList: ['But, you see, I know Brenda so well.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Only four o'clock?
subQuotationList: ["Only four o'clock?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I thought you were asleep.
subQuotationList: ['I thought you were asleep.']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
No, just thinking... Jock will be more than half-way there by now,
about Aylesbury or Tring.
subQuotationList: ['No, just thinking... Jock will be more than half-way there by now,\nabout Aylesbury or Tring.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's a slow way to travel.
subQuotationList: ["It's a slow way to travel."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
It's less than four hours ago that it happened... it's odd to think
that this is the same day; that it's only five hours ago they were all
here at the meet having drinks.
subQuotationList: ["It's less than four hours ago that it happened... it's odd to think\nthat this is the same day; that it's only five hours ago they were all\nhere at the meet having drinks."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It was twenty-eight
minutes past twelve when I heard. I looked at my watch... It was ten to
one when they brought John in... just over three hours ago... It's
almost incredible, isn't it, everything becoming absolutely different,
suddenly like that?
subQuotationList:
["It was twenty-eight
minutes past twelve when I heard. I looked at my watch... It was ten to
one when they brought John in... just over three hours ago... It's
almost incredible, isn't it, everything becoming absolutely different,
suddenly like that?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's always that way,
subQuotationList: ["It's always that way,"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
Brenda will hear in an hour now... if Jock finds her in. Of course she
may very likely be out. He won't know where to find her, because there's
no one else in the flat. She leaves it locked up, empty, when she goes
out... and she's out half the day. I know because I sometimes ring up
and can't get an answer. He may not find her for hours... It may be as
long again as the time since it happened. That would only make it eight
o'clock. It's quite likely she won't come in until eight... Think of
it, all the time between now and when it happened, before Brenda hears.
It's scarcely credible, is it? And then she's got to get down here.
There's a train that leaves at nine something. She might get that. I
wonder if I ought to have gone up too... I didn't like to leave John.
subQuotationList:
["Brenda will hear in an hour now... if Jock finds her in. Of course she
may very likely be out. He won't know where to find her, because there's
no one else in the flat. She leaves it locked up, empty, when she goes
out... and she's out half the day. I know because I sometimes ring up
and can't get an answer. He may not find her for hours... It may be as
long again as the time since it happened. That would only make it eight
o'clock. It's quite likely she won't come in until eight... Think of
it, all the time between now and when it happened, before Brenda hears.
It's scarcely credible, is it? And then she's got to get down here.
There's a train that leaves at nine something. She might get that. I
wonder if I ought to have gone up too... I didn't like to leave John."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
...Of course she may be at home when he arrives. In that case she can
get the evening train she used always to come by, when she went to
London for the day, before she got the flat... I'm trying to see it
all, as it's going to happen, Jock coming and her surprise at seeing
him, and then his telling her... It's awful for Jock... She may know
at half-past five or a bit earlier.
subQuotationList:
["...Of course she may be at home when he arrives. In that case she can
get the evening train she used always to come by, when she went to
London for the day, before she got the flat... I'm trying to see it
all, as it's going to happen, Jock coming and her surprise at seeing
him, and then his telling her... It's awful for Jock... She may know
at half-past five or a bit earlier."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's a pity you don't play patience,
subQuotationList: ["It's a pity you don't play patience,"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
In a way I shall feel happier when she knows... it feels all wrong as
it is at present, having it as a secret that Brenda doesn't know... I'm
not sure how she fits in her day. I suppose her last lecture is over at
about five... I wonder if she goes home first to change if she's going
out to tea or cocktails. She can't sit about much in the flat, it's so
small.
subQuotationList:
["In a way I shall feel happier when she knows... it feels all wrong as
it is at present, having it as a secret that Brenda doesn't know... I'm
not sure how she fits in her day. I suppose her last lecture is over at
about five... I wonder if she goes home first to change if she's going
out to tea or cocktails. She can't sit about much in the flat, it's so
small."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's a heart-breaking game,
subQuotationList: ["It's a heart-breaking game,"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
Is that only a quarter-past?... You know, I think I should have gone
off my head if I were alone. It's nice of you to stay with me.
subQuotationList: ["Is that only a quarter-past?... You know, I think I should have gone\noff my head if I were alone. It's nice of you to stay with me."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Do you play bezique?
subQuotationList: ['Do you play bezique?']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: I'm afraid not.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid not."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Or piquet?
subQuotationList: ['Or piquet?']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: No. I've never been able to learn any card game except animal snap.
subQuotationList: ["No. I've never been able to learn any card game except animal snap."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Pity.
subQuotationList: ['Pity.']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
There's Marjorie and several people I ought to wire to, but I'd better
wait until I know that Jock has seen Brenda. Suppose she was with
Marjorie when the telegram arrived.
subQuotationList: ["There's Marjorie and several people I ought to wire to, but I'd better\nwait until I know that Jock has seen Brenda. Suppose she was with\nMarjorie when the telegram arrived."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You've got to try and stop thinking about things. Can you throw craps?
subQuotationList: ["You've got to try and stop thinking about things. Can you throw craps?"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
That's easy; I'll show you. There'll be some dice in the backgammon
board.
subQuotationList: ["That's easy; I'll show you. There'll be some dice in the backgammon\nboard."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: I'm all right, really. I'd sooner not play.
subQuotationList: ["I'm all right, really. I'd sooner not play."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You get the dice and sit up here at the table. We've got six hours to
get through.
subQuotationList: ["You get the dice and sit up here at the table. We've got six hours to\nget through."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
I've seen it on the
cinema--pullman porters and taxi men.
subQuotationList: ["I've seen it on the\ncinema--pullman porters and taxi men."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Of course you have, it's easy... there you see you've won, you take
all.
subQuotationList: ["Of course you have, it's easy... there you see you've won, you take\nall."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: I've just thought of something.
subQuotationList: ["I've just thought of something."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Don't you ever take a rest from thinking?
subQuotationList: ["Don't you ever take a rest from thinking?"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
Suppose the evening papers have got hold of it already. Brenda may
see it on a placard, or just pick up a paper casually and there it
will be... perhaps with a photograph.
subQuotationList: ['Suppose the evening papers have got hold of it already. Brenda may\nsee it on a placard, or just pick up a paper casually and there it\nwill be... perhaps with a photograph.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, I thought of that just now, when you were talking about
telegraphing.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I thought of that just now, when you were talking about\ntelegraphing.']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
But it's quite likely, isn't it? They get hold of everything so
quickly. What can we do about it?
subQuotationList: ["But it's quite likely, isn't it? They get hold of everything so\nquickly. What can we do about it?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
There isn't anything we can do. We've just got to wait... Come on,
boy, throw up.
subQuotationList: ["There isn't anything we can do. We've just got to wait... Come on,\nboy, throw up."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: I don't want to play any more. I'm worried.
subQuotationList: ["I don't want to play any more. I'm worried."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I know you're worried. You don't have to tell me... you aren't going
to give up playing just when the luck's running your way?
subQuotationList: ["I know you're worried. You don't have to tell me... you aren't going\nto give up playing just when the luck's running your way?"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: I'm sorry... it isn't any good.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry... it isn't any good."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
At least we can find out whether the evening
papers have got it in. We can ring up and ask the hall porter at my
club.
subQuotationList: ['At least we can find out whether the evening\npapers have got it in. We can ring up and ask the hall porter at my\nclub.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
That's not going to prevent your wife reading it. We've just got to
wait. What was the game you said you knew? Animal something?
subQuotationList: ["That's not going to prevent your wife reading it. We've just got to\nwait. What was the game you said you knew? Animal something?"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: Snap.
subQuotationList: ['Snap.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'll buy it.
subQuotationList: ["I'll buy it."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: It's just a child's game. It would be ridiculous with two.
subQuotationList: ["It's just a child's game. It would be ridiculous with two."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Show me.
subQuotationList: ['Show me.']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: Well each of us chooses an animal.
subQuotationList: ['Well each of us chooses an animal.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: All right, I'm a dog and you're a hen. Now what?
subQuotationList: ["All right, I'm a dog and you're a hen. Now what?"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
I'd say it was one of those games that you have to feel pretty good
first, before you can enjoy them, But I'll try
anything. Bow-wow, Bow-wow, You know you aren't putting
your heart into this.
subQuotationList:
["I'd say it was one of those games that you have to feel pretty good
first, before you can enjoy them,", "But I'll try
anything.", 'Bow-wow,', 'Bow-wow,', "You know you aren't putting
your heart into this."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: Oh, Coop-coop-coop.
subQuotationList: ['Oh,', 'Coop-coop-coop.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Coop-coop-coop.
subQuotationList: ['Coop-coop-coop.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Don't be dumb, that isn't a pair...
subQuotationList: ["Don't be dumb,", "that isn't a pair..."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: What must that man have thought?
subQuotationList: ['What must that man have thought?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Sitting there clucking like a 'en, and the little
fellow lying dead upstairs.
subQuotationList: ["Sitting there clucking like a 'en,", 'and the little\nfellow lying dead upstairs.']
speaker: Albert

quoteText: We'd better stop.
subQuotationList: ["We'd better stop."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It wasn't a very good game. And to think it's the only one you know.
subQuotationList: ["It wasn't a very good game. And to think it's the only one you know."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
Five
o'clock. Now that the shutters are up we shan't hear the chimes. Jock
must be in London by now.
subQuotationList: ["Five\no'clock. Now that the shutters are up we shan't hear the chimes. Jock\nmust be in London by now."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'd rather like some whisky.
subQuotationList: ["I'd rather like some whisky."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: Are you looking for Lady Brenda Last?
subQuotationList: ['Are you looking for Lady Brenda Last?']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: I am. Is she a friend of yours?
subQuotationList: ['I am. Is she a friend of yours?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Oh, _such_ a friend,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, _such_ a friend,']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: Then perhaps you can tell me where I can find her?
subQuotationList: ['Then perhaps you can tell me where I can find her?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
I think she's bound to be at Lady Cockpurse's. I'm just going there
myself. Can I give her any message?
subQuotationList: ["I think she's bound to be at Lady Cockpurse's. I'm just going there\nmyself. Can I give her any message?"]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: I had better come and see her.
subQuotationList: ['I had better come and see her.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Well, wait five minutes and you can go with me. Come inside.
subQuotationList: ['Well, wait five minutes and you can go with me. Come inside.']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: What's your name?
subQuotationList: ["What's your name?"]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
Oh yes,
I've heard them mention you. I was at Hetton the week-end before last...
such a quaint old place.
subQuotationList: ["Oh yes,\nI've heard them mention you. I was at Hetton the week-end before last...\nsuch a quaint old place."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
I'd better tell you. There's been a frightful accident there this
morning.
subQuotationList: ["I'd better tell you. There's been a frightful accident there this\nmorning."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Quick, _tell me_. I can't bear it. Is it _death_?
subQuotationList: ['Quick,', "_tell me_. I can't bear it. Is it _death_?"]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: Their little boy... kicked by a horse.
subQuotationList: ['Their little boy... kicked by a horse.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: _Little Jimmy._
subQuotationList: ['_Little Jimmy._']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: John.
subQuotationList: ['John.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: John... _dead_. It's _too_ horrible.
subQuotationList: ["John... _dead_. It's _too_ horrible."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: It wasn't anybody's fault.
subQuotationList: ["It wasn't anybody's fault."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Oh yes, It was. It was _my_ fault. I ought never to have
gone there... a terrible curse hangs over me. Wherever I go I bring
nothing but sorrow... if only it was _I_ that was dead... I shall
never be able to face them again. I feel like a murderess... that brave
little life snuffed out.
subQuotationList:
['Oh yes,', 'It was. It was _my_ fault. I ought never to have
gone there... a terrible curse hangs over me. Wherever I go I bring
nothing but sorrow... if only it was _I_ that was dead... I shall
never be able to face them again. I feel like a murderess... that brave
little life snuffed out.']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: I say, you know, really, I shouldn't take that line about it.
subQuotationList: ["I say, you know, really, I shouldn't take that line about it."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
It isn't the first time it's happened... always, anywhere, I am hunted
down... without remorse. O God, What have I
done to deserve it?
subQuotationList: ["It isn't the first time it's happened... always, anywhere, I am hunted\ndown... without remorse. O God,", 'What have I\ndone to deserve it?']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
Well, I must go along to Polly's
and see Brenda.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I must go along to Polly's\nand see Brenda."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Wait a minute and I'll come too.
subQuotationList: ["Wait a minute and I'll come too."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
Have you got a car here, or shall I ring up a
taxi?
subQuotationList: ['Have you got a car here,', 'or shall I ring up a\ntaxi?']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
Bad
interview?
subQuotationList: ['Bad\ninterview?']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: Awful.
subQuotationList: ['Awful.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Bring me one too, will you?
subQuotationList: ['Bring me one too, will you?']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
I only wanted to see him about arrangements. He tried to be
comforting. It was very painful... after all the last thing one wants
to talk about at a time like this is religion.
subQuotationList: ['I only wanted to see him about arrangements. He tried to be\ncomforting. It was very painful... after all the last thing one wants\nto talk about at a time like this is religion.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Some like it,
subQuotationList: ['Some like it,']
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
Of course, when you haven't got children
yourself--
subQuotationList: ['Of course,', "when you haven't got children\nyourself--"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I've got two sons,
subQuotationList: ["I've got two sons,"]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText:
Have you? I'm so sorry. I didn't realize... we know each other so
little. How very impertinent of me.
subQuotationList: ["Have you? I'm so sorry. I didn't realize... we know each other so\nlittle. How very impertinent of me."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
That's all right. People are always surprised. I don't see them often.
They're at school somewhere. I took them to the cinema last summer.
They're getting quite big. One's going to be good-looking, I think. His
father is.
subQuotationList:
["That's all right. People are always surprised. I don't see them often.
They're at school somewhere. I took them to the cinema last summer.
They're getting quite big. One's going to be good-looking, I think. His
father is."]
speaker: Mrs. Rattery

quoteText: Quarter-past six, He's bound to have told her by now.
subQuotationList: ['Quarter-past six,', "He's bound to have told her by now."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
What a time she is taking
over Daisy.
subQuotationList: ['What a time she is taking\nover Daisy.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: She is very thorough, and it tickles rather.
subQuotationList: ['She is very thorough,', 'and it tickles rather.']
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText: What was she like?
subQuotationList: ['What was she like?']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: I mustn't tell or it spoils it all,
subQuotationList: ["I mustn't tell or it spoils it all,"]
speaker: Daisy

quoteText: Where's Mr Beaver to-day?
subQuotationList: ["Where's Mr Beaver to-day?"]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
He's flown over to France with his mother to see some new wallpapers.
She's been worrying all day thinking he's had an accident.
subQuotationList: ["He's flown over to France with his mother to see some new wallpapers.\nShe's been worrying all day thinking he's had an accident."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
It's all very touching, isn't it? Though I can't see his point
myself...
subQuotationList: ["It's all very touching, isn't it? Though I can't see his point\nmyself..."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: You must never do anything on Thursdays,
subQuotationList: ['You must never do anything on Thursdays,']
speaker: Mrs. Northcote

quoteText: Nothing?
subQuotationList: ['Nothing?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Nothing important. You are intellectual, imaginative, sympathetic,
easily led by others, impulsive, affectionate. You are highly artistic
and are not giving full scope to your capabilities.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing important. You are intellectual, imaginative, sympathetic,\neasily led by others, impulsive, affectionate. You are highly artistic\nand are not giving full scope to your capabilities.']
speaker: Mrs. Northcote

quoteText: Isn't there anything about love?
subQuotationList: ["Isn't there anything about love?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I am coming to love. All these lines from the great toe to the instep
represent lovers.
subQuotationList: ['I am coming to love. All these lines from the great toe to the instep\nrepresent lovers.']
speaker: Mrs. Northcote

quoteText: Yes, go on some more about that...
subQuotationList: ['Yes, go on some more about that...']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Where's Brenda? I
thought she'd be here.
subQuotationList: ["Where's Brenda?", "I\nthought she'd be here."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: Mrs Northcote's doing her now.
subQuotationList: ["Mrs Northcote's doing her now."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Jock Menzies wants to see her. He's downstairs.
subQuotationList: ["Jock Menzies wants to see her. He's downstairs."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: Darling Jock... Why on earth didn't you bring him up?
subQuotationList: ["Darling Jock... Why on earth didn't you bring him up?"]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: No, it's something terribly important. He's got to see Brenda alone.
subQuotationList: ["No, it's something terribly important. He's got to see Brenda alone."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
My dear, how mysterious. Well, she won't be long now. We can't disturb
them. It would upset Mrs Northcote.
subQuotationList: ["My dear, how mysterious. Well, she won't be long now. We can't disturb\nthem. It would upset Mrs Northcote."]
speaker: Unknowable
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Brenda'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar', 'Polly Cockpurse', 'Daisy', 'Veronica', 'Souki De Foucald-Esterhazy'], ['Mrs Northcote', 'Brenda'], ['Mrs. Northcote']]]

quoteText:
Four men dominate your fate, one is loyal and tender but he has not yet disclosed his love,
one is passionate and overpowering, you are a little afraid of him.
subQuotationList: ['Four men dominate your fate,', 'one is loyal and tender but he has not yet disclosed his love,\none is passionate and overpowering, you are a little afraid of him.']
speaker: Mrs. Northcote

quoteText: Dear me, How very exciting. Who _can_ they be?
subQuotationList: ['Dear me,', 'How very exciting. Who _can_ they be?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
One you must avoid; he bodes no good for you, he is steely hearted and
rapacious.
subQuotationList: ['One you must avoid; he bodes no good for you, he is steely hearted and\nrapacious.']
speaker: Mrs. Northcote

quoteText: I bet that's my Mr Beaver, bless him.
subQuotationList: ["I bet that's my Mr Beaver, bless him."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: _Most_ enjoyable, Why, how odd you all look.
subQuotationList: ['_Most_ enjoyable,', 'Why, how odd you all look.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Jock Grant-Menzies wants to see you downstairs.
subQuotationList: ['Jock Grant-Menzies wants to see you downstairs.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Jock? How very extraordinary. It isn't anything awful, is it?
subQuotationList: ["Jock? How very extraordinary. It isn't anything awful, is it?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You'd better go and see him.
subQuotationList: ["You'd better go and see him."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
What is it, Jock? Tell me quickly, I'm scared. It's nothing awful, is
it?
subQuotationList: ["What is it, Jock? Tell me quickly, I'm scared. It's nothing awful, is\nit?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm afraid it is. There's been a very serious accident.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid it is. There's been a very serious accident."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: John?
subQuotationList: ['John?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Dead?
subQuotationList: ['Dead?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Tell me what
happened. Why do you know about it first?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me what\nhappened. Why do you know about it first?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I've been down at Hetton since the week-end.
subQuotationList: ["I've been down at Hetton since the week-end."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Hetton?
subQuotationList: ['Hetton?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Don't you remember? John was going hunting to-day.
subQuotationList: ["Don't you remember? John was going hunting to-day."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
John... John
Andrew... I... oh, thank God...
subQuotationList: ['John... John\nAndrew... I... oh, thank God...']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
There are four men dominating your fate. One is loyal and
tender but has not yet disclosed his love...
subQuotationList: ['There are four men dominating your fate. One is loyal and\ntender but has not yet disclosed his love...']
speaker: Mrs. Northcote
referringExpression: Mrs Northcote had Souki FoucauldEsterhazy by the foot and was saying

quoteText:
This is Jock speaking. I've just seen Brenda. She's coming down by the
seven o'clock train.
subQuotationList: ["This is Jock speaking. I've just seen Brenda. She's coming down by the\nseven o'clock train."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Is she terribly upset?
subQuotationList: ['Is she terribly upset?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, naturally.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, naturally.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Where is she now?
subQuotationList: ['Where is she now?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: She's with me. I'm speaking from Polly's.
subQuotationList: ["She's with me. I'm speaking from Polly's."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Shall I talk to her?
subQuotationList: ['Shall I talk to her?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Better not.
subQuotationList: ['Better not.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: All right... I'll meet that train. Are you coming too?
subQuotationList: ["All right... I'll meet that train. Are you coming too?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No.
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Well, you've been wonderful. I don't know what I should have done
without you and Mrs Rattery.
subQuotationList: ["Well, you've been wonderful. I don't know what I should have done\nwithout you and Mrs Rattery."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, that's all right. I'll see Brenda off.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, that's all right. I'll see Brenda off."]

quoteText: Yes, I'll go by that train.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I'll go by that train."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
We ought to start. I suppose you will have to get some things from the
flat.
subQuotationList: ['We ought to start. I suppose you will have to get some things from the\nflat.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: My bag... upstairs. You get it. I can't go in there again.
subQuotationList: ["My bag... upstairs. You get it. I can't go in there again."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
There's plenty of time really. Tell me exactly what
happened.
subQuotationList: ["There's plenty of time really. Tell me exactly what\nhappened."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Poor little boy, Poor little boy. That's
everything, There's still too much time.
subQuotationList: ['Poor little boy,', 'Poor little boy.', "That's\neverything,", "There's still too much time."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Would you like anything to eat?
subQuotationList: ['Would you like anything to eat?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Oh no, nothing to eat.
subQuotationList: ['Oh no, nothing to eat.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
When you first
told me, I didn't understand. I didn't know what I was
saying.
subQuotationList: ['When you first\ntold me,', "I didn't understand. I didn't know what I was\nsaying."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I know.
subQuotationList: ['I know.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: I didn't say anything, did I?
subQuotationList: ["I didn't say anything, did I?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You know what you said.
subQuotationList: ['You know what you said.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Yes, I know... I didn't mean... I don't think it's any good trying to
explain.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I know... I didn't mean... I don't think it's any good trying to\nexplain."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Are you sure you've got everything?
subQuotationList: ["Are you sure you've got everything?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Yes, that's everything,
subQuotationList: ["Yes, that's everything,"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, we'd better go to the station.
subQuotationList: ["Well, we'd better go to the station."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: All right. It's early. But it doesn't matter.
subQuotationList: ["All right. It's early. But it doesn't matter."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Why not go first-class?
subQuotationList: ['Why not go first-class?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: No, no. I always go third.
subQuotationList: ['No, no. I always go third.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Don't you want anything to read?
subQuotationList: ["Don't you want anything to read?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Nothing to read.
subQuotationList: ['Nothing to read.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Or eat?
subQuotationList: ['Or eat?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Or eat.
subQuotationList: ['Or eat.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Then I'll say good-bye.
subQuotationList: ["Then I'll say good-bye."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['Good-bye.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Well, anyway, this
will mean the end of Mr Beaver.
subQuotationList: ['Well, anyway, this\nwill mean the end of Mr Beaver.']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
That's the end of Tony so far as
Brenda is concerned.
subQuotationList: ["That's the end of Tony so far as\nBrenda is concerned."]
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText: Ghastly thing about Tony Last's boy.
subQuotationList: ["Ghastly thing about Tony Last's boy."]
speaker: Unknowable
referringExpression: One of the men by the bar said

quoteText: Yes, I was there.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I was there.']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: No, were you? What a ghastly thing.
subQuotationList: ['No, were you? What a ghastly thing.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: No, no, tell her I'm not here,
subQuotationList: ["No, no, tell her I'm not here,"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Wait a minute. I must just speak to that poor Ripon girl.
subQuotationList: ['Wait a minute. I must just speak to that poor Ripon girl.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I wish you
had been here yesterday. There were so many people about and I didn't
know what to say to them.
subQuotationList: ["I wish you\nhad been here yesterday. There were so many people about and I didn't\nknow what to say to them."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: What did you do all day?
subQuotationList: ['What did you do all day?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
There was the Shameless Blonde... we played animal snap some of the
time.
subQuotationList: ['There was the Shameless Blonde... we played animal snap some of the\ntime.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Animal snap? Was that any good?
subQuotationList: ['Animal snap? Was that any good?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Not much... It's odd to think that yesterday this time it hadn't
happened.
subQuotationList: ["Not much... It's odd to think that yesterday this time it hadn't\nhappened."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Poor little boy,
subQuotationList: ['Poor little boy,']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Nothing to say, is there?
subQuotationList: ['Nothing to say, is there?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: There's no need to talk.
subQuotationList: ["There's no need to talk."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No. I suppose there'll have to be a funeral.
subQuotationList: ["No. I suppose there'll have to be a funeral."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, of course.
subQuotationList: ['Well, of course.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes: to-morrow?
subQuotationList: ['Yes: to-morrow?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
They've done quite a lot, haven't
they?
subQuotationList: ["They've done quite a lot, haven't\nthey?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Don't
subQuotationList: ["Don't"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I'll go and finish
those letters.
subQuotationList: ["I'll go and finish\nthose letters."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: See you at luncheon.
subQuotationList: ['See you at luncheon.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
If you please, my
lady, I've been going through John's things. There's this handkerchief
doesn't belong to him.
subQuotationList: ["If you please, my\nlady, I've been going through John's things. There's this handkerchief\ndoesn't belong to him."]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: I know whose it is. I'll send it back to her.
subQuotationList: ["I know whose it is. I'll send it back to her."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Can't think how it came to be there,
subQuotationList: ["Can't think how it came to be there,"]
speaker: Nanny

quoteText: Poor little boy. Poor little boy,
subQuotationList: ['Poor little boy. Poor little boy,']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I was thinking about the pony, sir.
subQuotationList: ['I was thinking about the pony, sir.']
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Oh yes, Ben?
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, Ben?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Will you want to be keeping her now?
subQuotationList: ['Will you want to be keeping her now?']
speaker: Ben

quoteText: I hadn't thought... no, I suppose not.
subQuotationList: ["I hadn't thought... no, I suppose not."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Mr Westmacott over at Restall was asking about her. He thought she
might do for his little girl.
subQuotationList: ['Mr Westmacott over at Restall was asking about her. He thought she\nmight do for his little girl.']
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: How much shall we be asking?
subQuotationList: ['How much shall we be asking?']
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Oh, I don't know... whatever you think is right.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I don't know... whatever you think is right."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
She's a good little pony and she's always been treated well. I don't
think she ought to go under twenty-five quid, sir.
subQuotationList: ["She's a good little pony and she's always been treated well. I don't\nthink she ought to go under twenty-five quid, sir."]
speaker: Ben

quoteText: All right, Ben, you see about it.
subQuotationList: ['All right, Ben, you see about it.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'll ask thirty, shall I, sir, and come down a bit?
subQuotationList: ["I'll ask thirty, shall I, sir, and come down a bit?"]
speaker: Ben

quoteText: Do just what you think best.
subQuotationList: ['Do just what you think best.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Very good, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Very good, sir.']
speaker: Ben

quoteText:
Jock rang up. He wanted to know if there was
anything he could do.
subQuotationList: ['Jock rang up. He wanted to know if there was\nanything he could do.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: How sweet of him. Why don't you have him down for the week-end?
subQuotationList: ["How sweet of him. Why don't you have him down for the week-end?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Would you like that?
subQuotationList: ['Would you like that?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I shan't be here. I'm going to Veronica's.
subQuotationList: ["I shan't be here. I'm going to Veronica's."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You're going to Veronica's?
subQuotationList: ["You're going to Veronica's?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, don't you remember?
subQuotationList: ["Yes, don't you remember?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Are you really going
away?
subQuotationList: ['Are you really going\naway?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes. I can't stay here. You understand that, don't you?
subQuotationList: ["Yes. I can't stay here. You understand that, don't you?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Yes, of course. I was thinking we might both go away, abroad
somewhere.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, of course. I was thinking we might both go away, abroad\nsomewhere.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I couldn't
stay here. It's all over, don't you see, our life down here.
subQuotationList: ["I couldn't\nstay here. It's all over, don't you see, our life down here."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Darling, what _do_ you mean?
subQuotationList: ['Darling, what _do_ you mean?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Don't ask me to explain... not just now.
subQuotationList: ["Don't ask me to explain... not just now."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
But, Brenda, sweet, I don't understand. We're both young. Of course, we
can never forget John. He'll always be our eldest son, but...
subQuotationList: ["But, Brenda, sweet, I don't understand. We're both young. Of course, we\ncan never forget John. He'll always be our eldest son, but..."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Don't go on, Tony, please don't go on.
subQuotationList: ["Don't go on, Tony, please don't go on."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
So you're going to Veronica's
to-morrow?
subQuotationList: ["So you're going to Veronica's\nto-morrow?"]
speaker: Tony Last
referringExpression: Tony stopped and after a time said

quoteText: Mmmm.
subQuotationList: ['Mmmm.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I think I will ask Jock to come.
subQuotationList: ['I think I will ask Jock to come.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, I should.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I should.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: And we can think about plans later when we've got more used to things.
subQuotationList: ["And we can think about plans later when we've got more used to things."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, later.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, later.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: A sweet letter from mother,
subQuotationList: ['A sweet letter from mother,']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I got a telegram from Jock, he _can_ come.
subQuotationList: ['I got a telegram from Jock,', 'he _can_ come.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It's really rather embarrassing for us all, Brenda coming, I do think she might have chucked. I shan't in the least know
what to say to her.
subQuotationList: ["It's really rather embarrassing for us all, Brenda coming,", "I do think she might have chucked. I shan't in the least know\nwhat to say to her."]
speaker: Veronica

quoteText:
I've been trying to
understand, and I think I do now. It's not how I feel myself, but Brenda
and I are quite different in lots of ways. It's _because_ they were
strangers and didn't know John, and were never in our life here, that
she wants to be with them. That's it, don't you think? She wants to be
absolutely alone and away from everything that reminds her of what has
happened... all the same I feel awful about letting her go. I can't
tell you what she was like here... quite mechanical. It's so much worse
for her than it is for me, I see that. It's so terrible not being able
to do anything to help.
subQuotationList:
["I've been trying to
understand, and I think I do now. It's not how I feel myself, but Brenda
and I are quite different in lots of ways. It's _because_ they were
strangers and didn't know John, and were never in our life here, that
she wants to be with them. That's it, don't you think? She wants to be
absolutely alone and away from everything that reminds her of what has
happened... all the same I feel awful about letting her go. I can't
tell you what she was like here... quite mechanical. It's so much worse
for her than it is for me, I see that. It's so terrible not being able
to do anything to help."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Until Wednesday,
when I thought something had happened to you, I had no idea that I loved
you.
subQuotationList: ['Until Wednesday,\nwhen I thought something had happened to you, I had no idea that I loved\nyou.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well you've said it often enough.
subQuotationList: ["Well you've said it often enough."]
speaker: Beaver

quoteText: I'm going to make you understand, You clod.
subQuotationList: ["I'm going to make you understand,", 'You clod.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: She's only seen Beaver twice to my knowledge,
subQuotationList: ["She's only seen Beaver twice to my knowledge,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I'm sorry it should
have happened like this.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry it should\nhave happened like this."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: But it's not true, is it?
subQuotationList: ["But it's not true, is it?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, I'm afraid it is. Everyone has known for some time.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I'm afraid it is. Everyone has known for some time."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: How's the old boy taking it?
subQuotationList: ["How's the old boy taking it?"]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
Not so well. It makes me feel rather a beast, I'm afraid
he minds a lot.
subQuotationList: ['Not so well. It makes me feel rather a beast,', "I'm afraid\nhe minds a lot."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, you wouldn't like it if he didn't,
subQuotationList: ["Well, you wouldn't like it if he didn't,"]
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText: No, I suppose not.
subQuotationList: ['No, I suppose not.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I shall stick by you whatever happens,
subQuotationList: ['I shall stick by you whatever happens,']
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
Oh, everything is going quite smoothly now, There was a
certain amount of _g?ne_ with relatives.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, everything is going quite smoothly now,', 'There was a\ncertain amount of _g?ne_ with relatives.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
You just wait a few weeks, Brenda will come back. She'll
soon get sick of Beaver.
subQuotationList: ['You just wait a few weeks,', "Brenda will come back. She'll\nsoon get sick of Beaver."]
speaker: Allan

quoteText: But I don't want her back.
subQuotationList: ["But I don't want her back."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I know just how you feel, but it doesn't do to be medieval about it. If
Brenda hadn't been upset at John's death this need never have come to a
crisis. Why, last year Marjorie was going everywhere with that ass Robin
Beaseley. She was mad about him at the time, but I pretended not to
notice and it all blew over. If I were you I should refuse to recognize
that anything has happened.
subQuotationList:
["I know just how you feel, but it doesn't do to be medieval about it. If
Brenda hadn't been upset at John's death this need never have come to a
crisis. Why, last year Marjorie was going everywhere with that ass Robin
Beaseley. She was mad about him at the time, but I pretended not to
notice and it all blew over. If I were you I should refuse to recognize
that anything has happened."]
speaker: Allan

quoteText:
Of _course_ Brenda doesn't love Beaver. How could
she?... And if she thinks she does at the moment, it's your duty to
prevent her making a fool of herself. You must refuse to be
divorced--anyway, until she has found someone more reasonable.
subQuotationList:
["Of _course_ Brenda doesn't love Beaver. How could
she?... And if she thinks she does at the moment, it's your duty to
prevent her making a fool of herself. You must refuse to be
divorced--anyway, until she has found someone more reasonable."]
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
Brenda has been very, very foolish. She always
was an excitable girl, but I am sure there was never anything _wrong_,
quite sure. _That_ wouldn't be like Brenda at all. I haven't met Mr
Beaver and I do not wish to. I understand he is unsuitable in every way.
Brenda would never want to marry anyone like that. I will tell you
exactly how it happened, Tony. Brenda must have felt a tiny bit
neglected--people often do at that stage of marriage. I have known
countless cases--and it was naturally flattering to find a young man to
beg and carry for her. That's all it was, nothing _wrong_. And then the
terrible shock of little John's accident unsettled her and she didn't
know what she was saying or writing. You'll both laugh over this little
fracas in years to come.
subQuotationList:
["Brenda has been very, very foolish. She always
was an excitable girl, but I am sure there was never anything _wrong_,
quite sure. _That_ wouldn't be like Brenda at all. I haven't met Mr
Beaver and I do not wish to. I understand he is unsuitable in every way.
Brenda would never want to marry anyone like that. I will tell you
exactly how it happened, Tony. Brenda must have felt a tiny bit
neglected--people often do at that stage of marriage. I have known
countless cases--and it was naturally flattering to find a young man to
beg and carry for her. That's all it was, nothing _wrong_. And then the
terrible shock of little John's accident unsettled her and she didn't
know what she was saying or writing. You'll both laugh over this little
fracas in years to come."]
speaker: Lady St. Cloud

quoteText:
I've been talking to Brenda, She's sick
of Beaver already. The one thing she wants is to go back to Hetton and
settle down with you again.
subQuotationList: ["I've been talking to Brenda,", "She's sick\nof Beaver already. The one thing she wants is to go back to Hetton and\nsettle down with you again."]
speaker: Allan

quoteText: Brenda, this is Tony.
subQuotationList: ['Brenda, this is Tony.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Hullo, Tony, what is it?
subQuotationList: ['Hullo, Tony, what is it?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I've been talking to Allan. He's just told me about your change of
mind.
subQuotationList: ["I've been talking to Allan. He's just told me about your change of\nmind."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'm not sure I know what you mean.
subQuotationList: ["I'm not sure I know what you mean."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: That you want to leave Beaver and come back to Hetton.
subQuotationList: ['That you want to leave Beaver and come back to Hetton.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Did Allan say that?
subQuotationList: ['Did Allan say that?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Yes; isn't it true?
subQuotationList: ["Yes; isn't it true?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I'm afraid it's not. Allan is an interfering ass. I had him here this
afternoon. He told me that you didn't want a divorce but that you were
willing to let me stay on alone in London and do as I liked provided
there was no public scandal. It seemed a good idea and I was going to
ring you up about it. But I suppose that's just his diplomacy too.
Anyway, I'm afraid there's no prospect of my coming back to Hetton just
at present.
subQuotationList:
["I'm afraid it's not. Allan is an interfering ass. I had him here this
afternoon. He told me that you didn't want a divorce but that you were
willing to let me stay on alone in London and do as I liked provided
there was no public scandal. It seemed a good idea and I was going to
ring you up about it. But I suppose that's just his diplomacy too.
Anyway, I'm afraid there's no prospect of my coming back to Hetton just
at present."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, I see. I didn't think it was likely... I just rang you up.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I see. I didn't think it was likely... I just rang you up."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's all right. How are you, Tony?
subQuotationList: ["That's all right. How are you, Tony?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: All right, thanks.
subQuotationList: ['All right, thanks.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Good, so am I. Good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['Good, so am I. Good-bye.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I gather Lady Brenda is being far from discreet. It is quite likely
that the King's Proctor may intervene... Moreover, there is the
question of money. You understand that by the present arrangement since
she is the innocent and injured party she will be entitled to claim
substantial alimony from the courts?
subQuotationList:
["I gather Lady Brenda is being far from discreet. It is quite likely
that the King's Proctor may intervene... Moreover, there is the
question of money. You understand that by the present arrangement since
she is the innocent and injured party she will be entitled to claim
substantial alimony from the courts?"]
speaker: The Solicitor

quoteText:
Oh, that's all right, I've been into all that with her
brother-in-law and have decided to make a settlement of five hundred a
year. She has four hundred of her own and I understand Mr Beaver has
something.
subQuotationList:
["Oh, that's all right,", "I've been into all that with her
brother-in-law and have decided to make a settlement of five hundred a
year. She has four hundred of her own and I understand Mr Beaver has
something."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It's a pity we can't put it in writing, but that
might constitute Conspiracy.
subQuotationList: ["It's a pity we can't put it in writing,", 'but that\nmight constitute Conspiracy.']
speaker: The Solicitor

quoteText: Lady Brenda's word is quite good enough,
subQuotationList: ["Lady Brenda's word is quite good enough,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
We like to protect our clients against even the most remote
contingencies,
subQuotationList: ['We like to protect our clients against even the most remote\ncontingencies,']
speaker: The Solicitor

quoteText:
We always
send our clients there. The servants are well accustomed to giving
evidence
subQuotationList: ['We always\nsend our clients there. The servants are well accustomed to giving\nevidence']
speaker: The Solicitor

quoteText:
It only remains to
select a partner, We have on occasions been instrumental in accommodating our
clients but there have been frequent complaints, so we find it best to
leave the choice to them. Lately we had a particularly delicate case
involving a man of very rigid morality and a certain diffidence. In the
end his own wife consented to go with him and supply the evidence. She
wore a red wig. It was quite successful.
subQuotationList:
['It only remains to
select a partner,', 'We have on occasions been instrumental in accommodating our
clients but there have been frequent complaints, so we find it best to
leave the choice to them. Lately we had a particularly delicate case
involving a man of very rigid morality and a certain diffidence. In the
end his own wife consented to go with him and supply the evidence. She
wore a red wig. It was quite successful.']
speaker: The Solicitor

quoteText: I don't think that would do in this case.
subQuotationList: ["I don't think that would do in this case."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No. Exactly. I was merely quoting it as a matter of interest.
subQuotationList: ['No. Exactly. I was merely quoting it as a matter of interest.']
speaker: The Solicitor

quoteText: I expect I shall be able to find someone,
subQuotationList: ['I expect I shall be able to find someone,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I have no doubt of it,
subQuotationList: ['I have no doubt of it,']
speaker: The Solicitor

quoteText:
It's not a thing one can ask every girl to do, whichever way you put it. If you say it is merely a legal form it is
rather insulting, and if you suggest going the whole hog it's rather
fresh--suddenly, I mean, if you've never paid any particular attention
to her before and don't propose to carry on with it afterwards... Of
course there's always old Sybil.
subQuotationList:
["It's not a thing one can ask every girl to do,", "whichever way you put it. If you say it is merely a legal form it is
rather insulting, and if you suggest going the whole hog it's rather
fresh--suddenly, I mean, if you've never paid any particular attention
to her before and don't propose to carry on with it afterwards... Of
course there's always old Sybil."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I'd do it like a shot any other time, but just at the moment it wouldn't suit my book. There's a
certain person who might hear about it and take it wrong... There's an
awfully pretty girl called Jenny Abdul Akbar. I wonder if you've met
her.
subQuotationList:
["I'd do it like a shot any other time,", "but just at the moment it wouldn't suit my book. There's a
certain person who might hear about it and take it wrong... There's an
awfully pretty girl called Jenny Abdul Akbar. I wonder if you've met
her."]

speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, won't she do?
subQuotationList: ["Well, won't she do?"]

quoteText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh dear, I don't know who to suggest.
subQuotationList: ["Oh dear, I don't know who to suggest."]
speaker: Sybil

speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: Is it any good going there yet?
subQuotationList: ['Is it any good going there yet?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: We may as well try. After all, we aren't going there for enjoyment.
subQuotationList: ["We may as well try. After all, we aren't going there for enjoyment."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: No, indeed.
subQuotationList: ['No, indeed.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Any of those do?
subQuotationList: ['Any of those do?']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: I don't much care.
subQuotationList: ["I don't much care."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Better get someone you like. You've got to put in a lot of time with
her.
subQuotationList: ["Better get someone you like. You've got to put in a lot of time with\nher."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: How are the postmen's hats?
subQuotationList: ["How are the postmen's hats?"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: You are the two boys who were here last month, aren't you?
subQuotationList: ["You are the two boys who were here last month, aren't you?"]
speaker: Milly
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Jock Grant-Menzies', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last', 'Jock Grant-Menzies'], ['Jock Grant-Menzies', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText: Yes. I'm afraid we were rather tight.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. I'm afraid we were rather tight."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: You don't say?
subQuotationList: ["You don't say?"]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: Well, come and sit down. How are you both?
subQuotationList: ['Well, come and sit down. How are you both?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
I think I'm starting a cold, I feel awful. Why can't they
heat this hole, the mean hounds?
subQuotationList: ["I think I'm starting a cold,", "I feel awful. Why can't they\nheat this hole, the mean hounds?"]
speaker: Babs

quoteText:
Care to
dance?
subQuotationList: ['Care to\ndance?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: My friend is looking for a lady to take to the seaside,
subQuotationList: ['My friend is looking for a lady to take to the seaside,']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText: What, this weather? That'll be a nice treat for a lonely girl.
subQuotationList: ["What, this weather? That'll be a nice treat for a lonely girl."]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: It's for a divorce.
subQuotationList: ["It's for a divorce."]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Oh, I see. Well, why doesn't he take Milly? She doesn't catch cold
easy. Besides, she knows how to behave at an hotel. Lots of the girls
here are all right to have a lark with in town, but you have to have a
_lady_ for a divorce.
subQuotationList:
["Oh, I see. Well, why doesn't he take Milly? She doesn't catch cold
easy. Besides, she knows how to behave at an hotel. Lots of the girls
here are all right to have a lark with in town, but you have to have a
_lady_ for a divorce."]
speaker: Babs

quoteText: D'you often get asked to do that?
subQuotationList: ["D'you often get asked to do that?"]
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

quoteText:
Now and then. It's a nice rest--but it means so much _talking_ and the
gentlemen will always go on so about their wives.
subQuotationList: ["Now and then. It's a nice rest--but it means so much _talking_ and the\ngentlemen will always go on so about their wives."]
speaker: Babs

quoteText:
I suppose you
wouldn't care to come away for the week-end?
subQuotationList: ["I suppose you\nwouldn't care to come away for the week-end?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Shouldn't mind, Where?
subQuotationList: ["Shouldn't mind,", 'Where?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: I thought of Brighton.
subQuotationList: ['I thought of Brighton.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh... Is it for a divorce?
subQuotationList: ['Oh... Is it for a divorce?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You wouldn't mind if I brought my little girl with us? She wouldn't be
any trouble.
subQuotationList: ["You wouldn't mind if I brought my little girl with us? She wouldn't be\nany trouble."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You mean you wouldn't mind?
subQuotationList: ["You mean you wouldn't mind?"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: I mean I should mind.
subQuotationList: ['I mean I should mind.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh... You wouldn't think I had a little girl of eight, would you?
subQuotationList: ["Oh... You wouldn't think I had a little girl of eight, would you?"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
She's called Winnie. I was only sixteen when I had her. I was the
youngest of the family and our stepfather wouldn't leave any of us girls
alone. That's why I have to work. She lives with a lady at Finchley.
Twenty-eight bob a week it costs me, not counting her clothes. She does
like the seaside.
subQuotationList:
["She's called Winnie. I was only sixteen when I had her. I was the
youngest of the family and our stepfather wouldn't leave any of us girls
alone. That's why I have to work. She lives with a lady at Finchley.
Twenty-eight bob a week it costs me, not counting her clothes. She does
like the seaside."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
No, I'm sorry but it would be quite impossible. We'll get
a lovely present for you to take back to her.
subQuotationList: ['No,', "I'm sorry but it would be quite impossible. We'll get\na lovely present for you to take back to her."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
All right... One gentleman gave her a fairy-cycle for Christmas. She
fell off and cut her knee... When do we start?
subQuotationList: ['All right... One gentleman gave her a fairy-cycle for Christmas. She\nfell off and cut her knee... When do we start?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Would you like to go by train or car?
subQuotationList: ['Would you like to go by train or car?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, train. Winnie's sick if she goes in a car.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, train. Winnie's sick if she goes in a car."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Winnie's not coming.
subQuotationList: ["Winnie's not coming."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, but let's go by train anyway.
subQuotationList: ["No, but let's go by train anyway."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: This is going to be hell,
subQuotationList: ['This is going to be hell,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Sorry if I'm late, Winnie here couldn't find
her shoes. I brought her along too. I knew you wouldn't mind really. She
travels on a half ticket.
subQuotationList: ["Sorry if I'm late,", "Winnie here couldn't find\nher shoes. I brought her along too. I knew you wouldn't mind really. She\ntravels on a half ticket."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: I hope you don't imagine she's coming with us.
subQuotationList: ["I hope you don't imagine she's coming with us."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, that the idea, She won't be any trouble--she's got
her puzzle.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, that the idea,', "She won't be any trouble--she's got\nher puzzle."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
Listen, You
don't want to come to a nasty big hotel. You go with this kind gentleman
here. He'll take you to a shop and let you choose the biggest doll you
can find and then he'll drive you back in his motor to your home. You'll
like that, won't you?
subQuotationList:
['Listen,', "You
don't want to come to a nasty big hotel. You go with this kind gentleman
here. He'll take you to a shop and let you choose the biggest doll you

like that, won't you?"]

quoteText:
No, I want to go to the seaside. I won't go with that
man. I don't want a doll. I want to go to the seaside with my mummy.
subQuotationList: ['No,', "I want to go to the seaside. I won't go with that\nman. I don't want a doll. I want to go to the seaside with my mummy."]

subQuotationList: ['Oh God!', "I suppose she's got to come."]

Look, we're travelling
first-class. Isn't that fun? We can have tea.

quoteText: Can I have an ice?
subQuotationList: ['Can I have an ice?']

subQuotationList: ["I don't expect they've got an ice. But you can have some nice tea."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: But I want an ice.
subQuotationList: ['But I want an ice.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText:
You shall have an ice when you get to Brighton. Now be a good girl and
play with your puzzle or mother won't take you to the seaside again.
subQuotationList: ["You shall have an ice when you get to Brighton. Now be a good girl and\nplay with your puzzle or mother won't take you to the seaside again."]

subQuotationList: ['The Awful Child of popular fiction,']
speaker: Jock Grant-Menzies

We
have reserved in your name double and single communicating rooms,

have reserved in your name double and single communicating rooms,

quoteText:
He got out
of that all right. Quite smart. But I don't like the look of this case.
Most irregular. Sets a nasty, respectable note bringing a kid into it.
We've got the firm to consider. It doesn't do them any good to get mixed
up with the King's Proctor.

["He got out
of that all right. Quite smart. But I don't like the look of this case.

speaker: Milly

subQuotationList: ['I want to go and see it.']

subQuotationList: ["But it's dark now, pet. You shall see it to-morrow."]

subQuotationList: ['I want to see it to-night.']
speaker: Winnie

speaker: Tony Last

subQuotationList: ["Sure you won't be lonely?"]
speaker: Milly

speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Good evening,

Nasty, raw
evening.

quoteText: Have a drink.
subQuotationList: ['Have a drink.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Don't mind if I do.
subQuotationList: ["Don't mind if I do."]
speaker: The Detective Colleague
referringExpression: the junior detective brightened instinctively and said

quoteText: Come and sit down. I feel rather lonely.
subQuotationList: ['Come and sit down. I feel rather lonely.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Mr
Last, sir, this is all _wrong_, You haven't
no business to recognize us at all. I don't know what they'd say at the
office.
subQuotationList:
['Mr
Last, sir, this is all _wrong_,', "You haven't
no business to recognize us at all. I don't know what they'd say at the
office."]
speaker: The Detective
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']], [['Tony Last'], ['The Detective', 'The Detective Colleague']]]

quoteText: Best respects,
subQuotationList: ['Best respects,']
speaker: The Detective Colleague

quoteText:
This is Mr James, my colleague, My name is
Blenkinsop. James is new to this kind of work.
subQuotationList: ['This is Mr James, my colleague,', 'My name is\nBlenkinsop. James is new to this kind of work.']
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: So am I,
subQuotationList: ['So am I,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
A pity we've such a nasty week-end for the job, very
damp and blowy. Gets me in the joints.
subQuotationList: ["A pity we've such a nasty week-end for the job,", 'very\ndamp and blowy. Gets me in the joints.']
speaker: The Detective

quoteText:
Tell me, Is it usual to bring children on an expedition of
this kind?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me,', 'Is it usual to bring children on an expedition of\nthis kind?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It is _not_.
subQuotationList: ['It is _not_.']
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: I thought it couldn't be.
subQuotationList: ["I thought it couldn't be."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Since you ask me, Mr Last, I regard it as most irregular and
injudicious. It looks wrong, and cases of this kind depend very much on
making the right impression. Of course as far as James and me are
concerned, the matter is O.K. There won't be a word about it in our
evidence. But you can't trust the servants. You might very likely happen
to strike one who was new to the courts, who'd blurt it out, and then
where would we be. I don't like it, Mr Last, and that's the truth.
subQuotationList:
["Since you ask me, Mr Last, I regard it as most irregular and
injudicious. It looks wrong, and cases of this kind depend very much on
making the right impression. Of course as far as James and me are
concerned, the matter is O.K. There won't be a word about it in our
evidence. But you can't trust the servants. You might very likely happen
to strike one who was new to the courts, who'd blurt it out, and then
where would we be. I don't like it, Mr Last, and that's the truth."]
speaker: The Detective
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['The Detective Colleague'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['The Detective', 'The Detective Colleague'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: You can't feel more strongly about it than I do.
subQuotationList: ["You can't feel more strongly about it than I do."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Fond of kids myself, How about one with us?
subQuotationList: ['Fond of kids myself,', 'How about one with us?']
speaker: The Detective Colleague

quoteText:
Tell me, You must have observed numerous couples in your time, qualifying
for a divorce; tell me, how do they get through their day?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me,', 'You must have observed numerous couples in your time, qualifying\nfor a divorce; tell me, how do they get through their day?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It's easier in the summer, the young ladies usually
bathe and the gentlemen read the papers on the esplanade; some goes for
motor drives and some just hangs around the bar. They're mostly glad
when Monday comes.
subQuotationList:
["It's easier in the summer,", "the young ladies usually
bathe and the gentlemen read the papers on the esplanade; some goes for
motor drives and some just hangs around the bar. They're mostly glad
when Monday comes."]
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: I've ordered an ice,
subQuotationList: ["I've ordered an ice,"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Quite right.
subQuotationList: ['Quite right.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I want late dinner. I want late dinner.
subQuotationList: ['I want late dinner. I want late dinner.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: No, dear, not late dinner. You have an ice up here.
subQuotationList: ['No, dear, not late dinner. You have an ice up here.']
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
Mr James, Did I understand you to
say you were fond of children.
subQuotationList: ['Mr James,', 'Did I understand you to\nsay you were fond of children.']
speaker: Tony Last
mentionEntitiesList: [[['The Detective Colleague']], [['The Detective Colleague'], ['The Detective Colleague']]]

quoteText: Yes, in their right place.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, in their right place.']
speaker: The Detective Colleague

quoteText:
You wouldn't, I suppose, consider dining to-night with the little girl
who has accompanied me? I should take it as a great kindness.
subQuotationList: ["You wouldn't, I suppose, consider dining to-night with the little girl\nwho has accompanied me? I should take it as a great kindness."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh no, sir, hardly that.
subQuotationList: ['Oh no, sir, hardly that.']
speaker: The Detective Colleague

quoteText: You would not find me ungrateful.
subQuotationList: ['You would not find me ungrateful.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, sir, I don't want to appear unobliging, but it's not part of my
duties.
subQuotationList: ["Well, sir, I don't want to appear unobliging, but it's not part of my\nduties."]
speaker: The Detective Colleague

quoteText:
Quite out of the
question, sir.
subQuotationList: ['Quite out of the\nquestion, sir.']
speaker: The Detective

quoteText:
Our trouble is always the
same--to make the clients realize that divorce is a serious matter.
subQuotationList: ['Our trouble is always the\nsame--to make the clients realize that divorce is a serious matter.']
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: How are we going to sleep?
subQuotationList: ['How are we going to sleep?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Oh, just as you like.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, just as you like.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Just as _you_ like.
subQuotationList: ['Just as _you_ like.']
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
Well, perhaps Winnie would be happier with you... she'll have to go
into the other room to-morrow morning when they bring in breakfast, of
course.
subQuotationList: ["Well, perhaps Winnie would be happier with you... she'll have to go\ninto the other room to-morrow morning when they bring in breakfast, of\ncourse."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Charming, perfectly charming. Shall
we go down to dinner?
subQuotationList: ['Charming,', 'perfectly charming. Shall\nwe go down to dinner?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Cheer up, You have a tongue sandwich. That'll make you
talk.
subQuotationList: ['Cheer up,', "You have a tongue sandwich. That'll make you\ntalk."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Sorry, am I being a bore?
subQuotationList: ['Sorry, am I being a bore?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I was only joking. You are a serious boy, aren't you?
subQuotationList: ["I was only joking. You are a serious boy, aren't you?"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
Yids, Still, it's nice to get a change
from the club once in a while.
subQuotationList: ['Yids,', "Still, it's nice to get a change\nfrom the club once in a while."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText:
Take "em up and
get "em unpacked and quick about it,
subQuotationList: ['Take "em up and\nget "em unpacked and quick about it,']
speaker: Dan

quoteText: Oh, for Christ's sake,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, for Christ's sake,"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: This is Dan,
subQuotationList: ['This is Dan,']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Well, well, well, what next?
subQuotationList: ['Well, well, well,', 'what next?']
speaker: Dan

Baby, you do, if I have to get it myself. Won't you two join us, or are
we _de trop_?
subQuotationList: ["Baby, you do, if I have to get it myself. Won't you two join us, or are\nwe _de trop_?"]

quoteText: I'm cold like hell,
subQuotationList: ["I'm cold like hell,"]

quoteText: We'll soon warm you up,

quoteText: This place stinks of Yids,
subQuotationList: ['This place stinks of Yids,']

quoteText: I always think that's the sign of a good hotel, don't you?

quoteText: Like hell,

speaker: Dan'S Girl

quoteText: You mustn't mind Baby, she's cold,
subQuotationList: ["You mustn't mind Baby, she's cold,"]

quoteText: Who wouldn't be, in your lousy car?

He's a very nice boy, and comes to the club a lot.
We get all sorts there, but Dan's one of the decent ones. I was going to
have gone abroad with him once but in the end he couldn't get away.
subQuotationList: ["He's a very nice boy,", "and comes to the club a lot.\nWe get all sorts there, but Dan's one of the decent ones. I was going to\nhave gone abroad with him once but in the end he couldn't get away."]

speaker: Milly

quoteText: That's a pretty girl in the corner.
subQuotationList: ["That's a pretty girl in the corner."]
speaker: Tony Last

Look here, if you two aren't doing anything special, why
don't you join up with us and come to the party at my friend's place.
You'll like it. He always gives one the best of everything.

This stuff's all right, it won't hurt

I'm so glad Dan brought you, Hope you're getting all

see over the place. Interested in roses?

quoteText: Nice kid, Milly.
subQuotationList: ['Nice kid, Milly.']
speaker: Dan

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I'll tell you a thing I've noticed about her. She attracts quite a
different type from the other girls. People like you and me.
subQuotationList: ["I'll tell you a thing I've noticed about her. She attracts quite a\ndifferent type from the other girls. People like you and me."]
speaker: Dan

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You wouldn't think she had a daughter of eight, would you?
subQuotationList: ["You wouldn't think she had a daughter of eight, would you?"]
speaker: Dan

quoteText: No, it's very surprising.
subQuotationList: ["No, it's very surprising."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I didn't know for ages. Then I was taking her to Dieppe for the
week-end and she wanted to bring the child along too. Of course that put
the kybosh on it, but I've always liked Milly just the same. You can
trust her to behave anywhere.
subQuotationList:
["I didn't know for ages. Then I was taking her to Dieppe for the
week-end and she wanted to bring the child along too. Of course that put
the kybosh on it, but I've always liked Milly just the same. You can
trust her to behave anywhere."]
speaker: Dan

quoteText:
I doubt if you'll
find a better show of roses anywhere in the south of England,
subQuotationList: ["I doubt if you'll\nfind a better show of roses anywhere in the south of England,"]
speaker: Dan'S Friend

quoteText:
Where were you? Never saw you all
the evening. Where did you get to? Where were you hiding? I call it a
lousy way to take a girl out.
subQuotationList: ['Where were you?', 'Never saw you all\nthe evening. Where did you get to? Where were you hiding? I call it a\nlousy way to take a girl out.']
speaker: Dan'S Girl

quoteText: Go quietly. We don't want to wake Winnie.
subQuotationList: ["Go quietly. We don't want to wake Winnie."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: Mother's still asleep,
subQuotationList: ["Mother's still asleep,"]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: So I should think, Go back to bed.
subQuotationList: ['So I should think,', 'Go back to bed.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, I'm dressed. Let's go out.
subQuotationList: ["No, I'm dressed. Let's go out."]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: It's hardly raining at all,
subQuotationList: ["It's hardly raining at all,"]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: What do you want to do?
subQuotationList: ['What do you want to do?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I want to go on the pier.
subQuotationList: ['I want to go on the pier.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: It won't be open yet.
subQuotationList: ["It won't be open yet."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, I want to go down to the sea. Come on.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I want to go down to the sea. Come on.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText:
All right.
You go and wait while I dress.
subQuotationList: ['All right.\nYou go and wait while I dress.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I'll wait here. Mother snores so.
subQuotationList: ["I'll wait here. Mother snores so."]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Oh, come on,
subQuotationList: ['Oh, come on,']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Why don't you bathe?
subQuotationList: ["Why don't you bathe?"]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Far too cold.
subQuotationList: ['Far too cold.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: But _they're_ bathing. I want to.
subQuotationList: ["But _they're_ bathing. I want to."]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: You must ask your mother.
subQuotationList: ['You must ask your mother.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I believe you're afraid. Can you swim?
subQuotationList: ["I believe you're afraid. Can you swim?"]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, why don't you? Bet you can't.
subQuotationList: ["Well, why don't you? Bet you can't."]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: All right. I can't.
subQuotationList: ["All right. I can't."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Then why did you say you could. Fibber.
subQuotationList: ['Then why did you say you could. Fibber.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Now my knickers are wet,
subQuotationList: ['Now my knickers are wet,']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Better come back and change.
subQuotationList: ['Better come back and change.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It feels horrible. Let's go and have breakfast.
subQuotationList: ["It feels horrible. Let's go and have breakfast."]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: We missed you last night,
subQuotationList: ['We missed you last night,']
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: We went to a party.
subQuotationList: ['We went to a party.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You shouldn't have done that--not strictly, but I daresay no harm will
come of it. Have you had your breakfast?
subQuotationList: ["You shouldn't have done that--not strictly, but I daresay no harm will\ncome of it. Have you had your breakfast?"]
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: Yes, in the dining-room with Winnie.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, in the dining-room with Winnie.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
But, Mr Last, what are you thinking of? You've got to get evidence from
the hotel servants.
subQuotationList: ["But, Mr Last, what are you thinking of? You've got to get evidence from\nthe hotel servants."]
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: Well, I didn't like to wake Milly.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I didn't like to wake Milly."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
She's paid for it, isn't she? Come, come, Mr Last, this won't do at
all. You'll never get your divorce if you don't give your mind to it
more.
subQuotationList: ["She's paid for it, isn't she? Come, come, Mr Last, this won't do at\nall. You'll never get your divorce if you don't give your mind to it\nmore."]
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: All right, I'll have breakfast again.
subQuotationList: ['All right,', "I'll have breakfast again."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: In bed, mind.
subQuotationList: ['In bed, mind.']
speaker: The Detective

quoteText: In bed.
subQuotationList: ['In bed.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
She woke
up once and then turned over. Do get her to come out. I want to go on
the pier.
subQuotationList: ['She woke\nup once and then turned over. Do get her to come out. I want to go on\nthe pier.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Milly, Milly.
subQuotationList: ['Milly,', 'Milly.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, What time is it?
subQuotationList: ['Oh,', 'What time is it?']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: We've got to have breakfast.
subQuotationList: ["We've got to have breakfast."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Don't want any breakfast. I think I'll sleep a little.
subQuotationList: ["Don't want any breakfast. I think I'll sleep a little."]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: You've had breakfast,
