subQuotationList: ["You've had breakfast,"]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText:
Come on, Plenty of time to sleep afterwards. This is what
we came for.
subQuotationList: ['Come on,', 'Plenty of time to sleep afterwards. This is what\nwe came for.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
O.K., Winnie, darling, give mother her
jacket off the chair.
subQuotationList: ['O.K.,', 'Winnie, darling, give mother her\njacket off the chair.']
speaker: Milly

quoteText: But it's early.
subQuotationList: ["But it's early."]
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: You are greedy, eating two breakfasts.
subQuotationList: ['You are greedy,', 'eating two breakfasts.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText:
When you're a little older you'll understand these things. It's the
Law. Now I want you to stay in the sitting-room for a quarter of an hour
very quietly. Promise? And afterwards you can do exactly what you like.
subQuotationList: ["When you're a little older you'll understand these things. It's the\nLaw. Now I want you to stay in the sitting-room for a quarter of an hour\nvery quietly. Promise? And afterwards you can do exactly what you like."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Can I bathe?
subQuotationList: ['Can I bathe?']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Yes, certainly, if you're quiet now.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, certainly, if you're quiet now."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Does that look all right?
subQuotationList: ['Does that look all right?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Love's young dream,
subQuotationList: ["Love's young dream,"]
speaker: Milly

quoteText: All right, then. I'll ring the bell.
subQuotationList: ["All right, then. I'll ring the bell."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: So much for my infidelity,
subQuotationList: ['So much for my infidelity,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It is curious to reflect
that this will be described in the papers as "intimacy".
subQuotationList: ['It is curious to reflect\nthat this will be described in the papers as "intimacy".']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Can I bathe now?
subQuotationList: ['Can I bathe now?']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText: Certainly.
subQuotationList: ['Certainly.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: This little girl would like to bathe,
subQuotationList: ['This little girl would like to bathe,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No bathing for children to-day,
subQuotationList: ['No bathing for children to-day,']
speaker: The Beach Attendant

quoteText:
The very idea, Does he want to drown the
child? He's no business to be trusted with children. _Unnatural
beast._
subQuotationList: ['The very idea,', 'Does he want to drown the\nchild?', "He's no business to be trusted with children.", '_Unnatural\nbeast._']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
But I _want_ to bathe, You said I could bathe if you had
two breakfasts.
subQuotationList: ['But I _want_ to bathe,', 'You said I could bathe if you had\ntwo breakfasts.']
speaker: Winnie

quoteText:
Two breakfasts? Wanting to let the child bathe?
The man's balmy.
subQuotationList: ["Two breakfasts? Wanting to let the child bathe?\nThe man's balmy."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Never mind, We'll go on the pier.
subQuotationList: ['Never mind,', "We'll go on the pier."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
There's a man who's eaten
two breakfasts and tries to drown his little girl,
subQuotationList: ["There's a man who's eaten\ntwo breakfasts and tries to drown his little girl,"]
speaker: Unknowable
mentionTextsList: [["There's a man who's eaten\ntwo breakfasts ", 'his little girl']]

quoteText:
Well, We have our case now, all quite
regular and complete. I don't think it can come on until next
term--there's a great rush at the moment, but there's no harm in you
having your own evidence ready. I've got it typed out for you. You'd
better keep it by you and get it clear in your mind.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', "We have our case now, all quite
regular and complete. I don't think it can come on until next
term--there's a great rush at the moment, but there's no harm in you
having your own evidence ready. I've got it typed out for you. You'd
better keep it by you and get it clear in your mind."]
speaker: Brenda'S Solicitor

quoteText:
Is that
necessary?
subQuotationList: ['Is that\nnecessary?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Not strictly, but it is advisable to put it in. A great deal depends on
psychological impression. Judges in their more lucid moments sometimes
wonder why perfectly respectable, happily married men go off for
week-ends to the seaside with women they do not know. It is always
helpful to offer evidence of general degeneracy.
subQuotationList:
['Not strictly, but it is advisable to put it in. A great deal depends on
psychological impression. Judges in their more lucid moments sometimes
wonder why perfectly respectable, happily married men go off for
week-ends to the seaside with women they do not know. It is always
helpful to offer evidence of general degeneracy.']
speaker: Brenda'S Solicitor

quoteText: I see, Yes, that all seems quite clear.
subQuotationList: ['I see,', 'Yes, that all seems quite clear.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: This whole business of Brenda is _very_ unfortunate,
subQuotationList: ['This whole business of Brenda is _very_ unfortunate,']
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
My mother is extremely upset about it, naturally. I'm upset myself. I
don't mind admitting, perfectly frankly, that I think she has behaved
very foolishly, foolishly and wrongly. I can quite understand your being
upset about it too.
subQuotationList:
["My mother is extremely upset about it, naturally. I'm upset myself. I
don't mind admitting, perfectly frankly, that I think she has behaved
very foolishly, foolishly and wrongly. I can quite understand your being
upset about it too."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: Yes,
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
But all the same, making every allowance for your feelings, I do think
that you are behaving rather vindictively in the matter.
subQuotationList: ['But all the same, making every allowance for your feelings, I do think\nthat you are behaving rather vindictively in the matter.']
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: I'm doing exactly what Brenda wanted.
subQuotationList: ["I'm doing exactly what Brenda wanted."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
My dear fellow, she doesn't know what she wants. I saw this chap Beaver
yesterday. I didn't like him _at all_. Do you?
subQuotationList: ["My dear fellow, she doesn't know what she wants. I saw this chap Beaver\nyesterday. I didn't like him _at all_. Do you?"]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: I hardly know him.
subQuotationList: ['I hardly know him.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, I can assure you I didn't like him. Now you're just throwing
Brenda into his arms. That's what it amounts to, as I see it, and I call
it vindictive. Of course, at the moment Brenda's got the idea that she's
in love with him. But it won't last. It couldn't with a chap like
Beaver. She'll want to come back in a year, just you see. Allan says the
same.
subQuotationList:
["Well, I can assure you I didn't like him. Now you're just throwing
Brenda into his arms. That's what it amounts to, as I see it, and I call
it vindictive. Of course, at the moment Brenda's got the idea that she's
in love with him. But it won't last. It couldn't with a chap like
Beaver. She'll want to come back in a year, just you see. Allan says the
same."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Allan']]]

quoteText: I've told Allan. I don't want her back.
subQuotationList: ["I've told Allan. I don't want her back."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well, that's vindictive.
subQuotationList: ["Well, that's vindictive."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: No, I just couldn't feel the same about her again.
subQuotationList: ["No, I just couldn't feel the same about her again."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, why feel _the same_? One has to change as one gets older. Why,
ten years ago I couldn't be interested in anything later than the
Sumerian age and I assure you that now I find even the Christian era
full of significance.
subQuotationList:
["Well, why feel _the same_? One has to change as one gets older. Why,
ten years ago I couldn't be interested in anything later than the
Sumerian age and I assure you that now I find even the Christian era
full of significance."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
Almost every grave had them, mostly
referring to the circus factions, scratched on lead. They used to be
dropped in through a funnel. We had found forty-three up-to-date, before
this wretched business happened, and I had to come back. Naturally I'm
upset. Besides, you know, it isn't as though it was all
Brenda's fault.
subQuotationList:
['Almost every grave had them,', "mostly
referring to the circus factions, scratched on lead. They used to be
dropped in through a funnel. We had found forty-three up-to-date, before
this wretched business happened, and I had to come back. Naturally I'm
upset.", 'Besides, you know,', "it isn't as though it was all
Brenda's fault."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: I haven't been thinking particularly whose fault it is.
subQuotationList: ["I haven't been thinking particularly whose fault it is."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, that's all very well, but you seem rather to be taking the line
of the injured husband--saying you can't feel the same again, and all
that. I mean to say, it takes two to make a quarrel and I gather things
had been going wrong for some time. For instance, you'd been drinking a
lot--have some more burgundy, by the way.
subQuotationList:
["Well, that's all very well, but you seem rather to be taking the line
of the injured husband--saying you can't feel the same again, and all
that. I mean to say, it takes two to make a quarrel and I gather things
had been going wrong for some time. For instance, you'd been drinking a
lot--have some more burgundy, by the way."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: Did Brenda say that?
subQuotationList: ['Did Brenda say that?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes. And then you'd been going round a bit with other girls yourself.
There was some woman with a Moorish name you had to stay at Hetton while
Brenda was there. Well, that's a bit thick, you know. I'm all for people
going their own way, but if they do they can't blame others, if you see
what I mean.
subQuotationList:
["Yes. And then you'd been going round a bit with other girls yourself.
There was some woman with a Moorish name you had to stay at Hetton while
Brenda was there. Well, that's a bit thick, you know. I'm all for people
going their own way, but if they do they can't blame others, if you see
what I mean."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Jenny Abdul Akbar'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: Did Brenda say that?
subQuotationList: ['Did Brenda say that?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes. Don't think I'm trying to lecture you or anything, but all I feel
is that you haven't any right to be vindictive to Brenda, as things
are.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. Don't think I'm trying to lecture you or anything, but all I feel\nis that you haven't any right to be vindictive to Brenda, as things\nare."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
She said I drank and was having an affair with the woman with a Moorish
name?
subQuotationList: ['She said I drank and was having an affair with the woman with a Moorish\nname?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, I don't know she actually said that, but she said you'd been
getting tight lately and that you were certainly interested in that
girl.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I don't know she actually said that, but she said you'd been\ngetting tight lately and that you were certainly interested in that\ngirl."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
So that really explains what I want to say, It's about money. I understand that when Brenda was in a very agitated
state just after the death of her child, she consented to some verbal
arrangement with you about settlements.
subQuotationList: ['So that really explains what I want to say,', "It's about money. I understand that when Brenda was in a very agitated\nstate just after the death of her child, she consented to some verbal\narrangement with you about settlements."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: Yes, I'm allowing her five hundred a year.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I'm allowing her five hundred a year."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, you know, I don't think that you have any right to take advantage
of her generosity in that way. It was most imprudent of her to consider
your proposal--she admits now that she was not really herself when she
did so.
subQuotationList:
["Well, you know, I don't think that you have any right to take advantage
of her generosity in that way. It was most imprudent of her to consider
your proposal--she admits now that she was not really herself when she
did so."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: What does she suggest instead?
subQuotationList: ['What does she suggest instead?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Let's go outside and have coffee.
subQuotationList: ["Let's go outside and have coffee."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
Well, I've discussed it with the lawyers and with the
family and we decided that the sum should be increased to two thousand.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I've discussed it with the lawyers and with the\nfamily and we decided that the sum should be increased to two thousand."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: That's quite out of the question. I couldn't begin to afford it.
subQuotationList: ["That's quite out of the question. I couldn't begin to afford it."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, you know, I have to consider Brenda's interests. She has very
little of her own and there will be no more coming to her. My mother's
income is an allowance which I pay under my father's will. I shan't be
able to give her anything. I am trying to raise everything I can for an
expedition to one of the oases in the Libyan desert. This chap Beaver
has got practically nothing and doesn't look like earning any. So you
see--
subQuotationList:
["Well, you know, I have to consider Brenda's interests. She has very
little of her own and there will be no more coming to her. My mother's
income is an allowance which I pay under my father's will. I shan't be
able to give her anything. I am trying to raise everything I can for an
expedition to one of the oases in the Libyan desert. This chap Beaver
has got practically nothing and doesn't look like earning any. So you
see--"]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
But, my dear Reggie, you know as well as I do that it's out of the
question.
subQuotationList: ["But, my dear Reggie, you know as well as I do that it's out of the\nquestion."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's rather less than a third of your income.
subQuotationList: ["It's rather less than a third of your income."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
Yes, but almost every penny goes straight back to the estate. Do you
realize that Brenda and I together haven't spent half that amount a year
on our personal expenses? It's all I can do to keep things going as it
is.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, but almost every penny goes straight back to the estate. Do you
realize that Brenda and I together haven't spent half that amount a year
on our personal expenses? It's all I can do to keep things going as it
is."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I didn't expect you'd take this line, Tony. I think it's extremely
unreasonable of you. After all, it's absurd to pretend in these days
that a single man can't be perfectly comfortable on four thousand a
year. It's as much as I've ever had.
subQuotationList:
["I didn't expect you'd take this line, Tony. I think it's extremely
unreasonable of you. After all, it's absurd to pretend in these days
that a single man can't be perfectly comfortable on four thousand a
year. It's as much as I've ever had."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: It would mean giving up Hetton.
subQuotationList: ['It would mean giving up Hetton.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, I gave up Brakeleigh, and I assure you, my dear fellow, I never
regret it. It was a nasty wrench at the time, of course, old association
and everything like that, but I can tell you this, that when the sale
was finally through I felt a different man, free to go where I liked...
subQuotationList:
['Well, I gave up Brakeleigh, and I assure you, my dear fellow, I never
regret it. It was a nasty wrench at the time, of course, old association
and everything like that, but I can tell you this, that when the sale
was finally through I felt a different man, free to go where I liked...']
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: But I don't happen to want to go anywhere else except Hetton.
subQuotationList: ["But I don't happen to want to go anywhere else except Hetton."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
There's a lot in what these Labour fellows say, you know. Big houses
are a thing of the past in England.
subQuotationList: ["There's a lot in what these Labour fellows say, you know. Big houses\nare a thing of the past in England."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
Tell me, did Brenda realize when she agreed to this proposal that it
meant my leaving Hetton?
subQuotationList: ['Tell me, did Brenda realize when she agreed to this proposal that it\nmeant my leaving Hetton?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, it was mentioned, I think. I daresay you'll find it quite easy to
sell to a school or something like that. I remember the agent said when
I was trying to get rid of Brakeleigh that it was a pity it wasn't
Gothic, because schools and convents always go for Gothic. I daresay
you'll get a very comfortable price and find yourself better off in the
end than you are now.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, it was mentioned, I think. I daresay you'll find it quite easy to
sell to a school or something like that. I remember the agent said when
I was trying to get rid of Brakeleigh that it was a pity it wasn't
Gothic, because schools and convents always go for Gothic. I daresay
you'll get a very comfortable price and find yourself better off in the
end than you are now."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: No. It's impossible,
subQuotationList: ["No. It's impossible,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You're making things extremely awkward for everyone, I
can't understand why you are taking up this attitude.
subQuotationList: ["You're making things extremely awkward for everyone,", "I\ncan't understand why you are taking up this attitude."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
What is more, I don't believe that Brenda ever expected or wanted me to
agree.
subQuotationList: ["What is more, I don't believe that Brenda ever expected or wanted me to\nagree."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh yes, she did, my dear fellow. I assure you of that.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, she did, my dear fellow. I assure you of that.']
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: It's inconceivable.
subQuotationList: ["It's inconceivable."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, there's more to it than just
money. Perhaps I'd better tell you everything. I hadn't meant to. The
truth is that Beaver is cutting up nasty. He says he can't marry Brenda
unless she's properly provided for. Not fair on her, he says. I quite
see his point in a way.
subQuotationList:
['Well,', "there's more to it than just
money. Perhaps I'd better tell you everything. I hadn't meant to. The
truth is that Beaver is cutting up nasty. He says he can't marry Brenda
unless she's properly provided for. Not fair on her, he says. I quite
see his point in a way."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Tony Last'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['John Beaver'], ['John Beaver']]]

quoteText:
Yes, I see his point, So what your proposal really amounts
to, is that I should give up Hetton in order to buy Beaver for Brenda.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I see his point,', 'So what your proposal really amounts\nto, is that I should give up Hetton in order to buy Beaver for Brenda.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's not how I should have put it,
subQuotationList: ["It's not how I should have put it,"]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
Well, I'm not going to and that's the end of it. If that's all you
wanted to say, I may as well leave you.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I'm not going to and that's the end of it. If that's all you\nwanted to say, I may as well leave you."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
No, it isn't quite all I wanted to say. In fact I think I must have put
things rather badly. It comes from trying to respect people's feelings
too much. You see, I wasn't so much asking you to agree to anything as
explaining what our side propose to do. I've tried to keep everything on
a friendly basis but I see it's not possible. Brenda will ask for
alimony of two thousand a year from the Court and on our evidence we
shall get it. I'm sorry you oblige me to put it so bluntly.
subQuotationList:
["No, it isn't quite all I wanted to say. In fact I think I must have put
things rather badly. It comes from trying to respect people's feelings
too much. You see, I wasn't so much asking you to agree to anything as
explaining what our side propose to do. I've tried to keep everything on
a friendly basis but I see it's not possible. Brenda will ask for
alimony of two thousand a year from the Court and on our evidence we
shall get it. I'm sorry you oblige me to put it so bluntly."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: I hadn't thought of that.
subQuotationList: ["I hadn't thought of that."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, nor had we, to be quite frank. It was Beaver's idea.
subQuotationList: ["No, nor had we, to be quite frank. It was Beaver's idea."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: You seem to have got me in a fairly hopeless position.
subQuotationList: ['You seem to have got me in a fairly hopeless position.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's not how I should have put it.
subQuotationList: ["It's not how I should have put it."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
I should like to make absolutely sure that Brenda is in on this. D'you
mind if I ring her up?
subQuotationList: ["I should like to make absolutely sure that Brenda is in on this. D'you\nmind if I ring her up?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Not at all, my dear fellow. I happen to know she's at Marjorie's
to-night.
subQuotationList: ["Not at all, my dear fellow. I happen to know she's at Marjorie's\nto-night."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: Brenda, this is Tony... I've just been dining with Reggie.
subQuotationList: ["Brenda, this is Tony... I've just been dining with Reggie."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, he said something about it.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, he said something about it.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: He tells me that you are going to sue for alimony. Is that so?
subQuotationList: ['He tells me that you are going to sue for alimony. Is that so?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Tony, don't be so bullying. The lawyers are doing everything. It's no
use coming to me.
subQuotationList: ["Tony, don't be so bullying. The lawyers are doing everything. It's no\nuse coming to me."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: But did you know that they proposed to ask for two thousand?
subQuotationList: ['But did you know that they proposed to ask for two thousand?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes. They did say that. I know it sounds a lot but...
subQuotationList: ['Yes. They did say that. I know it sounds a lot but...']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
And you know exactly how my money stands, don't you? You know it means
selling Hetton, don't you?... hullo, are you still there?
subQuotationList: ["And you know exactly how my money stands, don't you? You know it means\nselling Hetton, don't you?... hullo, are you still there?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, I'm here.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I'm here."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You know it means that?
subQuotationList: ['You know it means that?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Tony, don't make me feel a beast. Everything has been so difficult.
subQuotationList: ["Tony, don't make me feel a beast. Everything has been so difficult."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You do know just what you are asking?
subQuotationList: ['You do know just what you are asking?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes... I suppose so.
subQuotationList: ['Yes... I suppose so.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: All right, that's all I wanted to know.
subQuotationList: ["All right, that's all I wanted to know."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Tony, how odd you sound... don't ring off.
subQuotationList: ["Tony, how odd you sound... don't ring off."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well?
subQuotationList: ['Well?']
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
I got on to her. You were quite right. I'm sorry I didn't believe you.
It seemed so unlikely at first.
subQuotationList: ["I got on to her. You were quite right. I'm sorry I didn't believe you.\nIt seemed so unlikely at first."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's all right, my dear fellow.
subQuotationList: ["That's all right, my dear fellow."]
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: I've decided exactly what's going to happen.
subQuotationList: ["I've decided exactly what's going to happen."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Good.
subQuotationList: ['Good.']
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText:
Brenda is not going to get her divorce. The evidence I provided at
Brighton isn't worth anything. There happens to have been a child there
all the time. She slept both nights in the room I am supposed to have
occupied. If you care to bring the case I shall defend it and win, but I
think when you have seen my evidence you will drop it. I am going away
for six months or so. When I come back, if she wishes it, I shall
divorce Brenda without settlements of any kind. Is that clear?
subQuotationList:
["Brenda is not going to get her divorce. The evidence I provided at
Brighton isn't worth anything. There happens to have been a child there
all the time. She slept both nights in the room I am supposed to have
occupied. If you care to bring the case I shall defend it and win, but I
think when you have seen my evidence you will drop it. I am going away
for six months or so. When I come back, if she wishes it, I shall
divorce Brenda without settlements of any kind. Is that clear?"]
speaker: Tony Last
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Brenda'], ['Brenda'], ['Winnie'], ['Reggie St Cloud'], ['Reggie St Cloud'], ['Reggie St Cloud'], ['Brenda'], ['Brenda']]]

quoteText: But look here, my dear fellow.
subQuotationList: ['But look here, my dear fellow.']
speaker: Reggie St Cloud

quoteText: Good night. Thank you for the dinner. Good luck to the excavations.
subQuotationList: ['Good night. Thank you for the dinner. Good luck to the excavations.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Who on earth would have expected the old boy to turn up like that?
subQuotationList: ['Who on earth would have expected the old boy to turn up like that?']
speaker: Polly Cockpurse

quoteText:
Now I understand why they keep going on in the papers about divorce law
reform, It's _too_ monstrous that he should be allowed
to get away with it.
subQuotationList: ['Now I understand why they keep going on in the papers about divorce law\nreform,', "It's _too_ monstrous that he should be allowed\nto get away with it."]
speaker: Veronica

quoteText: The mistake they made was in telling him first,
subQuotationList: ['The mistake they made was in telling him first,']
speaker: Souki

quoteText: It's so like Brenda to trust everyone,
subQuotationList: ["It's so like Brenda to trust everyone,"]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: I do think Tony comes out of this pretty poorly,
subQuotationList: ['I do think Tony comes out of this pretty poorly,']
speaker: Marjorie

quoteText:
Oh, I don't know, I expect your ass of a brother put the
thing wrong.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I don't know,", 'I expect your ass of a brother put the\nthing wrong.']
speaker: Allan

quoteText: any idea how many times round the deck make a mile?
subQuotationList: ['any idea how many times round the deck make a mile?']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText:
None, I'm afraid, But I should think you must have walked
a great distance.
subQuotationList: ["None, I'm afraid,", 'But I should think you must have walked\na great distance.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Twenty-two times. One soon gets out of sorts at sea if you're used to
an active life. She's not much of a boat. Travel with this line often?
subQuotationList: ["Twenty-two times. One soon gets out of sorts at sea if you're used to\nan active life. She's not much of a boat. Travel with this line often?"]
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText: Never before.
subQuotationList: ['Never before.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Ah. Thought you might have been in business in the islands. Not many
tourists going out this time of year. Just the other way about. All
coming home, if you see what I mean. Going far?
subQuotationList: ['Ah. Thought you might have been in business in the islands. Not many\ntourists going out this time of year. Just the other way about. All\ncoming home, if you see what I mean. Going far?']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText: Demerara.
subQuotationList: ['Demerara.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Ah. Looking for minerals perhaps?
subQuotationList: ['Ah. Looking for minerals perhaps?']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText: No, to tell you the truth I am looking for a city.
subQuotationList: ['No, to tell you the truth I am looking for a city.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Sounded just like
you said you were looking for a city.
subQuotationList: ['Sounded just like\nyou said you were looking for a city.']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That _was_ what you said?
subQuotationList: ['That _was_ what you said?']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I thought it sounded like that... well, so long. I must do another few
rounds before dinner.
subQuotationList: ['I thought it sounded like that... well, so long. I must do another few\nrounds before dinner.']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText: Hullo Bit choppy Here we are again
subQuotationList: ['Hullo', 'Bit choppy', 'Here we are again']
speaker: The Genial Passenger
referringExpression: the man had taken to nodding then to saying

quoteText:
I'm afraid our table is not showing
up very well to-night, I see you are not a sufferer. My wife
is in her cabin. _She_ is a sufferer.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid our table is not showing\nup very well to-night,", 'I see you are not a sufferer. My wife\nis in her cabin. _She_ is a sufferer.']
speaker: The Coloured Archdeacon

quoteText:
It's not much of a boat, But I expect things will look brighter when we get into
the sun. That's all right, we're just
going down to the bar. You know, I feel I
owe you an apology. I thought you were potty just now before dinner.
Honestly I did, when you said you were going to Demerara to look for a
city. Well, it sounded pretty potty. Then the purser--I'm at his table.
Always get the cheeriest crowd at the purser's table _and_ the best
attention--the purser told me about you. You're the explorer, aren't
you?
subQuotationList:
["It's not much of a boat,", 'But I expect things will look brighter when we get into
the sun.', "That's all right,", "we're just
going down to the bar. You know,", "I feel I
owe you an apology. I thought you were potty just now before dinner.
Honestly I did, when you said you were going to Demerara to look for a
city. Well, it sounded pretty potty. Then the purser--I'm at his table.
Always get the cheeriest crowd at the purser's table _and_ the best
attention--the purser told me about you. You're the explorer, aren't
you?"]
speaker: The Genial Passenger
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['The Genial Passenger', 'Tony Last']], [], [['The Genial Passenger', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']], [['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: Yes, come to think of it, I suppose I am,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, come to think of it, I suppose I am,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: trade goods
subQuotationList: ['trade goods']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I am going away shortly, to Brazil. At least it
may be Brazil or Dutch Guiana. One cannot tell. The frontier has never
been demarcated. I ought to have started last week, only my plans were
upset. Do you by any chance know a Nicaraguan calling himself
alternately Ponsonby and FitzClarence?
subQuotationList:
['I am going away shortly,', 'to Brazil. At least it
may be Brazil or Dutch Guiana. One cannot tell. The frontier has never
been demarcated. I ought to have started last week, only my plans were
upset. Do you by any chance know a Nicaraguan calling himself
alternately Ponsonby and FitzClarence?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, I don't think I do.
subQuotationList: ["No, I don't think I do."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You are fortunate. That man has just robbed me of two hundred pounds
and some machine guns.
subQuotationList: ['You are fortunate. That man has just robbed me of two hundred pounds\nand some machine guns.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Machine guns?
subQuotationList: ['Machine guns?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, I travel with one or two, mostly for show, you know, or for trade,
and they are not easy to buy nowadays. Have you ever tried?
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I travel with one or two, mostly for show, you know, or for trade,\nand they are not easy to buy nowadays. Have you ever tried?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well you can take it from me that it's not easy. You can't just walk
into a shop and order machine guns.
subQuotationList: ["Well you can take it from me that it's not easy. You can't just walk\ninto a shop and order machine guns."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, I suppose not.
subQuotationList: ['No, I suppose not.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Still, at a pinch I can do without them. But I can't do without two
hundred pounds.
subQuotationList: ["Still, at a pinch I can do without them. But I can't do without two\nhundred pounds."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Ah yes, interesting little place. I expect you know Zingermaun there?
subQuotationList: ['Ah yes,', 'interesting little place. I expect you know Zingermaun there?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, I've not been there yet.
subQuotationList: ["No, I've not been there yet."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You'd like him--a very straight fellow. He used to do quite a lot,
selling ammunition to the Atlas caids before the pacification. Of course
it was easy money with the capitulations, but he did it better than most
of them. I believe he's running a restaurant now in Mogador. The pity is I can't let the R.G.S. in on this
expedition. I've got to find the money privately.
subQuotationList:
["You'd like him--a very straight fellow. He used to do quite a lot,
selling ammunition to the Atlas caids before the pacification. Of course
it was easy money with the capitulations, but he did it better than most
of them. I believe he's running a restaurant now in Mogador.", "The pity is I can't let the R.G.S. in on this
expedition. I've got to find the money privately."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: We'd better go up and lunch,
subQuotationList: ["We'd better go up and lunch,"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I have to be very
careful what I eat,
subQuotationList: ['I have to be very\ncareful what I eat,']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
...You see, there has been a continuous tradition about the City since
the first explorers of the sixteenth century. It has been variously
allocated, sometimes down in Matto Grosso, sometimes on the upper
Orinoco in what is now Venezuela. I myself used to think it lay
somewhere on the Uraricuera. I was out there last year and it was then
that I established contact with the Pie-wie Indians; no white man had
ever visited them and got out alive. And it was from the Pie-wies that I
learned where to look. None of them had ever visited the City, of
course, but they _knew about it_. Every Indian between Ciudad Bolivar
and Para knows about it. But they won't talk. Queer people. But I became
blood-brother with a Pie-wie--interesting ceremony. They buried me up to
the neck in mud and all the women of the tribe spat on my head. Then we
ate a toad and snake and a beetle and after that I was
blood-brother--well, he told me that the City lies between the head
waters of the Courantyne and the Takutu. There's a vast track of
unexplored country there. I've often thought of visiting it.
subQuotationList:
["...You see, there has been a continuous tradition about the City since
the first explorers of the sixteenth century. It has been variously
allocated, sometimes down in Matto Grosso, sometimes on the upper
Orinoco in what is now Venezuela. I myself used to think it lay
somewhere on the Uraricuera. I was out there last year and it was then
that I established contact with the Pie-wie Indians; no white man had
ever visited them and got out alive. And it was from the Pie-wies that I
learned where to look. None of them had ever visited the City, of
course, but they _knew about it_. Every Indian between Ciudad Bolivar
and Para knows about it. But they won't talk. Queer people. But I became
blood-brother with a Pie-wie--interesting ceremony. They buried me up to
the neck in mud and all the women of the tribe spat on my head. Then we
ate a toad and snake and a beetle and after that I was
blood-brother--well, he told me that the City lies between the head
waters of the Courantyne and the Takutu. There's a vast track of
unexplored country there. I've often thought of visiting it."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I've been looking up the historical side too, and I more or less know
how the City got there. It was the result of a migration from Peru at
the beginning of the fifteenth century, when the Incas were at the
height of their power. It is mentioned in all the early Spanish
documents as a popular legend. One of the younger princes rebelled and
led his people off into the forest. Most of the tribes had a tradition
in one form or another of a strange race passing through their
territory.
subQuotationList:
["I've been looking up the historical side too, and I more or less know
how the City got there. It was the result of a migration from Peru at
the beginning of the fifteenth century, when the Incas were at the
height of their power. It is mentioned in all the early Spanish
documents as a popular legend. One of the younger princes rebelled and
led his people off into the forest. Most of the tribes had a tradition
in one form or another of a strange race passing through their
territory."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: But what do you suppose this city will be like?
subQuotationList: ['But what do you suppose this city will be like?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Impossible to say. Every tribe has a different word for it. The
Pie-wies call it the 'Shining' or 'Glittering', the Arekuna the 'Many
Watered', the Patamonas the 'Bright Feathered', the Warau, oddly enough,
use the same word for it that they use for a kind of aromatic jam they
make. Of course, one can't tell how a civilization may have developed or
degenerated in five hundred years of isolation...
subQuotationList:
["Impossible to say. Every tribe has a different word for it. The
Pie-wies call it the 'Shining' or 'Glittering', the Arekuna the 'Many
Watered', the Patamonas the 'Bright Feathered', the Warau, oddly enough,
use the same word for it that they use for a kind of aromatic jam they
make. Of course, one can't tell how a civilization may have developed or
degenerated in five hundred years of isolation..."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Done much of that kind of thing?
subQuotationList: ['Done much of that kind of thing?']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText: No, to tell you the truth it is the first time.
subQuotationList: ['No, to tell you the truth it is the first time.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Ah. Well, I daresay it's more interesting than it sounds, else people wouldn't do it so much.
subQuotationList: ["Ah. Well, I daresay it's more interesting than it sounds,", "else people wouldn't do it so much."]
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText:
I wonder if anyone is doing anything about those dogs, I'll ask the purser to-morrow. We
might exercise them a bit. Kind of mournful the way they go on.
subQuotationList: ['I wonder if anyone is doing anything about those dogs,', "I'll ask the purser to-morrow. We\nmight exercise them a bit. Kind of mournful the way they go on."]
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText:
Been talking to the wireless operator, We ought to pass
quite near the Yarmouth Castle at about eleven.
subQuotationList: ['Been talking to the wireless operator,', 'We ought to pass\nquite near the Yarmouth Castle at about eleven.']
speaker: The Genial Passenger

quoteText:
Look, Ernie, come quick,
there's a shark.
subQuotationList: ["Look, Ernie, come quick,\nthere's a shark."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: That's not a shark, it's a dolphin.
subQuotationList: ["That's not a shark, it's a dolphin."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
Mr Brink said
it was a porpoise.
subQuotationList: ['Mr Brink said\nit was a porpoise.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: There he is again. Oh, if I had my camera.
subQuotationList: ['There he is again. Oh, if I had my camera.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
The last days
have been terrible. I saw you walking about. How I envied you.
subQuotationList: ['The last days\nhave been terrible. I saw you walking about. How I envied you.']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: It ought to be calm all the way now,
subQuotationList: ['It ought to be calm all the way now,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Are you going
far?
subQuotationList: ['Are you going\nfar?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Trinidad. That is my home... I tried to decide who you were from the
passenger list.
subQuotationList: ['Trinidad. That is my home... I tried to decide who you were from the\npassenger list.']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: Who was I?
subQuotationList: ['Who was I?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Well... someone called Colonel Strapper.
subQuotationList: ['Well... someone called Colonel Strapper.']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: Do I look so old?
subQuotationList: ['Do I look so old?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Are colonels old? I didn't know. It's not a thing we have much in
Trinidad. Now I know who you are because I asked the head steward. Do
tell me about your exploring.
subQuotationList: ["Are colonels old? I didn't know. It's not a thing we have much in\nTrinidad. Now I know who you are because I asked the head steward. Do\ntell me about your exploring."]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: You'd better ask Doctor Messinger. He knows more about it than I do.
subQuotationList: ["You'd better ask Doctor Messinger. He knows more about it than I do."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, _you_ tell me.
subQuotationList: ['No, _you_ tell me.']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
...Some of us used to keep lipstick and rouge secretly in our bedrooms
and try it on at night. One girl called Antoinette came to Mass on
Sunday wearing it. There was a terrible row with Madame de Supplice and
she left after that term. It was awfully brave. We all envied her...
But she was an ugly girl, always eating chocolates...
subQuotationList:
['...Some of us used to keep lipstick and rouge secretly in our bedrooms
and try it on at night. One girl called Antoinette came to Mass on
Sunday wearing it. There was a terrible row with Madame de Supplice and
she left after that term. It was awfully brave. We all envied her...
But she was an ugly girl, always eating chocolates...']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
...Now I am coming home to be married... No, I am not yet engaged,
but you see there are so few young men I can marry. They must be
Catholic and of an island family. It would not do to marry an official
and go back to live in England. But it will be easy because I have no
brothers or sisters and my father has one of the best houses in
Trinidad. You must come and see it. It is a stone house, outside the
town. My family came to Trinidad in the French Revolution. There are two
or three other rich families and I shall marry into one of them. Our son
will have the house. It will be easy...
subQuotationList:
['...Now I am coming home to be married... No, I am not yet engaged,
but you see there are so few young men I can marry. They must be
Catholic and of an island family. It would not do to marry an official
and go back to live in England. But it will be easy because I have no
brothers or sisters and my father has one of the best houses in
Trinidad. You must come and see it. It is a stone house, outside the
town. My family came to Trinidad in the French Revolution. There are two
or three other rich families and I shall marry into one of them. Our son
will have the house. It will be easy...']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
...There was an American girl at
Madame de Supplice's who was engaged. She had a ring with a big diamond
but she could never wear it except in bed. Then one day she had a letter
from her young man saying he was going to marry another girl. How she
cried. We all read the letter and most of us cried too... But in
Trinidad it will be quite easy.
subQuotationList:
["...There was an American girl at
Madame de Supplice's who was engaged. She had a ring with a big diamond
but she could never wear it except in bed. Then one day she had a letter
from her young man saying he was going to marry another girl. How she
cried. We all read the letter and most of us cried too... But in
Trinidad it will be quite easy."]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
But of course, there may be nothing in it. It
ought to be an interesting journey in any case.
subQuotationList: ['But of course,', 'there may be nothing in it. It\nought to be an interesting journey in any case.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: How I wish I was a man,
subQuotationList: ['How I wish I was a man,']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
We'll go in a small boat, so as to escape all that hideous nonsense of
deck games.
subQuotationList: ["We'll go in a small boat,", 'so as to escape all that hideous nonsense of\ndeck games.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
How funny, that was the
name of the man who didn't marry the American girl at Madame de
Supplice's
subQuotationList: ['How funny,', "that was the\nname of the man who didn't marry the American girl at Madame de\nSupplice's"]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
I can't believe this is the same ship as in those cold, rough days, You must come to my home and see what real creole cooking is like, We have a lot of old recipes that the planters used to
use. You must meet my father and mother.
subQuotationList: ["I can't believe this is the same ship as in those cold, rough days,", 'You must come to my home and see what real creole cooking is like,', 'We have a lot of old recipes that the planters used to\nuse. You must meet my father and mother.']
speaker: Therese De Vitre
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Tony Last']], [['Therese De Vitre'], ['Tony Last'], ["Thrse De Vitr'S Father"]]]

quoteText: Trinidad the day after to-morrow,
subQuotationList: ['Trinidad the day after to-morrow,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I don't like Doctor Messinger at all, Not anything about
him.
subQuotationList: ["I don't like Doctor Messinger at all,", 'Not anything about\nhim.']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: And you will have to choose your husband.
subQuotationList: ['And you will have to choose your husband.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes. There are seven of them. There was one called Honor? I liked, but
of course I haven't seen him for two years. He was studying to be an
engineer. There's one called Mendoza who's very rich but he isn't really
a Trinidadian. His grandfather came from Dominica and they say he has
coloured blood. I expect it will be Honor?. Mother always brought in his
name when she wrote to me and he sent me things at Christmas and on my
f?te. Rather silly things, because the shops aren't good in Port of
Spain.
subQuotationList:
["Yes. There are seven of them. There was one called Honor? I liked, but
of course I haven't seen him for two years. He was studying to be an
engineer. There's one called Mendoza who's very rich but he isn't really
a Trinidadian. His grandfather came from Dominica and they say he has
coloured blood. I expect it will be Honor?. Mother always brought in his
name when she wrote to me and he sent me things at Christmas and on my
f?te. Rather silly things, because the shops aren't good in Port of
Spain."]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
You'll be coming back by Trinidad, won't you? So I
shall see you then. Will you be a long time in the bush?
subQuotationList: ["You'll be coming back by Trinidad, won't you? So I\nshall see you then. Will you be a long time in the bush?"]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: I expect you'll be married by then.
subQuotationList: ["I expect you'll be married by then."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Tony, why haven't you ever got married?
subQuotationList: ["Tony, why haven't you ever got married?"]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: But I am.
subQuotationList: ['But I am.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Married?
subQuotationList: ['Married?']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You're teasing me.
subQuotationList: ["You're teasing me."]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: No, honestly I am. At least I was.
subQuotationList: ['No, honestly I am. At least I was.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh.
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: Are you surprised?
subQuotationList: ['Are you surprised?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I don't know. Somehow I didn't think you were. Where is she?
subQuotationList: ["I don't know. Somehow I didn't think you were. Where is she?"]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: In England. We had a row.
subQuotationList: ['In England. We had a row.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh... What's the time?
subQuotationList: ["Oh... What's the time?"]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: Quite early.
subQuotationList: ['Quite early.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Let's go back.
subQuotationList: ["Let's go back."]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: D'you want to?
subQuotationList: ["D'you want to?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, please. It's been a delightful day.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, please. It's been a delightful day."]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: You said that as if you were saying good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['You said that as if you were saying good-bye.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Did I? I don't know.
subQuotationList: ["Did I? I don't know."]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: It doesn't matter,
subQuotationList: ["It doesn't matter,"]
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText: He was someone on the ship,
subQuotationList: ['He was someone on the ship,']
speaker: Therese De Vitre

quoteText:
Reserved lot, these
real old creoles, Poor as church mice most
of them, but stinking proud. Time and again I've palled up with them on
board and when we got to port it's been good-bye. Do they ever so much
as ask you to their houses? Not they.
subQuotationList:
['Reserved lot, these
real old creoles,', "Poor as church mice most
of them, but stinking proud. Time and again I've palled up with them on
board and when we got to port it's been good-bye. Do they ever so much
as ask you to their houses? Not they."]
speaker: The Genial Passenger
referringExpression: remarked the passenger who had first made friends with Tony

quoteText: Oh, for God's sake.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, for God's sake."]
speaker: Dr Messinger
referringExpression: Dr Messinger turned over and said

quoteText:
Oh, for God's
sake,
subQuotationList: ["Oh, for God's\nsake,"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
A vampire bat got it. I must have gone to sleep with my foot against
the netting. God knows how long he had been at it, before I woke up.
That lamp ought to keep them off but it doesn't seem to.
subQuotationList: ["A vampire bat got it. I must have gone to sleep with my foot against\nthe netting. God knows how long he had been at it, before I woke up.\nThat lamp ought to keep them off but it doesn't seem to."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Vampires
plenty bad this side, Chief, Dat for why us no leave de
fire.
subQuotationList: ['Vampires\nplenty bad this side, Chief,', 'Dat for why us no leave de\nfire.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
It's just the way to get sick, blast it, I may
have lost pints of blood.
subQuotationList: ["It's just the way to get sick, blast it,", 'I may\nhave lost pints of blood.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
How I hate staying up late, but it seems a shame to take
my Mr Beaver away. He's so thrilled to be here, bless him, and it was a
great effort to get him asked... Come to think of it, I suppose that this is the last year _I_ shall be able to go to this
kind of party.
subQuotationList:
['How I hate staying up late,', "but it seems a shame to take
my Mr Beaver away. He's so thrilled to be here, bless him, and it was a
great effort to get him asked... Come to think of it,", 'I suppose that this is the last year _I_ shall be able to go to this
kind of party.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: You're going through with the divorce?
subQuotationList: ["You're going through with the divorce?"]
speaker: Jock

quoteText:
I don't know, Jock. It doesn't really depend on me. It's all a matter
of holding down Mr Beaver. He's getting very restive. I have to feed him
a bit of high-life every week or so, and I suppose that'll all stop if
there's a divorce. Any news of Tony?
subQuotationList:
["I don't know, Jock. It doesn't really depend on me. It's all a matter
of holding down Mr Beaver. He's getting very restive. I have to feed him
a bit of high-life every week or so, and I suppose that'll all stop if
there's a divorce. Any news of Tony?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Not for some time now. I got a cable when he landed. He's gone off on
some expedition with a crook doctor.
subQuotationList: ["Not for some time now. I got a cable when he landed. He's gone off on\nsome expedition with a crook doctor."]
speaker: Jock

quoteText: Is it _absolutely_ safe?
subQuotationList: ['Is it _absolutely_ safe?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Oh, I imagine so. The whole world is civilized now, isn't
it--charabancs and Cook's offices everywhere.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I imagine so. The whole world is civilized now, isn't\nit--charabancs and Cook's offices everywhere."]
speaker: Jock

quoteText:
Yes, I suppose it is... I hope he's not _brooding_. I shouldn't like
to think of him being unhappy.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I suppose it is... I hope he's not _brooding_. I shouldn't like\nto think of him being unhappy."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I expect he's getting used to things.
subQuotationList: ["I expect he's getting used to things."]
speaker: Jock

quoteText:
I do hope so. I'm very fond of Tony, you know, in spite of the
monstrous way he behaved.
subQuotationList: ["I do hope so. I'm very fond of Tony, you know, in spite of the\nmonstrous way he behaved."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Dey people all afeared,
subQuotationList: ['Dey people all afeared,']
speaker: The Black Boy

quoteText: Go and find someone to speak to us,
subQuotationList: ['Go and find someone to speak to us,']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Dere ain't no one but women dere, Dey dressing
deirselves. Come on out dere, De chief want
talk to you.
subQuotationList: ["Dere ain't no one but women dere,", 'Dey dressing\ndeirselves. Come on out dere,', 'De chief want\ntalk to you.']
speaker: The Black Boy

quoteText: Gassiri, the local drink made of fermented cassava.
subQuotationList: ['Gassiri,', 'the local drink made of fermented cassava.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
It is made in an interesting way. The women chew the root up and spit
it into a hollow tree-trunk.
subQuotationList: ['It is made in an interesting way. The women chew the root up and spit\nit into a hollow tree-trunk.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Good morning, How do you do? I am Rosa. I speak English
good. I live bottom-side two years with Mr Forbes. You give me
cigarette.
subQuotationList: ['Good morning,', 'How do you do? I am Rosa. I speak English\ngood. I live bottom-side two years with Mr Forbes. You give me\ncigarette.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: Why doesn't this woman answer?
subQuotationList: ["Why doesn't this woman answer?"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: She no speak English.
subQuotationList: ['She no speak English.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: But I was speaking Wapishiana.
subQuotationList: ['But I was speaking Wapishiana.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: She Macushi woman. All these people Macushi people.
subQuotationList: ['She Macushi woman. All these people Macushi people.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: Oh. I didn't know. Where are the men?
subQuotationList: ["Oh. I didn't know. Where are the men?"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Men all go hunting three days.
subQuotationList: ['Men all go hunting three days.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: When will they be back?
subQuotationList: ['When will they be back?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: They go after bush-pig.
subQuotationList: ['They go after bush-pig.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: When will they be back?
subQuotationList: ['When will they be back?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
No, bush-pig. Plenty bush-pig. Men all go hunting. You give me
cigarette.
subQuotationList: ['No, bush-pig. Plenty bush-pig. Men all go hunting. You give me\ncigarette.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: Listen, Rosa, I want to go to the Pie-wie country.
subQuotationList: ['Listen, Rosa, I want to go to the Pie-wie country.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, this Macushi. All the people Macushi.
subQuotationList: ['No, this Macushi. All the people Macushi.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: But we want to go Pie-wie.
subQuotationList: ['But we want to go Pie-wie.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, _all_ Macushi. You give me cigarette.
subQuotationList: ['No, _all_ Macushi. You give me cigarette.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: It's hopeless,
subQuotationList: ["It's hopeless,"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
We shall have to wait till the men
come back.
subQuotationList: ['We shall have to wait till the men\ncome back.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Look, cigarettes.
subQuotationList: ['Look,', 'cigarettes.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Give me.
subQuotationList: ['Give me.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
When men come back from hunting you come to river and tell me.
Understand?
subQuotationList: ['When men come back from hunting you come to river and tell me.\nUnderstand?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, men hunting bush-pig. You give me cigarettes.
subQuotationList: ['No, men hunting bush-pig. You give me cigarettes.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: What else you got? Give me,
subQuotationList: ['What else you got?', 'Give me,']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
When men come back, I give you plenty things if men come with me to
Pie-wies.
subQuotationList: ['When men come back, I give you plenty things if men come with me to\nPie-wies.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, _all_ Macushi here.
subQuotationList: ['No, _all_ Macushi here.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
We aren't doing any good, We'd better go back to
camp and wait. The men have been away three days. It's not likely they
will be much longer... I wish I could speak Macushi.
subQuotationList: ["We aren't doing any good,", "We'd better go back to\ncamp and wait. The men have been away three days. It's not likely they\nwill be much longer... I wish I could speak Macushi."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Number twenty,
subQuotationList: ['Number twenty,']
speaker: Jock

quoteText:
The matter is
receiving the closest attention. As the honourable member is no doubt
aware, the question of the importation of pork pies is a matter for the
Board of Trade, not for the Board of Agriculture. With regard to the
specifications of the basic pig, I must remind the honourable member
that, as he is doubtless aware, the eight-and-a-half-score pig is
modelled on the requirements of the bacon curers and has no direct
relation to pig meat for sale in pies. That is being dealt with by a
separate committee who have not yet made their report.
subQuotationList:
['The matter is
receiving the closest attention. As the honourable member is no doubt
aware, the question of the importation of pork pies is a matter for the
Board of Trade, not for the Board of Agriculture. With regard to the
specifications of the basic pig, I must remind the honourable member
that, as he is doubtless aware, the eight-and-a-half-score pig is
modelled on the requirements of the bacon curers and has no direct
relation to pig meat for sale in pies. That is being dealt with by a
separate committee who have not yet made their report.']
speaker: The Under-Secretary

quoteText:
Would the honourable member consider an increase of the specified
maximum of fatness on the shoulders?
subQuotationList: ['Would the honourable member consider an increase of the specified\nmaximum of fatness on the shoulders?']
speaker: Jock

quoteText: I must have notice of that question.
subQuotationList: ['I must have notice of that question.']
speaker: The Under-Secretary

quoteText: It will take them a week to get sober,
subQuotationList: ['It will take them a week to get sober,']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Give me cigarettes,
subQuotationList: ['Give me cigarettes,']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: You tell them I want men to go Pie-wie country,
subQuotationList: ['You tell them I want men to go Pie-wie country,']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Pie-wie bad people. Macushi people no go with Pie-wie people.
subQuotationList: ['Pie-wie bad people. Macushi people no go with Pie-wie people.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: You say I want ten men. I give them guns.
subQuotationList: ['You say I want ten men. I give them guns.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: You give me cigarettes...
subQuotationList: ['You give me cigarettes...']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
There's no one to touch it. We can send back for it in case of
emergency from the Pie-wie country, From now onwards the map is valueless to us,
subQuotationList: ["There's no one to touch it. We can send back for it in case of\nemergency from the Pie-wie country,", 'From now onwards the map is valueless to us,']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Mummy, Brenda wants a job.
subQuotationList: ['Mummy, Brenda wants a job.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Why?
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText:
Just like everybody else, short of money and nothing to do. She
wondered if she could be any use to you at the shop.
subQuotationList: ['Just like everybody else, short of money and nothing to do. She\nwondered if she could be any use to you at the shop.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Well... It's hard to say. At any other time she is exactly the kind of
saleswoman I am always looking for... but I don't know. _As things
are_, I'm not sure it would be wise.
subQuotationList: ["Well... It's hard to say. At any other time she is exactly the kind of\nsaleswoman I am always looking for... but I don't know. _As things\nare_, I'm not sure it would be wise."]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: I said I'd ask you, that's all.
subQuotationList: ["I said I'd ask you, that's all."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
John, you never tell me _anything_ and I don't like to seem
interfering; but what _is_ going to happen between you and Brenda?
subQuotationList: ["John, you never tell me _anything_ and I don't like to seem\ninterfering; but what _is_ going to happen between you and Brenda?"]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: I don't know.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
You never tell me _anything_, And there are so
many rumours going round. Is there going to be a divorce?
subQuotationList: ['You never tell me _anything_,', 'And there are so\nmany rumours going round. Is there going to be a divorce?']
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: I don't know.
subQuotationList: ["I don't know."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Well, I must get back to work. Where are you
lunching?
subQuotationList: ['Well, I must get back to work. Where are you\nlunching?']
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: Bratt's.
subQuotationList: ["Bratt's."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Poor John. By the way, I thought you were joining Brown's.
subQuotationList: ["Poor John. By the way, I thought you were joining Brown's."]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText:
I haven't heard anything from them. I don't know whether they've had an
election yet.
subQuotationList: ["I haven't heard anything from them. I don't know whether they've had an\nelection yet."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Your father was a member.
subQuotationList: ['Your father was a member.']
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: I've an idea I shan't get in... anyway I couldn't really afford it.
subQuotationList: ["I've an idea I shan't get in... anyway I couldn't really afford it."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I'm not happy about you, John. I'm not sure that things are working out
as well as I hoped about Christmas-time.
subQuotationList: ["I'm not happy about you, John. I'm not sure that things are working out\nas well as I hoped about Christmas-time."]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText:
There's my telephone. Perhaps it's Margot. She hasn't asked me to
anything for weeks.
subQuotationList: ["There's my telephone. Perhaps it's Margot. She hasn't asked me to\nanything for weeks."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I'm afraid mother's got nothing for you at the shop,
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid mother's got nothing for you at the shop,"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Oh well. I expect something will turn up. I could do with a little good
luck just at the moment.
subQuotationList: ['Oh well. I expect something will turn up. I could do with a little good\nluck just at the moment.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: So could I. Have you asked Allan about Brown's?
subQuotationList: ["So could I. Have you asked Allan about Brown's?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes, I did. He says they elected about ten chaps last week.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I did. He says they elected about ten chaps last week.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Oh, does that mean I've been blackballed?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, does that mean I've been blackballed?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I shouldn't know. Gentlemen are so odd about their clubs.
subQuotationList: ["I shouldn't know. Gentlemen are so odd about their clubs."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I thought that you were going to make Allan and Reggie support me.
subQuotationList: ['I thought that you were going to make Allan and Reggie support me.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
I asked them. What does it matter anyway? D'you want to come to
Veronica's for the week-end?
subQuotationList: ["I asked them. What does it matter anyway? D'you want to come to\nVeronica's for the week-end?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm not sure that I do.
subQuotationList: ["I'm not sure that I do."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: _I'd_ like it.
subQuotationList: ["_I'd_ like it."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
It's a beastly little house--and I don't think Veronica likes me.
Who'll be there?
subQuotationList: ["It's a beastly little house--and I don't think Veronica likes me.\nWho'll be there?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I shall be.
subQuotationList: ['I shall be.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Yes... well, I'll let you know.
subQuotationList: ["Yes... well, I'll let you know."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Am I seeing you this evening?
subQuotationList: ['Am I seeing you this evening?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'll let you know.
subQuotationList: ["I'll let you know."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
Oh dear, Now he's taken against me. It
isn't my fault he can't get into Brown's. As a matter of fact I believe
Reggie _did_ try to help.
subQuotationList: ['Oh dear,', "Now he's taken against me. It\nisn't my fault he can't get into Brown's. As a matter of fact I believe\nReggie _did_ try to help."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Let's go and have a cosy lunch at the Ritz,
subQuotationList: ["Let's go and have a cosy lunch at the Ritz,"]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
The Ritz isn't cosy at lunch-time and it costs eight and six. I daren't
cash a cheque for three weeks, Jenny. The lawyers are so disagreeable.
I've never been like this before.
subQuotationList: ["The Ritz isn't cosy at lunch-time and it costs eight and six. I daren't\ncash a cheque for three weeks, Jenny. The lawyers are so disagreeable.\nI've never been like this before."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: What wouldn't I do to Tony? Leaving you stranded like this.
subQuotationList: ["What wouldn't I do to Tony? Leaving you stranded like this."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText:
Oh, what's the good of knocking Tony? I don't suppose he's having a
packet of fun himself in Brazil or wherever it is.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, what's the good of knocking Tony? I don't suppose he's having a\npacket of fun himself in Brazil or wherever it is."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I hear they are putting in bathrooms at Hetton--while you are
practically starving. And he hasn't even gone to Mrs Beaver for them.
subQuotationList: ["I hear they are putting in bathrooms at Hetton--while you are\npractically starving. And he hasn't even gone to Mrs Beaver for them."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: Yes, I _do_ think that was mean.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I _do_ think that was mean.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I got Polly and Souki, We're going to Daisy's joint. I _wish_ you were coming.
subQuotationList: ['I got Polly and Souki,', "We're going to Daisy's joint. I _wish_ you were coming."]
speaker: Jenny Abdul Akbar

quoteText: Me? Oh, I'm all right,
subQuotationList: ["Me? Oh, I'm all right,"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: We are now in the Amazon system of rivers, You see, the water is running south.
subQuotationList: ['We are now in the Amazon system of rivers,', 'You see, the water is running south.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Very curious, A discovery of genuine scientific
value.
subQuotationList: ['Very curious,', 'A discovery of genuine scientific\nvalue.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Is there a name for any of these streams?
subQuotationList: ['Is there a name for any of these streams?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Macushi people called him Waurupang.
subQuotationList: ['Macushi people called him Waurupang.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: No, not the river where we first camped. _These rivers._
subQuotationList: ['No, not the river where we first camped. _These rivers._']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Yes, Waurupang.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, Waurupang.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: _This river here._
subQuotationList: ['_This river here._']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Macushi people call him all Waurupang.
subQuotationList: ['Macushi people call him all Waurupang.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: It's hopeless,
subQuotationList: ["It's hopeless,"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: John, I think it's time you had a holiday.
subQuotationList: ["John, I think it's time you had a holiday."]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: A holiday what from, mumsy?
subQuotationList: ['A holiday what from, mumsy?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
A change... I'm going to California in July. To the Fischbaums--Mrs
Arnold Fischbaum, not the one who lives in Paris. I think it would do
you good to come with me.
subQuotationList: ["A change... I'm going to California in July. To the Fischbaums--Mrs\nArnold Fischbaum, not the one who lives in Paris. I think it would do\nyou good to come with me."]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: Yes, mumsy.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, mumsy.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: You _would_ like it, wouldn't you?
subQuotationList: ["You _would_ like it, wouldn't you?"]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: Me? Yes, I'd like it.
subQuotationList: ["Me? Yes, I'd like it."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText:
You've picked up that way of talking from Brenda. It sounds ridiculous
in a man.
subQuotationList: ["You've picked up that way of talking from Brenda. It sounds ridiculous\nin a man."]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: Sorry, mumsy.
subQuotationList: ['Sorry, mumsy.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: All right then, that's settled.
subQuotationList: ["All right then, that's settled."]
speaker: Mrs Beaver

quoteText: We can't go on breaking into tinned stores, The men must go out and shoot something.
subQuotationList: ["We can't go on breaking into tinned stores,", 'The men must go out and shoot something.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
No birds, no animals here, All gone. Maybe they get
some fish.
subQuotationList: ['No birds, no animals here,', 'All gone. Maybe they get\nsome fish.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
This is clearly Amazon water, It probably flows
into the Rio Branco or the Rio Negro. The Pie-wies live along the bank,
and the City, from all accounts, must be downstream of us, up one of the
tributaries. When we reach the first Pie-wie village we will be able to
get guides.
subQuotationList:
['This is clearly Amazon water,', 'It probably flows
into the Rio Branco or the Rio Negro. The Pie-wies live along the bank,
and the City, from all accounts, must be downstream of us, up one of the
tributaries. When we reach the first Pie-wie village we will be able to
get guides.']
speaker: Dr Messinger
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText:
When will the boats be ready? Ask
the men.
subQuotationList: ['When will the boats be ready? Ask\nthe men.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Just now.
subQuotationList: ['Just now.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: How many days--four?--five?--how many?
subQuotationList: ['How many days--four?--five?--how many?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No, not many. Boats finish just now.
subQuotationList: ['No, not many. Boats finish just now.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
We shall take eight men with us. Four can stay behind with the women to
guard the camp. Once we are among the Pie-wies, everything will be easy.
These Macushis can go home then. I don't think they will rob the stores.
There is nothing here that would be much use to them.
subQuotationList:
["We shall take eight men with us. Four can stay behind with the women to
guard the camp. Once we are among the Pie-wies, everything will be easy.
These Macushis can go home then. I don't think they will rob the stores.
There is nothing here that would be much use to them."]
speaker: Dr Messinger
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText:
Hadn't we better keep Rosa with us to act as interpreter with the
Macushis?
subQuotationList: ["Hadn't we better keep Rosa with us to act as interpreter with the\nMacushis?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, perhaps we had. I will tell her.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, perhaps we had. I will tell her.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Rosa, we have decided to take you down the river with us. We need you
to help us talk to the men. Understand?
subQuotationList: ['Rosa, we have decided to take you down the river with us. We need you\nto help us talk to the men. Understand?']
speaker: Dr Messinger
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Rosa'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Rosa'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText: Understand?
subQuotationList: ['Understand?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Listen, Rosa, all women and four men stay here in camp. Eight men come
in boats to Pie-wie village. You come with boats. When we reach Pie-wie
village, you and eight men and boats go back to camp to other women and
men. Then back to Macushi country. Understand?
subQuotationList:
['Listen, Rosa, all women and four men stay here in camp. Eight men come
in boats to Pie-wie village. You come with boats. When we reach Pie-wie
village, you and eight men and boats go back to camp to other women and
men. Then back to Macushi country. Understand?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.
subQuotationList: ['Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
I am not asking you to go _with_ Pie-wie people. You and the men take
us as far as Pie-wies, then you go back to Macushi people. Understand?
subQuotationList: ['I am not asking you to go _with_ Pie-wie people. You and the men take\nus as far as Pie-wies, then you go back to Macushi people. Understand?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Macushi peoples there, Pie-wie peoples there, Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.
subQuotationList: ['Macushi peoples there,', 'Pie-wie peoples there,', 'Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
Now listen, Rosa. You are sensible, civilized woman. You lived two
years with black gentleman, Mr Forbes. You like cigarettes--
subQuotationList: ['Now listen, Rosa. You are sensible, civilized woman. You lived two\nyears with black gentleman, Mr Forbes. You like cigarettes--']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Yes, give me cigarettes.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, give me cigarettes.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: You come with men in boats, I give you plenty, plenty cigarettes.
subQuotationList: ['You come with men in boats, I give you plenty, plenty cigarettes.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Listen. You will have your man and seven others to protect you. How can
we talk with men without you?
subQuotationList: ['Listen. You will have your man and seven others to protect you. How can\nwe talk with men without you?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Men no go,
subQuotationList: ['Men no go,']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: Of course the men will go. The only question is, will you come too?
subQuotationList: ['Of course the men will go. The only question is, will you come too?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples,
subQuotationList: ['Macushi peoples no go with Pie-wie peoples,']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
Oh God, All right, we'll talk about it in
the morning.
subQuotationList: ['Oh God,', "All right, we'll talk about it in\nthe morning."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: You give me cigarette....
subQuotationList: ['You give me cigarette....']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText: It's going to be awkward if that woman doesn't come.
subQuotationList: ["It's going to be awkward if that woman doesn't come."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: It's going to be much more awkward if none of them come,
subQuotationList: ["It's going to be much more awkward if none of them come,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
We're all right for stores, There's enough for
three weeks at the shortest and we are bound to come across the Pie-wies
in a day or two. We will start to-morrow.
subQuotationList: ["We're all right for stores,", "There's enough for\nthree weeks at the shortest and we are bound to come across the Pie-wies\nin a day or two. We will start to-morrow."]
