speaker: Dr Messinger
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']], [['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText: We start to-morrow,
subQuotationList: ['We start to-morrow,']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Yes, just now.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, just now.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
Tell the men what I told you last night. Eight men to come in boats,
others wait here. You come in boats. All these stores stay here. All
these stores go in boats. You tell men that.
subQuotationList: ['Tell the men what I told you last night. Eight men to come in boats,\nothers wait here. You come in boats. All these stores stay here. All\nthese stores go in boats. You tell men that.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Understand?
subQuotationList: ['Understand?']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: No peoples go in boats, All peoples go this way, To-morrow or next day all people go back to village.
subQuotationList: ['No peoples go in boats,', 'All peoples go this way,', 'To-morrow or next day all people go back to village.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
You tell the men to
come here
subQuotationList: ['You tell the men to\ncome here']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
It's no use threatening them, They are a queer, timid lot. If
you threaten them they take fright and disappear, leaving you stranded.
Don't worry, I shall be able to persuade them.
subQuotationList: ["It's no use threatening them,", "They are a queer, timid lot. If\nyou threaten them they take fright and disappear, leaving you stranded.\nDon't worry, I shall be able to persuade them."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: We'd better go across and talk to them.
subQuotationList: ["We'd better go across and talk to them."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
What's the matter? I told you to bring the men
here.
subQuotationList: ["What's the matter?", 'I told you to bring the men\nhere.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: So Macushi people are cowards. They are afraid of Pie-wie people.
subQuotationList: ['So Macushi people are cowards. They are afraid of Pie-wie people.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
It is the cassava field, We must go back to dig the
cassava. Otherwise it will be bad.
subQuotationList: ['It is the cassava field,', 'We must go back to dig the\ncassava. Otherwise it will be bad.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
Listen. I want the men for one, two weeks. No more. After that, all
finish. They can go home.
subQuotationList: ['Listen. I want the men for one, two weeks. No more. After that, all\nfinish. They can go home.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
It is the time to dig the cassava. Macushi people dig cassava before
the big rains. All people go home just now.
subQuotationList: ['It is the time to dig the cassava. Macushi people dig cassava before\nthe big rains. All people go home just now.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
It's pure blackmail, Let's get out some trade
goods.
subQuotationList: ["It's pure blackmail,", "Let's get out some trade\ngoods."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: You give me this, Give me this,
subQuotationList: ['You give me this,', 'Give me this,']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
Each man can choose three things from this box if he comes in the
boats.
subQuotationList: ['Each man can choose three things from this box if he comes in the\nboats.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Macushi peoples dig cassava field just
now.
subQuotationList: ['Macushi peoples dig cassava field just\nnow.']
speaker: Rosa

quoteText:
It's no good, We shall have to try with the mice. I wanted to keep them
till we reached the Pie-wies. It's a pity. But they'll fall for the
mice, you see. I _know_ the Indian mind. Well, I'm damned, that's better than I expected.
subQuotationList: ["It's no good,", "We shall have to try with the mice. I wanted to keep them\ntill we reached the Pie-wies. It's a pity. But they'll fall for the\nmice, you see. I _know_ the Indian mind.", "Well, I'm damned,", "that's better than I expected."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: More than you expected, anyway.
subQuotationList: ['More than you expected, anyway.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh, it's all right. They'll come back. I know them.
subQuotationList: ["Oh, it's all right. They'll come back. I know them."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
We'd better make a fire.
They'll come back when it is dark.
subQuotationList: ["We'd better make a fire.\nThey'll come back when it is dark."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: We'd better get some supper,
subQuotationList: ["We'd better get some supper,"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: We shall find them all here in the morning, They're an odd bunch.
subQuotationList: ['We shall find them all here in the morning,', "They're an odd bunch."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Let's have the window open, It's stuffy in here.
subQuotationList: ["Let's have the window open,", "It's stuffy in here."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: It's quite light,
subQuotationList: ["It's quite light,"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: After five. Oughtn't we to go to bed?
subQuotationList: ["After five. Oughtn't we to go to bed?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Only another week and then all the parties will be over,
subQuotationList: ['Only another week and then all the parties will be over,']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Well, let's go.
subQuotationList: ["Well, let's go."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: All right. Can you pay? I just haven't any money.
subQuotationList: ["All right. Can you pay? I just haven't any money."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Eight shillings, How does Daisy expect to make a success of the place when she charges
prices like that?
subQuotationList: ['Eight shillings,', 'How does Daisy expect to make a success of the place when she charges\nprices like that?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: It does seem a lot.... So you really _are_ going to America?
subQuotationList: ['It does seem a lot.... So you really _are_ going to America?']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I must. Mother has taken the tickets.
subQuotationList: ['I must. Mother has taken the tickets.']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Nothing I've said to-night makes any difference?
subQuotationList: ["Nothing I've said to-night makes any difference?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Darling, don't go on. We've been through all that. You know it's the
only thing that _can_ happen. Why spoil the last week?
subQuotationList: ["Darling, don't go on. We've been through all that. You know it's the\nonly thing that _can_ happen. Why spoil the last week?"]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: You _have_ enjoyed the summer, haven't you?
subQuotationList: ["You _have_ enjoyed the summer, haven't you?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Of course... well, shall we go?
subQuotationList: ['Of course... well, shall we go?']
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: Yes. You needn't bother to see me home.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. You needn't bother to see me home."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Sure you don't mind? It _is_ miles out of the way and it's late.
subQuotationList: ["Sure you don't mind? It _is_ miles out of the way and it's late."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: There's no knowing what I mind.
subQuotationList: ["There's no knowing what I mind."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Brenda, darling, for heaven's sake... It isn't like you to go on like
this.
subQuotationList: ["Brenda, darling, for heaven's sake... It isn't like you to go on like\nthis."]
speaker: John Beaver

quoteText: I never was one for making myself expensive.
subQuotationList: ['I never was one for making myself expensive.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: The situation is grave, But not desperate.
subQuotationList: ['The situation is grave,', 'But not desperate.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
It was just a passing attack, wasn't it? I shall be
perfectly fit to-morrow, shan't I?
subQuotationList: ["It was just a passing attack, wasn't it?", "I shall be\nperfectly fit to-morrow, shan't I?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I hope so,
subQuotationList: ['I hope so,']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I feel
grand,
subQuotationList: ['I feel\ngrand,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Good.
subQuotationList: ['Good.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
We've got to go on, We can't be far from a village
now.
subQuotationList: ["We've got to go on,", "We can't be far from a village\nnow."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I feel awful. Wouldn't it be better to wait a day till I am perfectly
fit again?
subQuotationList: ["I feel awful. Wouldn't it be better to wait a day till I am perfectly\nfit again?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It's no good waiting. We've got to get on. D'you think you can manage
to get into the canoe?
subQuotationList: ["It's no good waiting. We've got to get on. D'you think you can manage\nto get into the canoe?"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: So the Indians came back?
subQuotationList: ['So the Indians came back?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I knew they would. Silly of them to be scared by a toy. I suppose the
others are following.
subQuotationList: ['I knew they would. Silly of them to be scared by a toy. I suppose the\nothers are following.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, I expect so. Try and sit still.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I expect so. Try and sit still.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Damned fool, being frightened of a toy mouse,
subQuotationList: ['Damned fool, being frightened of a toy mouse,']
speaker: Tony Last
referringExpression: Tony said derisively to the woman amidships

quoteText:
I'm sorry, I didn't see it was you. You wouldn't be frightened of a toy
mouse.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry,", "I didn't see it was you. You wouldn't be frightened of a toy\nmouse."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
That's what poise means, D'you know, I once saw a
questionnaire that people had to fill in when they applied for a job in
an American firm, and one of the things they had to answer was "Have you
poise?"
subQuotationList:
["That's what poise means,", 'D'you know, I once saw a
questionnaire that people had to fill in when they applied for a job in
an American firm, and one of the things they had to answer was "Have you
poise?"']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
What was so absurd
about the question was that they only had the applicant's word for it, I mean--is it a sign of poise to think you
have it?
subQuotationList: ["What was so absurd\nabout the question was that they only had the applicant's word for it,", 'I mean--is it a sign of poise to think you\nhave it?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Just sit quiet here while I sling your hammock.
subQuotationList: ['Just sit quiet here while I sling your hammock.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Yes, I'll sit here with Brenda. I am so glad she could come. She must
have caught the three-eighteen.
subQuotationList: ["Yes, I'll sit here with Brenda. I am so glad she could come. She must\nhave caught the three-eighteen."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You're down to normal again.
subQuotationList: ["You're down to normal again."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Thank God. I've been pretty ill, haven't I? I can't remember much.
subQuotationList: ["Thank God. I've been pretty ill, haven't I? I can't remember much."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: How d'you feel?
subQuotationList: ["How d'you feel?"]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Grand, Of course, I haven't eaten anything. I expect
it will be a day or two before I'm really well.
subQuotationList: ['Grand,', "Of course, I haven't eaten anything. I expect\nit will be a day or two before I'm really well."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: See if you can drink this.
subQuotationList: ['See if you can drink this.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: Are we going on to-day?
subQuotationList: ['Are we going on to-day?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: We'll think about it.
subQuotationList: ["We'll think about it."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I think I'd better
explain things. It's no use your thinking you are cured because you are
out of fever for one day. That's the way it goes. One day fever and one
day normal. It may take a week or it may take much longer. That's a
thing we've got to face. I can't risk taking you in the canoe. You
nearly upset us several times the day before yesterday.
subQuotationList:
["I think I'd better
explain things. It's no use your thinking you are cured because you are
out of fever for one day. That's the way it goes. One day fever and one
day normal. It may take a week or it may take much longer. That's a
thing we've got to face. I can't risk taking you in the canoe. You
nearly upset us several times the day before yesterday."]
speaker: Dr Messinger
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText: I thought there was someone there I knew.
subQuotationList: ['I thought there was someone there I knew.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You thought a lot of things. It'll go on like that. Meanwhile we've
provisions for about ten days. There's no immediate anxiety there but
it's a thing to remember. Besides, what you need is a roof over your
head and constant nursing. If only we were at a village....
subQuotationList:
["You thought a lot of things. It'll go on like that. Meanwhile we've
provisions for about ten days. There's no immediate anxiety there but
it's a thing to remember. Besides, what you need is a roof over your
head and constant nursing. If only we were at a village...."]
speaker: Dr Messinger
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Dr Messinger', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText: I'm afraid I'm being a great nuisance.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid I'm being a great nuisance."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: That's not the point. The thing is to find what is best for us to do.
subQuotationList: ["That's not the point. The thing is to find what is best for us to do."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
I'm going to fix
up the tarpaulin as a roof.
subQuotationList: ["I'm going to fix\nup the tarpaulin as a roof."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
Look here, why don't
you leave me here and go down the river for help?
subQuotationList: ["Look here, why don't\nyou leave me here and go down the river for help?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I thought of that. It's too big a risk.
subQuotationList: ["I thought of that. It's too big a risk."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText:
How long
have we been here?
subQuotationList: ['How long\nhave we been here?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Only three days.
subQuotationList: ['Only three days.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: What time is it now?
subQuotationList: ['What time is it now?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Getting on for ten in the morning.
subQuotationList: ['Getting on for ten in the morning.']
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: I feel awful.
subQuotationList: ['I feel awful.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I am going downstream for the day, to see if there's any sign of a village. I hate leaving you but
it's a chance worth taking. I shall be able to get a long way in the
canoe now it's empty. Lie quiet. Don't move from the hammock. I shall be
back before night. I hope with some Indians to help.
subQuotationList:
['I am going downstream for the day,', "to see if there's any sign of a village. I hate leaving you but
it's a chance worth taking. I shall be able to get a long way in the
canoe now it's empty. Lie quiet. Don't move from the hammock. I shall be
back before night. I hope with some Indians to help."]
speaker: Dr Messinger

quoteText: All right,
subQuotationList: ['All right,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Mr Graceful, I've got to have some more money.
subQuotationList: ['Mr Graceful,', "I've got to have some more money."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
I should have thought that was really
a question for your bank manager. I understand that your securities are
in your own name and that the dividends are paid into your account.
subQuotationList: ['I should have thought that was really\na question for your bank manager. I understand that your securities are\nin your own name and that the dividends are paid into your account.']
speaker: Mr Graceful

quoteText:
They never seem to pay dividends nowadays. Besides, it's really very
difficult to live on so little.
subQuotationList: ["They never seem to pay dividends nowadays. Besides, it's really very\ndifficult to live on so little."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: No doubt. No doubt.
subQuotationList: ['No doubt. No doubt.']
speaker: Mr Graceful

quoteText: Mr Last left you with power of attorney, didn't he?
subQuotationList: ["Mr Last left you with power of attorney, didn't he?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
With strictly limited powers, Lady Brenda. I am instructed to pay the
wage bill at Hetton and all expenses connected with the upkeep of the
estate--he is putting in new bathrooms and restoring some decorations in
the morning-room which had been demolished. But I am afraid that I have
no authority to draw on Mr Last's account for other charges.
subQuotationList:
["With strictly limited powers, Lady Brenda. I am instructed to pay the
wage bill at Hetton and all expenses connected with the upkeep of the
estate--he is putting in new bathrooms and restoring some decorations in
the morning-room which had been demolished. But I am afraid that I have
no authority to draw on Mr Last's account for other charges."]
speaker: Mr Graceful

quoteText:
But, Mr Graceful, I am sure he didn't intend to stay abroad so long. He
can't possibly have meant to leave me stranded like this, can he?...
Can he?
subQuotationList: ["But, Mr Graceful, I am sure he didn't intend to stay abroad so long. He\ncan't possibly have meant to leave me stranded like this, can he?...\nCan he?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
To be quite frank, Lady
Brenda, I fear that _was_ his intention. I raised this particular point
shortly before his departure. He was quite resolved on the subject.
subQuotationList: ['To be quite frank, Lady\nBrenda, I fear that _was_ his intention. I raised this particular point\nshortly before his departure. He was quite resolved on the subject.']
speaker: Mr Graceful

quoteText:
But is he _allowed_ to do that? I mean, haven't I got any rights under
the marriage settlement or anything?
subQuotationList: ["But is he _allowed_ to do that? I mean, haven't I got any rights under\nthe marriage settlement or anything?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Nothing which you can claim without application to the courts. You
_might_ find solicitors who would advise you to take action. I cannot
say that I should be one of them. Mr Last would oppose any such order to
the utmost and I think that, in the present circumstances, the courts
would undoubtedly find for him. In any case it would be a prolonged,
costly and slightly undignified proceeding.
subQuotationList:
['Nothing which you can claim without application to the courts. You
_might_ find solicitors who would advise you to take action. I cannot
say that I should be one of them. Mr Last would oppose any such order to
the utmost and I think that, in the present circumstances, the courts
would undoubtedly find for him. In any case it would be a prolonged,
costly and slightly undignified proceeding.']
speaker: Mr Graceful

quoteText: Oh, I see... well, that's that, isn't it?
subQuotationList: ["Oh, I see... well, that's that, isn't it?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: It certainly looks as though it were.
subQuotationList: ['It certainly looks as though it were.']
speaker: Mr Graceful

quoteText:
There's one thing. Do you know, I mean, can you tell me whether Mr Last
made another will?
subQuotationList: ["There's one thing. Do you know, I mean, can you tell me whether Mr Last\nmade another will?"]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: I'm afraid that is a thing I cannot discuss.
subQuotationList: ["I'm afraid that is a thing I cannot discuss."]
speaker: Mr Graceful

quoteText:
No, I suppose not. I'm sorry if it was wrong to ask. I just wanted to
know how I am with him.
subQuotationList: ["No, I suppose not. I'm sorry if it was wrong to ask. I just wanted to\nknow how I am with him."]
speaker: Brenda

quoteText:
Perhaps I can say as much as this to guide you.
The heirs-presumptive to Hetton are now his cousins, the Richard Lasts
at Princes Risborough. I think that your knowledge of Mr Last's
character and opinions will tell you that he would always wish his
fortune to go with the estate, in order that it may be preserved in what
he holds to be its right condition.
subQuotationList:
["Perhaps I can say as much as this to guide you.
The heirs-presumptive to Hetton are now his cousins, the Richard Lasts
at Princes Risborough. I think that your knowledge of Mr Last's
character and opinions will tell you that he would always wish his
fortune to go with the estate, in order that it may be preserved in what
he holds to be its right condition."]
speaker: Mr Graceful
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Brenda'], ['Richard Last', 'Mrs Last', 'Teddy Last', 'Molly Last'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Brenda'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: Yes, I ought to have thought of that. Well, good-bye.
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'I ought to have thought of that. Well, good-bye.']
speaker: Brenda

quoteText: Why are you dressed like that?
subQuotationList: ['Why are you dressed like that?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It looks so dirty.
subQuotationList: ['It looks so dirty.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: But it isn't Wednesday?
subQuotationList: ["But it isn't Wednesday?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I can't get as far as Pigstanton. I've got to stay here until Messinger
comes back. I'm ill. He told me to be quiet. He's coming this evening.
subQuotationList: ["I can't get as far as Pigstanton. I've got to stay here until Messinger\ncomes back. I'm ill. He told me to be quiet. He's coming this evening."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
She has a daughter. She has as much right here as Lady
Cockpurse.
subQuotationList: ['She has a daughter. She has as much right here as Lady\nCockpurse.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Ladies and gentlemen, I beg you to understand that I am
ill and must not move from the hammock. Dr Messinger has given the
clearest instructions.
subQuotationList: ['Ladies and gentlemen,', 'I beg you to understand that I am\nill and must not move from the hammock. Dr Messinger has given the\nclearest instructions.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Why are you all changing your clothes?
subQuotationList: ['Why are you all changing your clothes?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Why, I didn't know you were here.
subQuotationList: ["Why, I didn't know you were here."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: But how can I reach the City if I stay here?
subQuotationList: ['But how can I reach the City if I stay here?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, in the library. There is no point in using the dining-hall now
that her Ladyship has gone to live in Brazil.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, in the library. There is no point in using the dining-hall now\nthat her Ladyship has gone to live in Brazil.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: But I don't want the pony. I told Ben to sell her.
subQuotationList: ["But I don't want the pony. I told Ben to sell her."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Very well, Ambrose.
subQuotationList: ['Very well, Ambrose.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You're the first person who's spoken to me for days, The
others won't stop. They keep bicycling by... I'm tired... Brenda was
with me at first but she was frightened by a mechanical mouse, so she
took the canoe and went off. She said she would come back that evening
but she didn't. I expect she's staying with one of her new friends in
Brazil... You haven't seen her, have you?
subQuotationList:
["You're the first person who's spoken to me for days,", "The
others won't stop. They keep bicycling by... I'm tired... Brenda was
with me at first but she was frightened by a mechanical mouse, so she
took the canoe and went off. She said she would come back that evening
but she didn't. I expect she's staying with one of her new friends in
Brazil... You haven't seen her, have you?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You are the first stranger I have seen for a very long time.
subQuotationList: ['You are the first stranger I have seen for a very long time.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: She was wearing a top hat when she left. You can't miss her.
subQuotationList: ["She was wearing a top hat when she left. You can't miss her."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Do you see that house over there? Do you think you can manage to walk
to it? If not, I can send some Indians to carry you.
subQuotationList: ['Do you see that house over there? Do you think you can manage to walk\nto it? If not, I can send some Indians to carry you.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Architecture harmonizing with local character, indigenous
material employed throughout. Don't let Mrs Beaver see it or she will
cover it with chromium plating.
subQuotationList: ['Architecture harmonizing with local character,', "indigenous\nmaterial employed throughout. Don't let Mrs Beaver see it or she will\ncover it with chromium plating."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Try and walk.
subQuotationList: ['Try and walk.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
I'll ride your bicycle. It _was_ you I passed just now on a bicycle,
wasn't it?... except that your beard is a different colour. His was
green... green as mice.
subQuotationList: ["I'll ride your bicycle. It _was_ you I passed just now on a bicycle,\nwasn't it?... except that your beard is a different colour. His was\ngreen... green as mice."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
It is a very short way. When we get there I will give you something to
make you better.
subQuotationList: ['It is a very short way. When we get there I will give you something to\nmake you better.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Very kind of you... rotten thing for a man to have his wife go away in
a canoe. That was a long time ago. Nothing to eat since. I say, you're English. I'm English too. My name is Last.
subQuotationList: ['Very kind of you... rotten thing for a man to have his wife go away in\na canoe. That was a long time ago. Nothing to eat since.', "I say, you're English. I'm English too. My name is Last."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Well, Mr Last, you aren't to bother about anything more. You're ill and
you've had a rough journey. I'll take care of you.
subQuotationList: ["Well, Mr Last, you aren't to bother about anything more. You're ill and\nyou've had a rough journey. I'll take care of you."]
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Are you all English?
subQuotationList: ['Are you all English?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, all of us.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, all of us.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
That dark girl married a Moor... It's very lucky I met you all. I
suppose you're some kind of cycling club?
subQuotationList: ["That dark girl married a Moor... It's very lucky I met you all. I\nsuppose you're some kind of cycling club?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes.
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Well, I feel too tired for bicycling... never liked it much...
you fellows ought to get motor bicycles, you know, much faster and
noisier... Let's stop here.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I feel too tired for bicycling... never liked it much...\nyou fellows ought to get motor bicycles, you know, much faster and\nnoisier... Let's stop here."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: No, you must come as far as the house. It's not very much farther.
subQuotationList: ["No, you must come as far as the house. It's not very much farther."]
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
All right... I suppose you would have some difficulty getting petrol
here.
subQuotationList: ['All right... I suppose you would have some difficulty getting petrol\nhere.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Lie there in the hammock.
subQuotationList: ['Lie there in the hammock.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: That's what Messinger said. He's in love with John Beaver.
subQuotationList: ["That's what Messinger said. He's in love with John Beaver."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I will get something for you.
subQuotationList: ['I will get something for you.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Very good of you. Just my usual morning tray--coffee, toast, fruit. And
the morning papers. If her Ladyship has been called I will have it with
her...
subQuotationList: ['Very good of you. Just my usual morning tray--coffee, toast, fruit. And\nthe morning papers. If her Ladyship has been called I will have it with\nher...']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
...You would hear better and it would be more polite if you stood
still when I addressed you instead of walking round in a circle. It is
for your own good that I am telling you... I know you are friends of my
wife and that is why you will not listen to me. But be careful. She will
say nothing cruel, she will not raise her voice, there will be no hard
words. She hopes you will be great friends afterwards as before. But she
will leave you. She will go away quietly during the night. She will take
her hammock and her rations of farine... Listen to me. I know I am not
clever but that is no reason why we should forget all courtesy. Let us
kill in the gentlest manner. I will tell you what I have learned in the
forest, where time is different. There is no City. Mrs Beaver has
covered it with chromium plating and converted it into flats. Three
guineas a week, each with a separate bathroom. Very suitable for base
love. And Polly will be there. She and Mrs Beaver under the fallen
battlements...
subQuotationList:
['...You would hear better and it would be more polite if you stood
still when I addressed you instead of walking round in a circle. It is
for your own good that I am telling you... I know you are friends of my
wife and that is why you will not listen to me. But be careful. She will
say nothing cruel, she will not raise her voice, there will be no hard
words. She hopes you will be great friends afterwards as before. But she
will leave you. She will go away quietly during the night. She will take
her hammock and her rations of farine... Listen to me. I know I am not
clever but that is no reason why we should forget all courtesy. Let us
kill in the gentlest manner. I will tell you what I have learned in the
forest, where time is different. There is no City. Mrs Beaver has
covered it with chromium plating and converted it into flats. Three
guineas a week, each with a separate bathroom. Very suitable for base
love. And Polly will be there. She and Mrs Beaver under the fallen
battlements...']
speaker: Tony Last
referringExpression: his guest was bolt upright astride the hammock talking

quoteText: Nasty medicine,
subQuotationList: ['Nasty medicine,']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It's very nasty, but it does do good.
subQuotationList: ["It's very nasty,", 'but it does do good.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
There is medicine for everything in the forest, to make
you well and to make you ill. My mother was an Indian and she taught me
many of them. I have learned others from time to time from my wives.
There are plants to cure you and give you fever, to kill you and send
you mad, to keep away snakes, to intoxicate fish so that you can pick
them out of the water with your hands like fruit from a tree. There are
medicines even I do not know. They say that it is possible to bring dead
people to life after they have begun to stink, but I have not seen it
done.
subQuotationList:
['There is medicine for everything in the forest,', 'to make
you well and to make you ill. My mother was an Indian and she taught me
many of them. I have learned others from time to time from my wives.
There are plants to cure you and give you fever, to kill you and send
you mad, to keep away snakes, to intoxicate fish so that you can pick
them out of the water with your hands like fruit from a tree. There are
medicines even I do not know. They say that it is possible to bring dead
people to life after they have begun to stink, but I have not seen it
done.']
speaker: Mr Todd
mentionEntitiesList: [[], [['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: But surely you are English?
subQuotationList: ['But surely you are English?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
My father was--at least a Barbadian. He came to Guiana as a missionary.
He was married to a white woman but he left her in Guiana to look for
gold. Then he took my mother. The Pie-wie women are ugly but very
devoted. I have had many. Most of the men and women living in this
savannah are my children. That is why they obey--for that reason and
because I have the gun. My father lived to a great age. It is not twenty
years since he died. He was a man of education. Can you read?
subQuotationList:
['My father was--at least a Barbadian. He came to Guiana as a missionary.
He was married to a white woman but he left her in Guiana to look for
gold. Then he took my mother. The Pie-wie women are ugly but very
devoted. I have had many. Most of the men and women living in this
savannah are my children. That is why they obey--for that reason and
because I have the gun. My father lived to a great age. It is not twenty
years since he died. He was a man of education. Can you read?']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Yes, of course.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, of course.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: It is not everyone who is so fortunate. I cannot.
subQuotationList: ['It is not everyone who is so fortunate. I cannot.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
But I suppose you haven't much opportunity
here.
subQuotationList: ["But I suppose you haven't much opportunity\nhere."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Oh yes, that is just it. I have a _great_ many books. I will show you
when you are better. Until five years ago there was an Englishman--at
least a black man, but he was well educated in Georgetown. He died. He
used to read to me every day until he died. You shall read to me when
you are better.
subQuotationList:
['Oh yes, that is just it. I have a _great_ many books. I will show you
when you are better. Until five years ago there was an Englishman--at
least a black man, but he was well educated in Georgetown. He died. He
used to read to me every day until he died. You shall read to me when
you are better.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: I shall be delighted to.
subQuotationList: ['I shall be delighted to.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Yes, you shall read to me,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, you shall read to me,']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
I will show you the black man's grave, He was very kind. Every afternoon until he
died, for two hours, he used to read to me. I think I will put up a
cross--to commemorate his death and your arrival--a pretty idea. Do you
believe in God?
subQuotationList:
["I will show you the black man's grave,", 'He was very kind. Every afternoon until he
died, for two hours, he used to read to me. I think I will put up a
cross--to commemorate his death and your arrival--a pretty idea. Do you
believe in God?']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: I suppose so. I've never really thought about it much.
subQuotationList: ["I suppose so. I've never really thought about it much."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I have thought about it a _great_ deal and I still do not know...
Dickens did.
subQuotationList: ['I have thought about it a _great_ deal and I still do not know...\nDickens did.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: I suppose so.
subQuotationList: ['I suppose so.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Oh yes, it is apparent in all his books. You will see.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes, it is apparent in all his books. You will see.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Now I think you are well enough to see the books.
subQuotationList: ['Now I think you are well enough to see the books.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
It has been hard to keep out the worms and ants. Two are practically
destroyed. But there is an oil the Indians make that is useful.
subQuotationList: ['It has been hard to keep out the worms and ants. Two are practically\ndestroyed. But there is an oil the Indians make that is useful.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: It does not matter which we take first.
subQuotationList: ['It does not matter which we take first.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: You are fond of Dickens?
subQuotationList: ['You are fond of Dickens?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Why, yes, of course. More than fond, far more. You see, they are the
only books I have ever heard. My father used to read them and then later
the black man... and now you. I have heard them all several times by
now but I never get tired; there is always more to be learned and
noticed, so many characters, so many changes of scene, so many words...
I have all Dickens's books here except those that the ants devoured. It
takes a long time to read them all--more than two years.
subQuotationList:
["Why, yes, of course. More than fond, far more. You see, they are the
only books I have ever heard. My father used to read them and then later
the black man... and now you. I have heard them all several times by
now but I never get tired; there is always more to be learned and
noticed, so many characters, so many changes of scene, so many words...
I have all Dickens's books here except those that the ants devoured. It
takes a long time to read them all--more than two years."]
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Well, they will well last out my visit.
subQuotationList: ['Well,', 'they will well last out my visit.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Oh, I hope not. It is delightful to start again. Each time I think I
find more to enjoy and admire.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, I hope not. It is delightful to start again. Each time I think I\nfind more to enjoy and admire.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Repeat the
name, I have forgotten him, Yes, yes, I remember her well. She
dies, poor woman.
subQuotationList: ['Repeat the\nname, I have forgotten him,', 'Yes, yes, I remember her well. She\ndies, poor woman.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Now, why does she say
that? Does she really mean it? Did she feel faint because of the heat of
the fire or of something in that paper?
subQuotationList: ['Now, why does she say\nthat? Does she really mean it? Did she feel faint because of the heat of\nthe fire or of something in that paper?']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
I
think the Dedlock is a very proud man,
subQuotationList: ['I\nthink the Dedlock is a very proud man,']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Mrs Jellyby does not take
enough care of her children.
subQuotationList: ['Mrs Jellyby does not take\nenough care of her children.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
You read beautifully,
with a far better accent than the black man. And you explain better. It
is almost as though my father were here again.
subQuotationList: ['You read beautifully,\nwith a far better accent than the black man. And you explain better. It\nis almost as though my father were here again.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
I enjoyed that _very_ much.
It was an extremely distressing chapter. But, if I remember it rightly,
it will all turn out well.
subQuotationList: ['I enjoyed that _very_ much.\nIt was an extremely distressing chapter. But, if I remember it rightly,\nit will all turn out well.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
We still have a lot to get through. I
hope I shall be able to finish it before I go.
subQuotationList: ['We still have a lot to get through. I\nhope I shall be able to finish it before I go.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Oh yes, Do not disturb yourself about that. You will
have time to finish it, my friend.
subQuotationList: ['Oh yes,', 'Do not disturb yourself about that. You will\nhave time to finish it, my friend.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
You know, Mr Todd, the time has come when I must be thinking about
getting back to civilization. I have already imposed myself on your
hospitality far too long.
subQuotationList: ['You know, Mr Todd, the time has come when I must be thinking about\ngetting back to civilization. I have already imposed myself on your\nhospitality far too long.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
How soon do you think I shall be able to get a boat?... I said, how
soon do you think I shall be able to get a boat? I appreciate all your
kindness to me more than I can say, but...
subQuotationList: ['How soon do you think I shall be able to get a boat?... I said, how\nsoon do you think I shall be able to get a boat? I appreciate all your\nkindness to me more than I can say, but...']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
My friend, any kindness I may have shown is amply repaid by your
reading of Dickens. Do not let us mention the subject again.
subQuotationList: ['My friend, any kindness I may have shown is amply repaid by your\nreading of Dickens. Do not let us mention the subject again.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Well, I'm very glad you have enjoyed it. I have, too. But I really must
be thinking of getting back...
subQuotationList: ["Well, I'm very glad you have enjoyed it. I have, too. But I really must\nbe thinking of getting back..."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, The black man was like that. He thought of it all
the time. But he died here...
subQuotationList: ['Yes,', 'The black man was like that. He thought of it all\nthe time. But he died here...']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Forgive me, Mr Todd, but I really must press
the point. When can I get a boat?
subQuotationList: ['Forgive me, Mr Todd, but I really must press\nthe point. When can I get a boat?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: There is no boat.
subQuotationList: ['There is no boat.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Well, the Indians can build one.
subQuotationList: ['Well, the Indians can build one.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
You must wait for the rains. There is not enough water in the river
now.
subQuotationList: ['You must wait for the rains. There is not enough water in the river\nnow.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: How long will that be?
subQuotationList: ['How long will that be?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: A month... two months...
subQuotationList: ['A month... two months...']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Now it is time to make preparations to go.
subQuotationList: ['Now it is time to make preparations to go.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Oh, that is impossible. The Indians will not make a boat during the
rainy season--it is one of their superstitions.
subQuotationList: ['Oh, that is impossible. The Indians will not make a boat during the\nrainy season--it is one of their superstitions.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: You might have told me.
subQuotationList: ['You might have told me.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Did I not mention it? I forgot.
subQuotationList: ['Did I not mention it? I forgot.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Mr Last, the Indians tell me that
you have been trying to speak with them. It is easier that you say
anything you wish through me. You realize, do you not, that they would
do nothing without my authority. They regard themselves, quite rightly
in many cases, as my children.
subQuotationList:
['Mr Last, the Indians tell me that
you have been trying to speak with them. It is easier that you say
anything you wish through me. You realize, do you not, that they would
do nothing without my authority. They regard themselves, quite rightly
in many cases, as my children.']
speaker: Mr Todd
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: Well, as a matter of fact, I was asking them about a canoe.
subQuotationList: ['Well, as a matter of fact, I was asking them about a canoe.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
So they gave me to understand... and now if you have finished your
meal perhaps we might have another chapter. I am quite absorbed in the
book.
subQuotationList: ['So they gave me to understand... and now if you have finished your\nmeal perhaps we might have another chapter. I am quite absorbed in the\nbook.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Mr Todd, I must speak frankly. You saved my life, and when
I get back to civilization I will reward you to the best of my ability.
I will give you anything within reason. But at present you are keeping
me here against my will. I demand to be released.
subQuotationList:
['Mr Todd,', 'I must speak frankly. You saved my life, and when
I get back to civilization I will reward you to the best of my ability.
I will give you anything within reason. But at present you are keeping
me here against my will. I demand to be released.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
But, my friend, what is keeping you? You are under no restraint. Go
when you like.
subQuotationList: ['But, my friend, what is keeping you? You are under no restraint. Go\nwhen you like.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: You know very well that I can't get away without your help.
subQuotationList: ["You know very well that I can't get away without your help."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: In that case you must humour an old man. Read me another chapter.
subQuotationList: ['In that case you must humour an old man. Read me another chapter.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Mr Todd, I swear by anything you like that when I get to Man?os I will
find someone to take my place. I will pay a man to read to you all day.
subQuotationList: ['Mr Todd, I swear by anything you like that when I get to Man?os I will\nfind someone to take my place. I will pay a man to read to you all day.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: But I have no need of another man. You read so well.
subQuotationList: ['But I have no need of another man. You read so well.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: I have read for the last time.
subQuotationList: ['I have read for the last time.']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: I hope not,
subQuotationList: ['I hope not,']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
May I trouble you to read that passage
again? It is one I particularly enjoy.
subQuotationList: ['May I trouble you to read that passage\nagain? It is one I particularly enjoy.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
It is one of the local feast days, and they have been
making _pivari_. You may not like it but you should try some. We will go
across to this man's home to-night.
subQuotationList: ['It is one of the local feast days,', "and they have been\nmaking _pivari_. You may not like it but you should try some. We will go\nacross to this man's home to-night."]
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: You must drink it all without lowering the cup. That is the etiquette.
subQuotationList: ['You must drink it all without lowering the cup. That is the etiquette.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText:
Ah, my friend, you are late for the reading this afternoon. There is
scarcely another half hour of light. How do you feel?
subQuotationList: ['Ah, my friend, you are late for the reading this afternoon. There is\nscarcely another half hour of light. How do you feel?']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Rotten. That drink doesn't seem to agree with me.
subQuotationList: ["Rotten. That drink doesn't seem to agree with me."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
I will give you something to make you better. The forest has remedies
for everything; to make you awake and to make you sleep.
subQuotationList: ['I will give you something to make you better. The forest has remedies\nfor everything; to make you awake and to make you sleep.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: You haven't seen my watch anywhere?
subQuotationList: ["You haven't seen my watch anywhere?"]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: You have missed it?
subQuotationList: ['You have missed it?']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Yes. I thought I was wearing it. I say, I've never slept so long.
subQuotationList: ["Yes. I thought I was wearing it. I say, I've never slept so long."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText: Not since you were a baby. Do you know how long? Two days.
subQuotationList: ['Not since you were a baby. Do you know how long? Two days.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Nonsense. I can't have.
subQuotationList: ["Nonsense. I can't have."]
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Yes, indeed. It is a long time. It is a pity because you missed our
guests.
subQuotationList: ['Yes, indeed. It is a long time. It is a pity because you missed our\nguests.']
speaker: Mr Todd

quoteText: Guests?
subQuotationList: ['Guests?']
speaker: Tony Last

quoteText:
Why, yes. I have been quite gay while you were asleep. Three men from
outside. Englishmen. It is a pity you missed them. A pity for them, too,
as they particularly wished to see you. But what could I do? You were so
sound asleep. They had come all the way to find you, so--I thought you
would not mind--as you could not greet them yourself, I gave them a
little souvenir, your watch. They wanted something to take back to
England where a reward is being offered for news of you. They were very
pleased with it. And they took some photographs of the little cross I
put up to commemorate your coming. They were pleased with that, too.
They were very easily pleased. But I do not suppose they will visit us
again, our life here is so retired... no pleasures except reading... I
do not suppose we shall ever have visitors again... well, well, I will
get you some medicine to make you feel better. Your head aches, does it
not?... We will not have any Dickens to-day... but to-morrow, and the
day after that, and the day after that. Let us read _Little Dorrit_
again. There are passages in that book I can never hear without the
temptation to weep.
subQuotationList:
['Why, yes. I have been quite gay while you were asleep. Three men from
outside. Englishmen. It is a pity you missed them. A pity for them, too,
as they particularly wished to see you. But what could I do? You were so
sound asleep. They had come all the way to find you, so--I thought you
would not mind--as you could not greet them yourself, I gave them a
little souvenir, your watch. They wanted something to take back to
England where a reward is being offered for news of you. They were very
pleased with it. And they took some photographs of the little cross I
put up to commemorate your coming. They were pleased with that, too.
They were very easily pleased. But I do not suppose they will visit us
again, our life here is so retired... no pleasures except reading... I
do not suppose we shall ever have visitors again... well, well, I will
get you some medicine to make you feel better. Your head aches, does it
not?... We will not have any Dickens to-day... but to-morrow, and the
day after that, and the day after that. Let us read _Little Dorrit_
again. There are passages in that book I can never hear without the
temptation to weep.']
speaker: Mr Todd
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last', 'Mr Todd'], ['Mr Todd', 'Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Mr Todd', 'Tony Last'], ['Mr Todd', 'Tony Last']]]

quoteText: Molly, you have rabbit-feed on your head again.
subQuotationList: ['Molly, you have rabbit-feed on your head again.']
speaker: Mrs Last

quoteText: Oh well, I shall have to tidy up anyway before the jamboree.
subQuotationList: ['Oh well, I shall have to tidy up anyway before the jamboree.']
speaker: Molly Last

quoteText: _Jamboree?_ Is nothing sacred to you children?
subQuotationList: ['_Jamboree?_ Is nothing sacred to you children?']
speaker: Richard Last

quoteText:
Another casualty at the stinkeries. That little vixen we
bought from the people at Okehampton got her brush bitten off during the
night. Must have got it through the wire into the next cage. Tricky
birds, foxes.
subQuotationList:
['Another casualty at the stinkeries. That little vixen we
bought from the people at Okehampton got her brush bitten off during the
night. Must have got it through the wire into the next cage. Tricky
birds, foxes.']
speaker: Teddy Last

quoteText: I'm sorry if I'm late.
subQuotationList: ["I'm sorry if I'm late."]
speaker: Agnes
referringExpression: She kissed her father and mother and said

quoteText: _If_ you're late...
subQuotationList: ["_If_ you're late..."]
speaker: Richard Last

quoteText:
How long will the show last? I've got to run over to
Bayton and get some more rabbits for the foxes. Chivers says he's got
about fifty waiting for me. We can't shoot enough here. Greedy little
beggars.
subQuotationList:
['How long will the show last?', "I've got to run over to
Bayton and get some more rabbits for the foxes. Chivers says he's got
about fifty waiting for me. We can't shoot enough here. Greedy little
beggars."]
speaker: Teddy Last

quoteText:
It will be all over by half-past eleven. Mr Tendril isn't going to
preach a sermon. It's just as well really. He's got it into his head
that Cousin Tony died in Afghanistan.
subQuotationList: ["It will be all over by half-past eleven. Mr Tendril isn't going to\npreach a sermon. It's just as well really. He's got it into his head\nthat Cousin Tony died in Afghanistan."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
There's a letter here from Cousin Brenda. She's very sorry but she
can't get down here for the dedication.
subQuotationList: ["There's a letter here from Cousin Brenda. She's very sorry but she\ncan't get down here for the dedication."]
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Oh.
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: She says that Jock has a three-line whip for this afternoon.
subQuotationList: ['She says that Jock has a three-line whip for this afternoon.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: Oh.
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: She could have come without him,
subQuotationList: ['She could have come without him,']
speaker: Molly Last

quoteText: She sends her love to us all and to Hetton.
subQuotationList: ['She sends her love to us all and to Hetton.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText:
Well, I think it's a jolly good thing, She couldn't show
much widowly grief. It didn't take her long to get hitched up again.
subQuotationList: ["Well, I think it's a jolly good thing,", "She couldn't show\nmuch widowly grief. It didn't take her long to get hitched up again."]
speaker: Molly Last

quoteText: _Molly!_
subQuotationList: ['_Molly!_']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: And you know you think the same.
subQuotationList: ['And you know you think the same.']
speaker: Molly Last

quoteText:
I will not allow you to talk like that about Cousin Brenda, whatever we
think. She had a perfect right to marry again and I hope she and Mr
Grant-Menzies are very happy.
subQuotationList: ['I will not allow you to talk like that about Cousin Brenda, whatever we\nthink. She had a perfect right to marry again and I hope she and Mr\nGrant-Menzies are very happy.']
speaker: Unknowable

quoteText: She was always jolly decent to us when she used to live here,
subQuotationList: ['She was always jolly decent to us when she used to live here,']
speaker: Agnes

quoteText: Well, I should hope so, After all, it's our place.
subQuotationList: ['Well, I should hope so,', "After all, it's our place."]
speaker: Teddy Last

quoteText:
I'm glad we put that up, You know, I should never have
thought of it, if it had not been for a Mrs Beaver. She wrote to me as
soon as the news of Tony's death was published. I didn't know her at the
time. Of course we knew very few of Tony's friends.
subQuotationList:
["I'm glad we put that up,", "You know, I should never have
thought of it, if it had not been for a Mrs Beaver. She wrote to me as
soon as the news of Tony's death was published. I didn't know her at the
time. Of course we knew very few of Tony's friends."]
speaker: Richard Last
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Lady St Cloud', 'Richard Last']], [['Lady St Cloud'], ['Tony Last'], ['Molly Last', 'Mrs Last', 'Teddy Last', 'Richard Last'], ['Tony Last']]]

quoteText: It was her suggestion?
subQuotationList: ['It was her suggestion?']
speaker: Lady St Cloud

quoteText:
Yes, she said that as one of Tony's closest friends she knew he would
wish to have some monument at Hetton. She was most considerate--even
offering to arrange with the contractors for it. Her own plans were more
ambitious. She proposed that we should have the chapel redecorated as a
chantry. But I think this is what he would have preferred. The stone
comes from one of our own quarries and was cut by the estate workmen.
subQuotationList:
["Yes, she said that as one of Tony's closest friends she knew he would
wish to have some monument at Hetton. She was most considerate--even
offering to arrange with the contractors for it. Her own plans were more
ambitious. She proposed that we should have the chapel redecorated as a
chantry. But I think this is what he would have preferred. The stone
comes from one of our own quarries and was cut by the estate workmen."]
speaker: Richard Last
mentionEntitiesList: [[['Tony Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Molly Last', 'Mrs Last', 'Teddy Last', 'Richard Last'], ['Tony Last'], ['Mrs Last', 'Molly', 'Teddy', 'Richard Last', 'Agnes']]]

quoteText: Yes, I think he would have preferred this,
subQuotationList: ['Yes, I think he would have preferred this,']
speaker: Lady St Cloud

quoteText: Coming to the stinkeries?
subQuotationList: ['Coming to the stinkeries?']
speaker: Teddy Last

quoteText:
No, I'm looking after Cousin Frances. She got rather on mother's nerves
through crabbing the new boiler.
subQuotationList: ["No, I'm looking after Cousin Frances. She got rather on mother's nerves\nthrough crabbing the new boiler."]
speaker: Agnes
